documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Hello,

I am submitting this comment in opposition of DEA scheduling of kratom.  I use kratom daily for the treatment of depression, bi-polar disorder, and PTSD.  I would be devastated by restrictions on its sale, possession or use.

I am currently disabled.  I receive Social Security benefits.  I take psychiatric medicine, which works to the extent that I am not homeless, incarcerated, or dead.  My daily life is still severely affected by these problems; before discovering kratom, I could not even take care of my personal hygiene.  I spent most days in a depressed fog in which nothing mattered to me.

Kratom has greatly improved my quality of life since I began taking it several months ago.  I feel happiness and contentment, emotions which have eluded me for decades.  Kratom gives me the energy and willpower to take care of myself.  I have never experienced any negative side-effects from taking kratom.

I am concerned about kratom's legal status for personal reasons, but also because I believe government overreach in areas of personal liberty are troubling.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Greg M.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

I hadn't previously heard of kratom, but if it aids people to kick addiction to opiates I believe it is a good thing.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

In 2009 I was struck by a car while riding on my bicycle, the driver of the car was intoxicated with alcohol and was a "hit and run" driver. The left side of my body impacted the car, my skull cracked on the hood of the car and my left temporal skull bone was fractured severely. I sustained traumatic injuries in my left neck, shoulder, rib cage,  hip, femur, and knee. My body then fell off of the car and impacted the concrete road, seriously injuring my right side, especially my right hip. I sustained multiple abrasions, lacerations, and bone fractures throughout my body. I would later wake up in the trauma intensive care unit (TICU) at the regional hospital in my state, approximately nine hours after I was struck by the car. 

I had extreme cognitive deficits and was having great difficulty with my short and long term memory, I also developed Broca's Aphasia. This type of Aphasia is a neurological disease that affected my speech, language, and communication abilities, all of which are primarily enabled by the left temporal lobe of the brain. My left temporal lobe was compressed by the inward pressure of the collapsed bone fragments from my depressed skull fracture. My skull's bone fragments came within one millimeter of lacerating a major artery in my brain, which would have almost certainly killed me through hemorrhaging. I spent the next year recovering from my body's injuries and my traumatic brain injury. It took me three months to be able to walk again with the assistance of a walker, then weeks later I could walk with a cane, then unassisted. I spent many months in neurological, physical, speech, and occupational therapy. 

Two years after my trauma and brain injury I was almost fully recovered and had overcome my Broca's Aphasia. I've always suffered from severe persistent asthma however, and in the Fall two years post-injury I was admitted into my local hospital's emergency department for a severe asthma exacerbation related to a bout of bronchitis I developed. My asthma attack took several weeks to recover from and I was prescribed heavy doses of both oral and intravenous corticosteroids to treat my lung tissue and airway inflammation. I was ordered to stay on corticosteroids for many months. 

Unfortunately, a major side effect of the corticosteroids I was given is Avascular Necrosis, which for me, was the vascular occlusion of my left and right femoral heads, the round bone "ball" extension of the upper femur that fits into the "socket" of the pelvic acetabulum. Blood supply was cut off to both my left and right femoral heads over the course of several months from corticosteroids to treat my asthma and inflammation. This lack of blood and oxygen resulted in my left and right femoral head bones dying, they became severely necrotic in their cores. 

Eventually after living with severe chronic pain for yet another year, my right femoral head fractured and collapsed in on itself while I was walking in my home. I then had to wait another two months with a collapsed femoral head and a nearly collapsed, hollow, necrosed left femoral head. My entire existence became defined by severe, unrelenting, chronic pain. I was finally able to get a right-side total hip replacement, which was a success and replaced my necrosed right femoral head, femoral neck, and upper femur with a titanium and ceramic composite prosthesis.

After going through more than three years of extreme chronic pain, traumatic brain injury recovery, neurological comorbidities, sequelae, asthma, and many dozens of hospital and rehabilitation center stays and visits, I finally knew what I wanted to do with my life. I decided to become a registered nurse, as the RN's that took care of me so compassionately throughout my many injuries and recovery periods had a profound impact on me. However, even after my hip replacement my left femoral head was still partially necrosed and my right femoral nerve was damaged in the surgery. I still suffered from severe chronic pain of musculoskeletal and neuropathic varieties. Over the past several years my daily chronic pain levels, on a scale of 1-10, have averaged from 6 to 9 out of 10.

To treat my extreme chronic pain I was prescribed numerous opioid medications. My pain levels continued to be debilitating and made both my daily routine and progress in nursing school very difficult. The opioids also caused extreme side effects and would have killed me from intestinal blockage if I continued to take them. I then found Kratom and finally found relief in this plant, my pain went down to 2-3 out of 10 and my life improved substantially. I have used Kratom for many years now and have never had side effects. I rely on Kratom for my chronic pain control, nothing else works, if it were made illegal my life would become a tortuous, burdensome existence again. This plant is a miracle for me, my life will be negatively changed by a Kratom ban, thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
Im 48 years old. For the last 10 years, I have had non-stop / 24 hours a day headaches similar to having the flu.  The condition includes pain in my ears and tinnitus.  Arthritis in my shoulders.  Sleeping is extremely difficult. I have fibromyalgia. I am sensitive to light and sound. I have seen 30+ doctors (neurologists, rheumatologist, ent, sleep docs, primary care, urgent care, long term pain management). I have spent 2 weeks in the hospital getting IV drugs, nerve blockers, and anti-seizure drugs. I have taken over 100 drugs to treat my condition with no success. 

After years of trying alternative therapies including meditation, yoga and exercise, I have found the only thing that gives me relief from the constant pain is some form of Oxycontin or Kratom.  So, the choice is to become a addicted to the most addictive pill on the market or use Kratom.  Kratom is inexpensive and doesn't appear to be addictive for me (i.e., my dosage has not increased in a year of using it).  I am terrified that the DEA will make it illegal because then my options look pretty awful (i.e., become addicted to a drug or suffer in agonizing pain).

Due to this disease, I went from being a successful Vice President of several companies driving range rovers and Mercedes Benz convertibles to laying in a darkened room petting my dogs belly for comfort. Before Kratom,  I was in such horrible pain that I contemplated suicide often.  Doctors do not like to prescribe Oxycontin for me because of fear of addiction.  Additionally, in this climate, DEA has scared doctors so much that they are unwilling to risk punishment by the DEA. The DEA has, in effect, made it extremely difficult for me to get any medical relief treatment for my pain. I wish it was possible to somehow have Doctors or the DEA feel my pain for a year, without a doubt, they would change their minds. 

I was diagnosed with New Daily Persistent Headaches (NDPH) about 6 years ago. I was so happy to get a diagnosis that I didnt realize until later that all this meant was that there are other people who suffer similarly but no one knows what causes it. The only thing doctors do know is that there is no treatment (I.e., it is refractory). 

In the last year, I started looking into Lyme and co-infections. I was tested over the years for Lyme but the tests came back negative. I didnt find out until about 6 months ago that the tests for Lyme are only about 70% accurate. So, it is possible that I have been suffering for the last 10 years and it could have been treated. At some point, shouldnt the medical community take responsibility and at a minimum treat me for pain? Instead, medical insurance doesnt cover treatment for Lyme disease and it is over $1100 for the first 2 doctors visits. 

In June 2016, a Lyme disease clinic found that I have Lyme disease, walking pneumonia, rocky mountain fever and babesia.  I am currently on 2 IV antibiotics and 4 oral antibiotics.  These are all treatable but will probably be over a year of heavy medication.  Additionally,  it has done so much damage to me in the last 10 years that even if the antibiotics eradicate the disease from my body, I could still suffer for the rest of my life.  A brain scan identified damage to both the white and gray matter in my brain.  

Kratom is a god send. It is very effective in treating my pain. Please do not make it illegal.  Making Kratom illegal without any alternative treatment will subject me to a least another year of intolerable pain.  If the pain doesn't leave when the Lyme disease and coinfections are treated, I could face a lifetime of pain without any relief.  Please should me mercy.

Thank you,
Robert Herman

My name is Sara, I am a 34 year old office manager. I have personally witnessed the positive effects of Kratom on my husband, Ryan. He is 35 and had an accident injuring his back about 10 years ago. His doctor prescribed him several painkillers and he got to the point where he was eating them like candy. About a year ago, Ryan's doctor became under investigation, and was no longer allowed to practice, for prescribing an excessive amount of painkillers and several other factors. Ryan and I tried to find a new doctor for him but no one would give him the prescriptions he had taken for many years. Ryan did not think he had became dependant on these drugs but when he got severely ill and started having major withdrawals, it was very scary to our family. I became so desperate to help him, i took him to the methadone clinic. A place i never thought he or I would ever step foot in. It was disgusting to me and he was embarassed to have to stoop that low. The people there do not want to help you to become clean, they want to keep you using their product, and talk down to you when you try to reduce your dose. After about a month of this, Ryan decided to do all the research he could into other options to help him. That's when he came across an article on Kratom. He told me about it and was very excited, but I was very skeptical and thinking this is going to be a waste of money. But at this point I was desperate to try anything to help him. He ordered a small amount online and the day it came in the mail, he drank some and did not go to the clinic. He has never went back since. Ryan has not had a pain pill since and is now totally against them. He had his wisdom teeth pulled and refused when the dentist tried to give him a prescription. Ryan will occasionally drink some Kratom if hes having back pain but he no longer takes it daily. I believe Kratom saved his life. It helped him to overcome his addiction and helped him to get his life back, with no side effects or habit forming effects. I believe Kratom should be easily available to families who have nowhere else to turn in a situation like ours. If it weren't for Ryan stumbling across Kratom by accident, i do not know what would have happened. Now we have our normal lives back and he is free from addiction. Please allow Kratom to help others the way it has helped us. I have also tried Kratom because i have Generalized Anxiety Disorder. It has helped me to feel less anxious and improved my mood. I believe Kratom can be helpful to many people and should not be considered a controlled substance. I have nothing but positive things to say about Kratom and it doesn't have that "high" effect that most painkillers do. It just helps us to live our normal lives without being addicted or feeling the need to have some everyday. 


Sincerely,
Sara Horn

documents.commentText:
My name is Denise Hartley and I am writing you today in regards to the DEA's proposed ban on Kratom. Kratom is a herbal supplement made from the crushed leaves of the kratom tree, an evergreen native to the tropics of Southeast Asia in the coffee family. The leaves can be brewed into a tea, which after ingested can provide relief from pain and anxiety. Kratom has been used medicinally, safely, for thousands of years. 

In the midst of epidemic opiod abuse in the United States, for the DEA to spend the resources on passing and enforcing a ban on kratom, I feel is a misuse of federal resources. Not only is kratom not an opiate, but it actually assists opiate addicts through withdrawal and staves off craving. The timing could not be worse to deny Americans a solution to opiod addiction. According to the CDC, in 2014 alone, there were more deaths caused by opioids than ever before in our history, with approximately 78 people dying per day. Source: https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/epidemic/

Banning kratom would also make it very difficult to do any clinical research on the medicinal properties of the herb because researchers would be required to obtain a license from the DEA and meet its stringent requirements. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/kratom-drug-ban-may-cripple-promising-painkiller-research/ Kratom is an herb that could have important implications for pain relief, anxiety, depression, PTSD and stopping opioid dependence. Kratom offers these painkilling and antidepressant effects but has less side effects such as respiratory depression which is the leading cause of death in opiod overdose. It should be available to Americans and researchers as is any other benign herbal supplement.

Kratom allows millions of Americans to function at a level they would not be otherwise able to due to chronic illness and anxiety. It is not good public policy to ban kratom and deny people the ability to use it, therefore significantly reducing their quality of life and increasing the probability of disability, drug abuse, and suicide. 

My personal story:

I am a 36 year old disabled woman. I am housebound and mostly bedbound due to illness. I am immunocompromised and am battling chlamydia pneumonia, Epstein Barr, HHV6, chronic influenza A and B, Bartonella, Babesia, Lyme Disease, mold toxicity, PTSD, depression, anxiety, and Chronic Fatigue Syndrome. Kratom allows me to have a quality of life. 

I found Kratom while desperately seeking pain control in 2014. At the time I could not walk unassisted, I was 95lbs, and in incredible pain. I began taking Kratom after experiencing pain so intense it landed me in the hospital for 6 days. I am unable to take pharmaceutical pain medications due to severe adverse reactions in each class of drugs. 

I researched intensely before deciding to use kratom. I hold a Masters degree and two undergraduate degrees. I am familiar with ethnobotanical research. I weighed the benefits and risks after reading about the medicinal uses of the herb. I believed and still believe that kratom is the least of all evils at my disposal and is actually of benefit to me.

I prefer kratom because there is no high associated with it. It's addictive properties are minimal. I have never had an issue stopping my usage or taking varying dosages. There are no cravings and withdrawal symptoms are less than that of caffeine dependency.

Kratom has relieved my pain and helped my mental illness symptoms for more than two years. When the pain from my diseases made me suicidal, I turned to Kratom. When I couldn't sleep because of my suffering, I turned to Kratom. When the PTSD from the medical trauma I endured left me curled in a ball unable to move or speak, Kratom was there. When medical science could not ease my pain, there was Kratom- an ever faithful friend holding my hand through the darkest times I have ever known.

What this ban would mean for me is the end of life as I know it. I am afraid of how much I will regress without the herb that has carried me through my darkest days. I am afraid to go back on prescription medications and experience side effects that render me completely disabled and zombie-like. I deserve a quality of life. I am not hurting anyone with my use of Kratom, least of all myself.

documents.commentText:
Kratom is not analogous to a drug at all, but to FDA-approved dietary supplements such as St. John's Wort or Valerian root. I myself have taken kratom to help the symptoms of mild to moderate depression, and as an occasional, non-addictive sleep-aid. The benefits of kratom for easing the symptoms of depression are, in my experience, almost exactly like St. John's Wort or Valerian root, but without unwanted side effects such as sensitivity to light or a dizzy, "hung-over" feeling the next day that both of the aforementioned FDA-approved supplements have caused. 

I have never found kratom to be addictive in any traditional sense of the word; going without kratom "cold turkey" after taking a moderate-sized dosage of 5-6 grams once or twice a day for several weeks resulted only in a mild headache and slight irritability for two days, exactly like quitting caffeine in the same way. 

I consider the idea that kratom should be subject to emergency scheduling as something ridiculous, especially in light of already-approved substances such as alcohol which are both directly and indirectly responsible for the deaths of many Americans every year.

As a simple dietary supplement, I consider kratom not to be a necessity at all, but certainly a boon that makes being a productive member of society easier for myself and for others. With adequate testing and vetting in the way that other dietary supplements have been processed, I have confidence that kratom can and will be a safe and healthy tool that will help many Americans to pursue happiness and well-being, as is their collective, inalienable right.

documents.commentText:
My name is Susan Farmer. I am 53 years old. I am an RN as well as a certified public health nurse for the state of California .
 I am very opposed to the DEA placing Kratom on the list of schedule one controlled substances.   I started using Kratom  three years ago to help control chronic pain .   I came to use it after being on opioid narcotics prescribed by physicians for three years.   I eventually quit the opioid narcotics due to their high addiction potential,  and increasing tolerance.   The crate him not only helped me quit taking the opioid (Easing withdrawals),  but also helped me and replacing the opiods.
 They are certainly not as strong  as the prescribed hydrocodone, but taken together with ibuprofen allow me to function in society .   Without Kratom,  my choices would be to go back on narcotic opioids,  or to go on disability.
As an RN,  I can see the potential benefit of this herb in helping millions of people  to get off of synthetic narcotics.   Millions of people are dying from overdoses related  to opioids  such as Fentanyl.  
 By keeping this herb legal,  you are saving lives, inspiring hope,  and helping to reduce crime associated with street narcotics.
 If you are  working at the DEA and you truly believe in helping people, then you need to do the right thing.   As a health professional, I will continue to support Kratom.
 Personally, I feel that marijuana is a much more dangerous drug.   I am quite sure that the pharmaceutical industry does not want this herb kept legal.  

As a  Health professional, I can claim that this herb  has improved my immune system, and general health. I have lab results to back up this claim.   Additionally, I have seen many former narcotic addicts who are now able to live without their prescribed narcotics and who are now  functioning members of society.  
In the words of Dr. Christopher McCurdy, head researcher at the University of Mississippi (where kratom has most recently been studied in the U.S.): Based on the information available in the scientific literature, we know that Kratom has been utilized for centuries by people in Thailand, without stigma associated with its use. In traditional medicine, Kratom has been used as an antidiarrheal and as a treatment for opioid dependence. Although there are suggestions that Kratom has a risk of addiction, there is no solid scientific evidence available to support or refute this idea.    
Kratom is safely improving the health and well-being of adults all across America. I support further scientific study of the plant, regulations like age restrictions, and oppose legislation or action by the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to make it a schedule 1 controlled substance that will turn hundreds of thousands of responsible kratom consumers into criminals, and cut off promising ongoing research into its many benefits.

 If you personally know or are one of the millions of people dealing with chronic pain then please do the right thing for them.  
 

Sincerely,
 Susan Farmer RN BSN PHN (CA)

I have chronic back pain related to years of using my back.  In 2016 a piece of ruptured disc, broke off and dried out, then got lodged against my sciatic nerve.  During the 2 month period prior to when I could get the surgery, I was in pain from the moment I woke up, to when I went to sleep.  My only other relief was when I could position my back in a chair with a straight enough back. Lying in bed was worse, and walking resulted in pain every step.  While several doctors offered prescriptions for opioids, I did not want to be using them for 2 months and then post surgery.  During this time, I chose to use Kratom instead.  I found the Kratom would take the edge off my pain, enough so I could move around and function. 
Post surgery, I am using turmeric which helps along with Kratom.  I have residual pain in my lower back due to degeneration of the discs, arthritis and the like.  These things have allowed me to continue without prescription opioids. 

For myself, Kratom has no more of a psychological effect than my morning coffee, and I use it regularly.  If I discontinue for a period of time, I don't notice it unless I get a "report" from my lower back. There are no withdrawals or any compulsion to use it.   I cannot imagine how this would be used for recreational use.  From what I have read, it is cheaper to buy opiates on the street.  If you take too much, there is no additional affect, it simply makes one spontaneously vomit.  

These comments are based on my personal experience.  Scientific research might help in determining addiction potential, side effects, and other potential useful information for pain relief.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Growing up my dad was one of the most active, productive people you could possibly see.  He took care of our whole household including most of the cleaning, cooking, laundry, maintenance on the house all while working full-time and pursuing a college degree.  On top of that, we were always doing fun stuff and wrestling around.

A few years ago, my mother and him were in a bad car accident while driving to dinner when they were hit my a drunk driver.  My dad's back was hurt really bad and after that, he was rarely ever the same.  You could see him sometimes have good days but he could rarely carry through finish things he started and the housework didnt always get finished.  The environment in our house completely changed as it was more stressful and less happiness.  You could see my dad get eaten away from the pain and the tension between my parents mount.  Three years after the car accident, they got divorced and I have no doubt the car accident caused it.  My dad had been taking the pain meds the doctor gave him but they kept having to give him stronger ones.  I didnt know why at the time but he was getting worse and worse, often oversleeping and not getting up in the evening to care for us.  They finally sent him away for treatment for his back although I know now it was rehab because he was using heroin.

When he came back he was sober and in a much better mood but he still hurt really bad.  But, he started using the shredded leaf of a tree.  It looks disgusting but ever since I saw he start taking it he has slowly returned to the dad I grew up with many years ago.  He still has some bad days but now those are the few compared to the good.  He is much more active, he exercises again, he wrestles around with my little sister, he takes me out to do things, he stays on top of housework, he is always working on projects, and most of all - he started his own business and is doing well at it.  The only reason he is able to do this is because he found an oral supplement called kratom.  Without kratom, he would probably still be a shell of himself and he might have to go back to using heroin to get rid of the pain.

If you schedule kratom, I dont know what will happen to my dad.  His life will likely be ruined as he will have to face using painkillers or living with horrible pain.  The wreck was not his fault, his addiction to painkillers was not his fault, and this would not be his fault.  What kind of choice is that?  I know as I start my life as an adult, I will do so not trusting my own government.  How could I when it makes a decision that could destroy my dad's life by making leafs from a tree illegal to buy or possess.  I have read all the science behind kratom and there is no danger in taking it to anyone.  Dont ruin my father's life and do not ruin my faith in our government as I dont want to live my life like that.

documents.commentText:
My name is Evan Bradford and I am a 24 year-old youth coordinator working with people with disabilities at a nonprofit organization in the state of Georgia. 

I write today to express my adamant opposition to the proposed scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as Schedule 1 substances under the Controlled Substances Act. I understand the need to study these chemicals in Mitragyna speciosa, but the plant has far greater utility as a regulated dietary herbal supplement than isolating its chemicals as controlled substances.

I first started using kratom on June 2015 and have been using it since. I use kratom in powdered form currently at a frequency of twice a week in the evenings mixed with orange juice. My usage has not increased, but I often stop using kratom for two weeks and find no problems with consuming it at the same dose after this time. I do not use kratom to self-medicate for pain or mental illness, but I use it much like melatonin and valerian root tea.

My interest in this plant began by reading Cato Institute articles about kratom, and I was motivated to write about kratom's scheduling after reading a Forbes article published on September 30th titled "The Benefits of Kratom, And Risks of Kratom Extracts, From The People Who Use The Botanical Medicine". While the article points out that anecdotal testimonies of kratom users do not tell the whole story about the utility of kratom, I support the author's viewpoints.

www.forbes.com/sites/davidkroll/2016/09/30/the-benefits-of-kratom-from-the-people-who-use-the-botanical-medicine/#64b2d3516fca

Before purchasing kratom, I researched companies online that sold kratom exclusively and found a supplier that provided excellent customer service and dependable quality. In the deregulated environment that kratom exists at this point, I have experienced no misrepresentations of kratom in my orders. I also actively communicate regularly with the company to give consumer feedback and improve their product quality.

In the past year of my kratom consumption, I have experienced no personal harms and will continue my use of kratom. I urge you to consider my viewpoint as a testament to the individual utility of kratom.

-I think most responsible adults would agree to a 18-21 y/o restriction, although I don't think it is necessary.  
-It is a member of the coffee plant family
-low dose, slightly stimulating effect
-medium dose, painkilling properties
-high dose, self limiting effect that makes you dizzy and nauseous
-highest dose, I believe the LD-50 on the most potent leaf available is multiple pounds of powdered leaf. 

I have seen this plant help COUNTLESS people and have NEVER seen it hurt people anywhere near the realm of traditional opiates. The 2 active chemicals are not traditional opiates. 

Please, I am begging you here, this is a plant medicine that is more often than not used to HELP people. There is SO MUCH propaganda out there. Please do your homework.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I was born with a disease that has left my bones very brittle, and my leg muscles atrophied with severe pain for the last eight years. 

I was placed on opiate painkillers when the pain started. Percocet and Tramadol were my doctors drugs of choice. At first I became dependent on the medication; then I became addicted. 

I also suffer extreme anxiety with agoraphobia. I was given benzodiazepines for the anxiety, which I also became addicted to. 

As you well know, opiates mixed with benzodiazepines is a very deadly combination. Many people have died from mixing these two types of medications together. 
After years of addiction, I became suicidal. I didnt want to live any longer with the pain and anxiety, nor the addiction to prescription medications.

Enter kratom, two years ago. Kratom gave me my life back. I was able to get off of the addictive medications, and regulate my pain with this wonderful herb. 

I dont get high off kratom. I take just one teaspoon three times per day, which alleviates my pain and anxiety, to the point where I am a functioning adult once again. It has also saved me from being wheelchair-bound, which I am forever grateful for.

As a result of your impending restrictive scheduling of this natural herb, my anxiety has kicked-up a thousand-fold. I dont know what I would do if this herb was taken away from me and made illegal. I do not ever want to be placed back on opiate painkillers, so I suppose Id be breaking the law by continuing to take kratom, which saved my life in more ways than one.

Please do not take this wonderful herb away from me and the other people who use it. Do research on it, yes. Regulate it for purity, yes. I have no problems with that. But dont take away an herb that has given many people hope in life again.

Hello to whoever is reading this,

We already know that prohibition does not work. Prohibition will lead to more harm than good in this country, especially over a natural substance that has not been proven to actually be harmful. It would be foolish to so quickly ban something that has not been properly researched, especially when there is no concrete evidence that it is causing a public health problem. Maintaining legal status of Mitragyna speciosa provides opiate addicts a safe way to break their addiction to dangerous opiates that claim the lives of thousands each year. Kratom is a safe way to help mitigate this ongoing opiate epidemic that has swept the nation over recent decades, which is a genuine public health issue that desperately needs to be addressed.

Thank you for taking the time to read this, hopefully common sense can be used for once to make a sensible decision.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
After living over two decades in chronic pain, for which narcotic pain killers were only a partial solution with undesirable side effects, I found kratom. I was able to dump the oxycodones and hydrocodones that had only partially controlled the nerve pain I was experiencing while making concentration and focus difficult. 

For two years I have been able to order kratom and use it to control the constant pain without losing my ability to concentrate and focus on tasks. On days I have not needed the pain control (rare), I have experienced no withdrawals as I often did with the narcotic pain relievers when I had a day I didn't need them for the pain.

Kratom has given me back my life. The last thing we need is another prohibition with the resulting black market and a new reason to make criminals out of law abiding citizens who have the right to make health care choices for themselves and prefer the choice of a safe, natural substance that has never killed anyone (despite the hyped up cases where kratom was taken along with other lethal drugs).

I suspect the facts of kratom's effectiveness coming to light has been behind this ridiculous proposed ban as pharmaceutical corporations seek to force us back their lethal drugs in order to treat chronic pain conditions to increase their profits. The plants that grow on the earth that have been used by local populations for centuries with no ill effects have no business being denied to the people who choose to use them. 

What's next? Lettuce? Coffee?

documents.commentText:
Im a 34-year-old male and an owner of 5 different successful small businesses in Boise, ID.

I am opposed to ANY scheduling or prohibition of Kratom that restricts access for responsible adults.  

Kratom tea has been a daily part of my diet for the past 6 years.

Kratom is nothing short of a miracle for myself and hundreds of thousands of other law-abiding Americans.

It is a miracle because it is safe. 

Kratom is strong enough to treat mild-moderate pain without the significant risks that far stronger prescription pain killers carry.

I discovered Kratom in the Summer of 2006 after 4 months on Percocet from suffering a catastrophic knee and leg injury in a football game. 

The injury required multiple surgeries and the pain lingers to this very day. 

For pain management, I have been individually prescribed Oxycodone, Hydrocodone and Tramadol but developed a physical (and psychological) dependency to all three over the past decade.

As a responsible adult and business owner, I DO NOT like or seek the euphoria or debilitating cognitive effects that these medications induce. 

Kratom, on the other hand, allows me to be productive and alert without impairment in judgement, motor skills or developing an opiate dependency. 

I have multiple businesses and a family to take care of and I do not know where Id be without Kratom.

I am living the American dream. 

But I am lucky.

I found Kratom while so many others are searching for a way to get their lives back and face the daily dilemma - addiction or never-ending chronic pain. 

America (real people) is suffering through an opiate epidemic. 

According to the CDC, 78 Americans die EVERY DAY from opiate overdoses, over half from prescription killers. (1) 

The vast majority are not recreational users, but people seeking to live a halfway-functional life without pain.

Banning Kratom will devastate Americans in chronic pain and make the opiate epidemic absolutely explode. 

In May 2016, opiate overdoses in Alabama doubled within 30 days of banning Kratom. (2)

Americans in chronic pain or battling addiction should not become criminals for drinking this safe tea.

Kratom should remain fully legal and accessible while it is studied by independent scientists who have absolutely no financial incentive or ties to pharmaceutical companies. 

So many of us count on Kratom to live a functional, pain-free and drug-free life.

Please do not restrict access, in any way, to this miracle tea. 

(1) https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/epidemic/
(2) thealternativeexaminer.com/lawmakers-alabama-cost-citizens-lives/

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly incon sequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Therefore, I urge you to stop the ban on kratom.

documents.commentText:
Re: Docket No.DEA-442W  
I am a 56-Year-Old Male - Caucasian - BS Degree in Biology and a Master's Degree in Psychology.  I do not use recreational drugs and limit my alcohol intake to 1-2 servings of wine, 1-2X a week.   In 2011 I had a laminectomy/fusion of the L4/5 vertebra to stabilize congenital spondylolisthesis.  For several years leading up to the surgery I was in chronic pain and under the care of my physician.  I followed the recommended treatments to attempt to avoid the surgery.  In progression - physical therapy, NSAIDs, epidurals, acupuncture, hydrocodone (Vicodin) and ultimately to morphine just prior to the surgery.  

Approximately 1 year after the surgery, I began to experience weakness in my legs, shooting pain in my hips, and sore knees and feet.  I have a very difficult time sleeping and have had to curtail exercise.  I have never been able to tolerate opioid pain medicine well and experience significant gastrointestinal issues and I cannot function in my job, due to the side effect of opioid grogginess.  I am employed as a technical expert in the petrochemical and environmental industries and I have been in a continuous random drug-testing program for the past 29 years and must declare my prescription use to my employers HR/Medical Officer.  When I had to take opioids for pain, it precludes me from some functions where I might operate safety equipment or vehicles.  After the surgery, I have refused to take opioids and only use a Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS or TNS) unit and NSAIDs, but they do not provide enough relief to sleep through the night.

During online research for pain management I became aware of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine (Kratom) and have been taking a night dose of 1-2 grams, for the last year, whenever I have a pain flare-up.  I am now able to sleep through an entire night and I wake the next day with a clear mind and do not experience the grogginess that I had with opioids.  After a year of use I have never experienced any craving for the natural pain-killer, and do not experience any side effects, nor any sensation of a "high" feeling, unlike opioids.

I urge the DEA to refrain from classifying this as a Schedule I drug and recommend that rigorous clinical trials and triple-blind studies be performed at respected medical and homeopathic institutes as well and be subject to critical peer-review by experts. Ultimately, I hope to see Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine (Kratom) to be left as a non-schedule homeopathic treatment for pain, thereby allowing the American public to be able to make our own decisions on how and with with what natural medicine we use to manage our bodies and health concerns.

documents.commentText: I think it's important to keep this as short and simple as possible, while refraining from embellishment or using emotional rhetoric.  I am a 25 year old white male. I currently work in retail and have some college education. I have been dealing with chronic migraines ever since i was 7 years old and still do. From the age of 12 to 22 I suffered from drug addiction. I mostly used a wide variety of opiates including the injection of heroine. However, I am also a recovering alcoholic and have used a vast array of other substances. I provide this background because it is important to understand why I started using Kratom. About three years ago i decided to get clean and entered a rehab, and from there a sober house and the AA/NA program. Without the tools provided to me through these programs I would not still be clean today. But it is important to note that Kratom played a very important part in keeping me on a straight and narrow path when i could have very easily relapsed. When i first got clean I already heard about Kratom through a friend who had used it before. When i felt the very strong desire to use opiates again, i turned to a local smoke shop that carried Kratom and purchased a small amount. In my opinion it saved my life that day because if i couldn't have gotten a safe alternative to opiates in the early stages of recovery i would have turned to heroine. In my opinion and from my experience, Kratom was a better alternative than Suboxone or Methadone, as I have tried both. Kratom does not have the addictive qualities or the type of effects that these drugs have. Now three years clean later I still use Kratom once in a while because I still suffer from terrible chronic migraines. I take medicine that works well reducing the frequency of the headaches, but when i have one I am mostly incapacitated, which has severely affected my ability to work. On those days i can take a dose of Kratom and it helps me get through the day. It can not go understated how much this has helped me live my day to day life now that i am a functioning member of society. In fact, It is because of Kratom that i can say that at all. If the DEA were to ban the alkaloids in Kratom, making it virtually impossible to use, my life would severely change for the worse and I don't know what i would do.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works... It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies. http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes... Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects. http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

Concerned citizen

I am writing in regards to the DEA's plan to make Kratom a Schedule 1 substance.
I am a very responsible 52-year old aerospace engineer and a family man. I pay more than my fair share in taxes and by most measures I am considered a very successful contributor to society. I maintain a good quality of life despite suffering from chronic neck pain (I have had two neck surgeries). Throughout three decades of chronic pain, I have tried many prescription medications that have been ineffective, have side-effects and/or have addiction risk (e.g., Vicodin).  However, beginning approximately three years ago, I found pain relief through the use a natural remedy - Kratom. I purchase Kratom powder from a reputable supplier and I make capsules that I consume. Kratom provides relief from pain and it doesn't "get me high".  I only use Kratom when the pain is at its worst. It has not been addictive whatsoever. It has been a Godsend to relieve pain while allowing me to function normally. The government should not take away my right to use this natural and safe remedy. Please, do not classify Kratom as a Schedule 1 substance.  Losing the right to use this natural remedy will very negatively impact my quality of life and my ability to contribute to society. Without Kratom, I will likely choose to live with constant pain. I do not want to use prescription opiates that prevent me from functioning at the level needed for my job.  Further, prescription opiates present an addiction risk that has not been an issue with Kratom. I also question whether the Executive Branch has the right to make this determination.  Isnt it the job of Congress to make laws and the responsibility of the Executive branch enforce them??  

Thank you for considering my situation as you debate this matter. I think my story is a common one and this is a tremendous quality of life issue for me.  

Sincerely,

Matt Kistner

I am a 60 year old woman, retired from the non-profit field.

Acting on the suggestion of a friend, I have been using Kratom for over two years now. I take it daily, primarily to help with mood and I find it to have a slight but real effect, comparable to a very low dose of an anti-depressant.

Sincerely,

documents.commentText: I started using kratom about 8 months ago. A friend had told me that it was cheap, legal, and gave a nice sense of euphoria or "high". Foolishly I tracked it down and ordered some online, thinking that since it's legal it must be relatively harmless. Boy was I wrong. Within a couple weeks I was physically dependent on kratom, unable to stop due to the severity of the withdrawal symptoms (anxiety, restlessness, insomnia, nausea, general discomfort, and more) which would occur within a few hours of missing a dose. I was spending upwards of 5 hundred dollars a month on this drug. Even more troubling, I have no idea what was actually in the drug that I was ordering online since it's not regulated by the FDA. For all I know, there were lots of harmful additives or byproducts in the kratom I was receiving. Anyway I finally reached out to family and told them I had a problem, and that I needed help to quit. I was able to quit the drug just by sheer grit as the horrendous withdrawal symptoms wracked my body for 3 days. This is not a fate I would wish on anyone (except possibly the numerous companies online and on the street that sell the drug with impunity). Please make this drug ILLEGAL. It is addictive, and incredibly harmful. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Personally I used Kratom for 13 years.  Quality control was an issue, and also since Kratom is weak and not for parties, wholesalers added research chemicals to Kratom beginning in 2009, which is why Indiana was the first state to ban Kratom.  Enhanced Kratom, "isolated alkaloids".  I don't really believe enhanced Kratom had anything to do with Kratom.                          o-desmethyltramadol, a cleaner version of tramadol, was added I believe.  Who knows what else was added to Kratom to make it appealing to hedonistic drug seekers.  So banning Kratom is really trying to ban research chemicals imo.  -------  Kratom is good and bad, weak if anything, benign, but I found functionality with it and worked despite fibromyalgia, and extreme extremity pain.  Chronic pain, and I have feet problems.  I also abstained from alcohol for 13 years while using Kratom.  Kratom doesn't mix well with many things.  Kratom did make me euphoric maybe once a week or so with daily use.  I could not take it in the morning and experience euphoria.  It seemed to work better later in the day.  

I doubt Kratom has ever killed anyone, it never caused me any respiratory depression.  Never any heart problems like some people want to suggest.  I can't say I respected Kratom always, so I can attest to it's safety.  I quit a year ago because I am living in a banned state now.  I didn't have any withdrawals.  I had mental cravings at times before a year ago.   Kratom is nice like a cup of coffee.  It is not strong, also it makes ones tolerance for nicotine lower so one uses less nicotine.  

   It would be nice if Kratom was regulated like cigarettes are now, by the FDA, perhaps taxed as well, it would be worth it to me.  I hated getting bad quality Kratom.  Even bad Kratom was generally good though.  There are at least 10 different types of Kratom that has different effects.  I have never seen or heard of anyone going crazy on it as suggested by some folks who have no experience with it.  I have known quite a few professionals using it.  Kratom doesn't do much.  It also never seems to lose it's effectiveness over time, like months like other things do.  It does lose effectiveness in the short term.  It is much like coffee in that one gets diminishing returns quickly.  But also is like coffee in that it works for years. 

 Thank you for reading.  The people that support Kratom are some of the nicest people I have ever known.  They all maybe have experience with harder things, but are willing to compromise for kratoms lack of hedonism.  Kratom doesn't do much at all except give a mild mood lift sometimes, make one work harder, make one friendlier if they are in pain, helps fibromyalgia.  It would be nice if herbs and such were regulated.  That there was a specific dose and quality checks in place.  Thank you for your time on this boring subject to you probably.  I don't know about fairness, and people having jobs and such... The older I get and the more educated I become, I get sour, hopefully you can make a good decision based on the American population and not Doctors prescribing chemicals that are patented, and people that benefit from the legal system.   Information and education helps society.  Most people want one sentence to sum up things, Kratom can't be summed up in one sentence.

documents.commentText: I would like to give my story on kratom and how it saved the relationships I have with my family, friends, coworkers, and strangers. When I was a senior in high school I started to develop a social anxiety. I had a lot of friends and was generally pretty outgoing. My anxiety didn't affect my ability to talk to people or meet strangers. The social amxiety I developed was sweating of my buttocks. It started off in class one day my butt just felt hot and I didn't know why. To make a long story short, it started to get worse and it became something that occurred anytime I was around people. I still didn't know why until I did my research, it never happened when I was alone, only around people. I would worry about it, which would trigger it. It happened more often and became worse. The smell that it gave off was one that made eyes water. I became depressed and avoided human contact when possible. One day I discovered kratom. I did some research on kratom and gave it a try next time I went to hang out with friends. I now take kratom whenever I encounter a situation where the anxiety would kick in and it makes my mind not focus on my anxiety (which thinking about it was what triggered it). I have not beaten my anxiety, when not on kratom it still kicks in strong, but I have reduced its effects drastically and am still working to beat it. If kratom is made illegal I don't know if I could go on with how my relationships will be ruined. It's hard to act normal and enjoy yourself when you smell worse than a dumpster, even though I shower every day. I have heard plenty of stories of people relieving pain and kicking drug addiction with kratom but I haven't heard many anxiety stories. I just thought I should give a point of view on its other treatments. Kratom saved my life, I don't want it to go into shambles. Please don't schedule kratom. I have never had any bad effects in my year since discovering it. It helps thousands of people get their lives together when they would be a mess without it. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Dear Government Regulator,

Thank you for taking the time to review my comment. My name is Andrew and I am a 24 year old recent university graduate holding a 4 year degree in Business Administration. I am writing this in reference to "Docket No. DEA-442W". For the purpose of this comment "kratom" will be referencing "Mitragyna speciosa". First I would like to start out by stating my stance on the subject matter after which I will provide personal experience along with scientific evidence. 

Kratom is a natural tree-like plant belonging to the Mitragyna genus of the Rubiaceae family, the same plant family as coffee [1]. Kratom is not a chemical, it is not a bath salt, and it is not a recreational drug. Kratom cannot be smoked, and has a foul taste.

I am opposed to any scheduling of kratom. I believe kratom should be classified as a dietary supplement. The Center for Regulatory Effectiveness states their "position is similar to the program in place in Canada where kratom is classified as a natural health product." [3]

I have consumed kratom tea for 4 years to improve general wellbeing and to support healthy digestion. During these 4 years I have only experienced positive effects. I never had an adverse effect from the consumption of kratom tea. During these 4 years, I brought my body mass index from a 26.5 (overweight) to a 23.7 (normal) [2]. I have stomach issues from consuming coffee and thus consume kratom, in the form of a warm tea, as an alternative for an energy boost in the morning. Just as it would be unconstitutional to restrict some ones usage of coffee, it would be unconstitutional to restrict my ability to drink kratom tea as a natural way to increase my energy and productivity levels.

Kratom also helps me stay focused on tasks at hand. In these past 4 years I self-taught myself video game design, I created an artist persona and successfully released music, and created a YouTube channel that has brought in a small amount of revenue. Just as some people have benefits from one coffee in the morning, I get the same effect from kratom in terms of productivity. A few hours of lost productivity in a day might not seem like much. But in terms of a few decades, I truly believe this could amount to thousands if not hundredths of thousands of dollars I would be missing out on due to lost productivity, and thus decreasing my quality of life in the years to come. That is not fair, and I urge you to make the correct choice regarding this matter.

The Florida Department of Health "reports no pervasive health issues attributed to the ingestion of Kratom products in Florida." [4] In a study financed by the Ministry of Health-Malaysia, that "investigated the acute toxicity of standardized MS leaf aqueous extract on Sprague Dawley rats" [6], no deaths were observed and "the single oral dose of the extract also had no significant changes in the body weight, food and water consumption. The relative weights of the internal organs were also normal" [6]. 

I would like to end with a quote from Dr. Walter C. Prozialeck's "Update on the Pharmacology and Legal Status of Kratom" article from the Journal of the American Osteopathic Association: "After evaluating the literature, I can reach no other conclusion than, in pure herbal form, when taken at moderate doses of less than 10 to 15 g, pure leaf kratom appears to be relatively benign in the vast majority of users" [5]. Kratom is my dietary supplement which I consume in the form of tea. Kratom has increased my productivity, improved my general well-being, and overall improved my quality of life.

Thank you for taking my comment into consideration and God bless you!

1.	http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2094342
2.	https://www.rush.edu/health-wellness/quick-guides/what-is-a-healthy-weight
3.	http://www.thecre.com/forum11/?p=301
4.	http://speciosa.org/official-statewide-intelligence-drug-report-kratom-and-the-impact-to-florida/
5.	http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524
6.	http://speciosa.org/acute-toxicity-study-of-standardized-mitragyna-speciosa-korth-aqueous-extract-in-sprague-dawley-rats/

documents.commentText:
My name is Adam Stevens; I'm a 38-year old IT professional from North Chesterfield, Virginia. 
I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEA/FDA intent to schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine. 

My Story: In February of 2010, I started suffering back-pain and sciatica symptoms, due to a bulging disc in my lower back. After visiting with my doctor, I was prescribed hydrocodone for pain. For several months I continued taking hydrocodone, but my symptoms were getting worse. The next treatment was a lumbar epidural steroid injection; this helped for a couple of months, but after those couple of months, my pain symptoms worsened. I started seeing an orthopedic doctor. Based off an MRI, my orthopedic doctor recommended surgery (to remove a portion of the disc that was bulging), and diagnosed me with degenerative-disc disorder. After having micro-discectomy surgery, I continued taking prescribed medicine for pain, but also during this time, read about kratom. When my prescription for pain medicine was empty, I had a choice to make, go ask the doctor for more pain medicine, or try a natural alternative. Instead of asking for another prescription of pain medication, I started taking kratom tea, as needed, for pain. 

Kratom has helped me deal with nagging to severe back-pain. While taking prescription pain medication, I always felt brain-fog, lack of motivation, and lack of concentration. Kratom does not give me brain-fog, or lack of motivation, and I feel that it helps my concentration. Kratom has allowed me to function without the need for prescription pain medication. I do not want to go back to asking a doctor for pain medication. I do not want to deal with all of the side effects of prescription pain medication. 

Conclusion: Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important uses and has changed my life. I fear any scheduling by the FDA/DEA will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic. documents.commentText:
Greetings,

I am a professor, with multiple advanced degrees, with a debilitating disease that left me bedridden and on welfare for almost 8 yrs. 

I was in the hospital every month for about a week, and lost all of my teeth from all the vomiting. I have ectopic endometriosis that had eaten into some organs causing sickness and extreme pain. Doctors wouldn't treat me because I had no insurance. Eventually I couldn't deal with the pain anymore and nearly killed myself by ODing on Benadryl. 

Yes, you can OD on Benadryl, but not on Kratom. 

Thanks to my husband, I survived, and soon he came home and told me about Kratom, which he heard about online from a forum where a heroin addict had started taking it as part of rehab to quit. 

That was two years ago. Kratom literally did save my life. I was able to get my career back on track and my family was able to go off welfare and get our own house. 

My disease is not curable, barely treatable with frequent surgeries. the last one was five hrs long. Endo was in my gi tract, fused parts of it to my low back muscles and eaten into my sciatica, gallbladder, appendix, urinary tract, and internal abdominal wall.

With Kratom, I can deal with the pain, depression and low energy from my disease because it treats all of those things.

The statements made by the DEA are without merit, you cannot get high, hallucinate, or OD on Kratom. It is far safer than many prescriptions that treat these health problems.

Kratom is a tropical plant in the coffee family from Southeast Asia that has been used to support energy and focus, as well as a potent immune system booster.  Kratom is inherently safe and shares many therapeutic constituents in common with other widely recognized medicinal plants such as Cats Claw and Yohimbe, which currently enjoy wide spread and safe usage as dietary supplements in the United States and abroad. A simple Google search for Mitragyna speciosa will find over 1,660 search results documenting the potential medical value of Kratom. There are millions of people in America who use Kratom for depression, anxiety, insomnia, pain relief, energy and other legitimate health issues. 

Please help keep Kratom legal and available for us.

documents.commentText: I am disheartened to hear about your intention to schedule Kratom as a controlled substance. My depression was totally gone, and to this day has not returned. ALL the prescribed drugs previously mentioned have VERY real undesirable side effects, while the Kratom tea has none.    I fully understand that the profits of many big drug manufacturers will be adversely affected by allowing the public unrestricted access to this plant, but PLEASE let's keep our priorities straight. documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText: I am opposed to the prohibition of the alkaloids found in the leaf referred to as kratom. I have taken it for three years and it has been extremely useful in allowing me to work a strenuous job and take care of my family. After a bad car accident in 2009 I was put in pain management and supplied monthly with a hefty dose of opiates. At first it was helpful but eventually it almost cost me my family. The opiates left me in a fog all the time and I began to spiral out of control. After 3 years of prescribed use I lost my job, crashed my car and missed my daughter's important surgery as a direct result of the painkillers I was taking. I was given an ultimatum by my wife to get off pain pills or get a divorce. I have 4 children who I love and cherish and the answer was easy: to discontinue taking opiate medication. I was tapered by method of  Suboxone and I successfully quit the pain medication. However the results of my car accident came glaringly back into my life. I was in so much pain and discomfort that I was pretty much useless. I spent most of the day in the shower or in bed trying to catch up on lost sleep from pain. This went on for months after my taper and I started to become really depressed. I thought about taking pain meds again but realized that wasn't a viable option. I had had years of physical therapy including acupuncture, trigger point injections, coritozone injections and chiropractic visits. They could not relieve the pain I was in. So in desperation I tried to find something natural that wasn't addicting and wouldn't ruin my life. That's when I found kratom. Having been on daily on 4 morphine, 6 Norco and 6 baclofin I was well aware of how opiates affected me. When I began to use kratom I could find no comparison between the two. It helps my mild to moderate pain with no inebriation and no craving to keep wanting to dose. It does fall short of my acute severe flair ups but helps it to be more manageable. I have e now been working for two and a half years straight with no late shows or absents. My employer took me back after I explained I had been on opiates before and that was why I was extremely unreliable. I was graciously given a second chance and I have been productive, reliable and responsible. I can only attribute this to kratom as it's the only thing I take. My pain is manageable and I am able to focus on my job and my family. My wife thinks ita a godsend considering the hell she was forced to live in during my time on Rx pain meds. Recently she had a hysterectomy and had a difficult time refilling her Rx pain meds because the surgeon wanted her dr to fill it but the dr refused to get back with her and place the order. She took powdered kratom leaf in gel capsules to help ease the pain of her incisions and insides. It helped her to get through weeks of pain and discomfort. She stopped taking it with no problems what so ever. Though it is anecedotal evidence to use it is fact. Kratom has been very beneficial to our lives. We have had no negative impacts from taking it and a ban would be very harmful to our family. Please reconsider this action and be aware of the reality for many people who it has benefited. I and many I know would be willing to undergo examination to document the positive effects it has had with minimal negatives. Don't let my children lose their father to pain and depression because of sensationalized media stories. The truth is kratom has helped many many people suffering from chronic pain, and the evidence shows prolonged opiate use has far more negative effects than positive. You are well aware of the negative effects of Rx pain meds as the supply has been reduced , the process to get prescribed has been tightened and the scrutiny  of those prescribing is high. Let us responsible adults take our leaf in peace and enjoy being able to live life freely not burdened by pain. Thank you

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I suffer from a rare and pretty obscure disease called Mast Cell Activation Syndrome. I experience debilitating chronic pain, chronic fatigue and when I'm in a state of anaphylaxis, I experience severe anxiety. In my city, no doctors knows of it and the treatment I get is extremely limited and of very little use.

Kratom allows me to be functional. Without it, I can barely get around, let alone do the most basic tasks most people take for granted like cleaning or even showering.

I have been using kratom almost daily for three years now, as of yet I have not experienced an increase in tolerance.

I urge you to reconsider putting kratom as a Schedule I substance, preventing it from being studied. It helps so many people with debilitating diseases and seems so promising in terms of studies.

Furthermore, the notice of intent filed by the DEA to temporarily designate Kratom (specifically its alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine) as a schedule 1 drug listed 33 footnotes/references, but the actual references themselves were not included in the document.

Since, a FOIA request for all of the data and documents referenced in the 33 footnotes has been submitted, but was denied. This is extremely worrisome. If the data behind the apprehensions of the DEA are solid, why not have them open to social commentary?

When there are substances like cigarettes and alcohol available to any adult, substances that have no medicinal value whatsoever and who can provoke well documented severe health issues, it is hard to fathom the reasons that could motivate the DEA to classify a fairly harmless substance like kratom Schedule I without fearing something more nefarious is at work, something else than the well being of the American citizens.

Please, in my name and the name of all people who suffer daily from terrible maladies, do not take away this precious plant.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom as a safer alternative, But if you mark it as a Schedule I designation then its role in opioid treatment would have to immediately stop. 
It is being actively studied in the U.S for therapeutic uses and should be allowed to continued to do so.

Your emergency scheduling action would have subjected anyone caught with any quantity of kratom to long prison sentences and would halt all scientific investigations into kratom's medicinal benefit;, seems a little premature to me. That move would also make it impossible to enact sensible legal regulations, such as quality control measures, product labeling requirements, as well as marketing, branding and retail display restrictions, which are long proven to reduce substance misuse and youth access. 

Decisions about how drugs are classified and regulated should be guided by science, not by law enforcement. Scheduling decisions should be led by federal health agencies, with input from independent scientists and experts.

If Your emergency scheduling action goes into effect, more people who struggle with addiction will be criminalized.  Which in this day and age, we are finally moving away from, with our deeper knowledge in science and our further understanding that drug addiction is a medical issue not a criminal issue.

documents.commentText:
**At 8am this morning I took my first dose of kratom. 1/2 tsp of each. Green Zombie and Super red Suma. At 10 my sister and I went to vote, took 15 almost to park... An hour plus of standing in line At 30 minutes my back started hurting by 45 minutes it got to a 6, by the time we got to the car I was at a 7. Normally on two tramadol I would have had 10-15 minutes, at the end of that time its severe and about a 7 plus. The pain going from my back down to my hips and down the front of my right thigh. I refused to sit down, I was starting to sweat and the trembling never started. My sister said I was moaning but I don't remember. BUT I made it so much longer, I am so amazed. I got home and took just the red and it knocked me out, which wasn't hard as I was up all night. OBTW, I was able to do a quick trip in Walmart too!**

That was my Facebook post from October 28, 2016

That was also the first time since early 2013 that I have stood or walked so long. I was completely amazed and happy. I have been taking Tramadol over two years and was taking 6 a day and never got relief like that. Even in the beginning I never did. After my surgery on Oxycontin I got some time like that but not once I was off of it.

I never wanted to be on a heavy pain medication, Hydrocodone was too hard for me. I did not like Lyrica either. For pain/depression I was on 900mg of Neurontin, 90mg Cymbalta, 6 50mg Tramadol a day.  I slept almost 16 plus hours a day and when I was awake I was a zombie. I was confused, I couldn't put complete sentences together. I stayed depressed and suicidal.

I have weaned off the Tramadol, tapered down the Neurontin to 300mg at night and Cymbalta to 40mg at night. I am in a lot more pain but mentally more stable and more alert. I can talk like a normal person mostly now too. 

I tried Kratom for my pain and it worked amazingly, better than I hoped for.  It worked on my pain without messing with my head. It did not leave me tired and fatigued.

I have degenerative disc disease, spinal stenosis in L3, L4 L5, had two laminectomies in L4, L5, 4 herniated disks, ostepenia , arthritis of the spine, degenerative spondylolisthesis, L4 & L5 are at a grade 1 as of last year. I have chronic migraines, I was shot in the head when I was 15 years old, bone fragments and bullet fragments still in. I have a deviated septum that causes chronic sinusitis. I have cubital tunnel and carpel tunnel in my right arm, just carpel in the left arm, TmJ, tinnitus, diabetes.

As a chronic pain patient I never wanted a heavy narcotic or opiate and Kratom fills that bill. Tramadol, Cymbalta, Neurontin, Lyrica and Hydrocodone have all messed with my mental abilities and left me tired. I do not even drink alcohol. 

Please leave us this natural option!

Sincerely,

Kelly Ann Bortner

documents.commentText:
My name is Alison. I am 68 years old and I would like to share my experience with kratom. I have never taken it myself, but I believe that it should be made available to anyone who finds it useful. My son was in a terrible car accident years ago. He had many corrective surgeries and has suffered with pain ever since. The pain got to a level that he needed some sort of relief to be able to function as a normal person and to sleep. Norcos were really the only thing that worked consistently. Everything was fine for awhile, but the thing with opiates is you keep needing to take more and more for the same effect. At a certain point, the negatives outweigh the positives. But at this point youre dependent on them and its very difficult to stop. 
   During this time, I could tell that something was off. The light in his eyes just wasnt there anymore and I could tell he was depressed. He stopped hanging out with friends and family more and more. I didnt know what the problem was, but I should have pressed him harder. At one point he finally asked me for help and it all made sense. 
   I asked a friend of mine who had a son that suffered from addiction. She was the one who told me about kratom. After a couple weeks, I could see an immediate difference in my son. He said it helped the chronic pain about as well as the opiates did, but with minimal side effects. I am no doctor, but I could see the difference with my own eyes. I had my son back and all because of a simple plant.  
   When I heard that the DEA announced they were going to ban this plant and make it schedule I, I thought it must be a mistake. With the problems that this country has with opiates, it is unbelievable that anyone would even consider doing this. Banning kratom will take it away from all the people who have turned their lives around from its use. Why would you ban something that has killed no one to force people back on something that we know does? At one point when we were talking about it, my son broke down and cried. He feared that this would ruin the rest of his life.
   I do have hope though. The fact that you are taking comments and listening to the public in this matter is encouraging to me. It makes sense that you thought kratom was just a legal high sold in gas stations, and you didnt know the real side of it. Please listen to what thousands of us are saying and take advantage of this opportunity to study kratom and learn more about it. If it is proven to be dangerous, then I do not want my son to be taking it. But considering that in 2014, prescription opiates killed more than 14,000 people alone, I think the answer is obvious. You now have the opportunity to do the right thing and make a difference in this country. For the sake of my son and millions of others like him, please keep kratom a legal supplement available to all. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
To whom it concerns:

I am in my final year of medical training, and if there is one thing that I have learned as a certainty, it is that the common prescribed opiates that are given for pain relief today in hospitals are a double edged sword.  While they can be effective, they often cause dependency that leaves patients constipated, mentally dull, yet still needing and wanting more of the drug. 

While mitragynine is rarely used and under researched,  the few patients I have met who self-medicate with it seem to convalesce much more smoothly and with effective pain control, compared to today's main-stream opiates. For this reason, it is my firm opinion that mitragynine needs further research and standardization by the medical community as a possible substitute for the problematic analgesics we have today. While this may not be the most popular opinion in all parties, it certainly appears to be the morally responsible option. 

Thank you,
Michael Goldzman
