documents.commentText:
Hello, 

I am writing to you about the benefits of Kratom. I was diagnosed with a severe case of restless leg syndrome, a symptom of a neurological disorder. I have been prescribed medication solely made for RLS, however it is only effective for a short amount of time. I was then prescribed tramadol, which took care of it, but it has severely addictive properties and even worse withdrawal symptoms. I got pregnant 2 years ago with my first child, and my PCP told me I had to stop taking it. I asked her for an alternative, however they did not offer one and expected me to stop cold turkey (which can be very harmful to the body, and cause seizures). When I spoke with my ob/gyn, Sh le told me that tramadol is not addictive. My RLS became unbearable. I had heard about Kratom, and decided to try it. To my surprise, it completely relieved my RLS. I was getting about 2 hours of broken sleep during the period of not taking anything, but with the relief I got from Kratom, I was able to get a full night's sleep and have exhaustion not interfere with my job (I work in an emergency department). The only other things that will relieve RLS are opiates, and I did not want to risk taking those and becoming addicted. Kratom is in no way like the drugs that are currently considered schedule 1 substances; it does not give me any sort of "high", because if it did I would be unable to do my job which requires a clear mind and my full attention. I just recently gave birth a week and a half ago, was given Tylenol 3, which provided no relief from the postpartum pains. Taking Kratom has not only relieved my RLS, but also the cramping I have been experiencing. 

Please consider doing more research on Kratom, instead of banning it altogether based on poorly gathered evidence (patients who have passed while taking it, because in the 15 cases mentioned, they were on other substances as well). Kratom is a very helpful supplement that needs to be studied, not banned. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

I have seen it give immeasurable help to people trying to avoid prescription medication.  To think that this incredibly safe and effective tool would be scheduled and banned as a dangerous substance is mind boggling to me.  There is clearly no evidence of Kratom being a danger to ANYONE when taken responsibility.  It is FAR safer AND more effective than legal substances like alcohol and tobacco, as well as EVERY single prescription medication used for similar conditions (oxycodone, paxil, Prozac, valium, Xanax, etc.)  Why would we prevent the American population from a safer more productive life?

documents.commentText:
To whom this may concern,
I am a 38 year old male who responsibly consumes Kratom. I am gainfully employed and I also go to school full time while maintaining a 3.8 GPA. A little background regarding why I started taking Kratom. I used to be a heroin addict and wasnt doing anything to be productive in society. Actually I was doing the opposite. Ive almost lost my life due to the depression that is accompanied by the use of heroin. Why should I go on living like this? My family disowned me especially my father. One day I came home to him telling me that I was kicked out of the house because I had stolen money from him. This was the last straw for him and he offered to drive me to a homeless shelter. This hit me hard and I made a decision that I was done with heroin. I called rehab facilities trying to find a bed open. No one seemed to have a bed open unless you had insurance, which I did; the only problem is that I had maxed out my mental health insurance because I had been fighting this disease of addiction for the past 4 years, spending time in and out of rehabs. All of them were telling me that I had to wait at least 30 days before they could get me in through the state. I finally found a rehab that would accept me but I had to pay for room and board, which was still $500 a week. I was in this particular rehab for almost 2 months and was on suboxone maintenance while I was in there. Around 10 days before they were to release me, I made the decision to stop taking suboxone because I didnt want to have to go through the withdraws outside of rehab. I didnt know if I would be able to do it without relapsing. I was released on January 10, 2014 and most of the withdraws were gone but noticed that I kept getting very bad headaches everyday.  One day I woke up with a different kind of headache. It felt like my head was being pierced by a hot metal rod and squeezed in a vice at the same time. I tried to sleep it off but was in sooooo much pain that I decided to go to the emergency room. They gave me some medication and released me without a diagnosis. The next day the same feeling came back and I ended up back at the emergency room again. Within those two weeks I was having headaches almost every single day, so I was forced to search for alternative ways to help with headaches. That is how I became familiar with Kratom. With the exercises that the emergency room doctor explained for me to do and consuming kratom, I was able to almost eliminate my headaches completely. There were some times that the headaches were there but for the most part they were gone. Back to the primary care physician. She had looked me over and came to the conclusion that I needed to go see a neurologist. I was written a referral to see a neurologist.I got it done and they forgot to scan me without the dye in my body so I actually had to have 2 MRIs done. The first one had an abnormal looking spot on it so they wanted me to get some blood work done, which I did and the major issues were ruled out. Thank God. The neurologist finally came to the conclusion that I was having migraines. Ummm no duh!! About $5000 later I got the answer that I already knew. The neurologist had prescribed me a blood pressure medication which I couldnt take because of all the side effects such as drowsiness, ED, dizziness, and vertigo.  I believe that without this supplement I would still be having those migraines, which I cannot afford to have because of school and work. An added bonus to consuming Kratom is that I am more active now and have lost some fat due to being able move around more, and am able to tolerate the pain in my knees. If this plant is taken away from us, it will do more harm than good. With the opiate epidemic out of control this country needs every little tool, every little stepping stone to get us out of it. By scheduling this plant, you are taking one of the most effective tools away from my and thousands of other people's hands. Just because it touches the opioid receptors you want to label it as harmful and an imminent threat to society. I have to disagree. I was very skeptical when I first started researching it, because I am an ex heroin addict and the image that was in the public eye was that it is a harmful drug. I can assure you that I wont go and rob someone to get kratom. I can assure you that I wont steal items from a store to pawn off for kratom. I dont want to have to go see a doctor to get prescribed something that is natural and effective for my needs. I havent found a better solution to my problem. I dont want to have to start over again, and possibly not find a solution. Keep this natural plant legal and add age limits, come up with a solution to this, where it has to be screened for adulterants and regulate it within reason, but to schedule it will do nothing but create another black market item and potentially create thousands of felons out of a society that seems to be mostly responsible consumers.

documents.commentText: Simply put, it is objectively illogical to ban a plant as benign as Kratom. There is no legitimate reason to declare this substance as a greater danger than Methamphetamine. The true reason this is even being discussed is blatant - thousands have weaved off of prescription Opiates (which, by this logic, should be scheduled even more vigorously than Kratom) using Kratom, as it's mechanism of action takes place in the opioid receptors - to a much lesser degree than pharmaceuticals. The saddening reality is that their fight to vilify Kratom with their monetary influence has taken the large corporations this far. I truly hope that you, the reader, takes a good hard look at studies from a variety of sources. As long as a nonbiased comprehensive analysis is achieved, there is no doubt in my mind this Scheduling will be retracted. However, if the DEA does move forward in scheduling, the true priorities will be painfully obvious to the American people (which, I may add will lead to thousands of opiate addicts relapsing and even dying. Death that YOU could have prevented simply by truly evaluating the 'dangers' of the plant.). All I can truly hope for at this point is the overwhelming voice of the people will not be drowned out by the few that would benefit from the ban. This, right here, right now is setting precedent for the direction of this country. It is up to you to do what is right, you can be a part of a decision that influences the life of not only us, but also the generations to come. Thank you, and I hope you are committed to doing what is truly the best for society.

documents.commentText:
I can't stress enough how safe and sound of a plant kratom is.  

In the past 7 years I have been prescribed 5 different medications, 3 of which I was still taking until about a year ago when I found Kratom.  Though I took my Doctors advice and stayed on these medications for the better part of a decade - the positives only barely outweighed the negatives (terrible side effects that I forced myself to cope with, including ongoing issues with my testicles that ultimately cost me my sex-life (yes, I'm 24 years old and wasn't sexually active for most of the last 5 years). Out of all the medications my Doctor had me try, the ones which I stayed on still had these terrible side effects. I had no other options. Since discovering Kratom I was able to safely substitute this for all of my Rx medications. 

Once again, I can't stress enough how safe and sound of a plant this is. 
The proof is crystal clear how beneficial this plant is and the safety profile couldn't be any safer.  It is extremely low risk.  It is barely any different than green tea.  I make tea out of this every morning to start my day. I consider myself a very productive member of society. 

It is clear that this plant is understudied.  Future studies Will confirm the safety profile of this plant. Given how safe it is, people deserve the right to make tea out of this Kratom as they please.  I used to drink a pot of coffee a day and take 5 medications before 9am, but now I have 2 cups of tea in place of all of that. Simply banning this plant would lack simple logic. 

I can't stress enough how safe and sound of a plant kratom is. 
It has changed the lives of tens of thousands of people in the United States - and it will continue doing so for many years to come. Especially those who have been opiate- addicted.
We have an opiate epidemic sweeping the country taking the lives of unsuspecting children into the dark cold hands of death, leaving behind scarred families and communities. 
Those who are in need deserve a second chance, and that second chance is Kratom. 

Please, don't ban a plant that is helping thousands of Americans who are in desperate need for positive change.  

Think of our children, our families, and our friends.  
Do what's right - allow this plant to be legally regulated - but NOT made illegal. 

You never know who You know that may be helped tremendously by this herb.

documents.commentText:
Thanks for taking the time to read my comment.  Kratom has been enormously helpful to me during my recovery from heroin and methamphetamine addiction.  Using Kratom has allowed me to deal proactively with my periods of craving and withdrawal from what are known to be dangerous drugs.  I've been sober for 21 months.  Before going to rehab, I was sober for maybe a handful of days during a span of about 18 years.  I had A LOT of adjustments to make in my thinking and how I related to the world.  Kratom has helped me feel 'normal' and has allowed me to meet the many challenges of newly found sobriety with strength and minimal emotional and physical discomfort.  I used Suboxone, under medical orders, during my initial phase of acute withdrawal; it helped enormously, but was not ideal for me for long term use.  Suboxone negatively affected my memory, sex-drive and emotional state.  Being on Suboxone for an extended length of time was nearly as troublesome as being back on heroin.  With Kratom, I experience NONE of the side-effects I had with Suboxone.  Kratom is nothing short of miraculous.  The only negative effects I've experienced from Kratom came from when I first began taking it, and being inexperienced, I took too much.  The result?  Nausea that lasted for a couple of hours, that's it.  Comparing the effects of Kratom to the effects of hard drugs is GROSSLY INACCURATE.  Hard drugs kill.  For that matter, caffeine kills, tobacco kills, alcohol kills- people even die from misusing sugar or water.  The dose makes the poison.
Scheduling Kratom will help no one.  Thanks for your time.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madame,

Please keep Kratom off DEA's Schedule I list and allow for more studies to be performed on this helpful herbal supplement. I am a 40-year-old working professional who has been responsibly using Kratom for more than 8 years to treat my chronic medical condition. This herbal remedy relieves my symptoms without the troublesome side effects I experience with pharmaceutical alternatives. I honestly cannot work as effectively as an attorney while using the pharmaceutical medication prescribed to treat my medical condition. 

I suffered through my condition for years until a dietician recommended Kratom to me in 2008. I'm truly dismayed at the news that it may be listed in the same category as heroin and cocaine. In regards to allegations of its addictive qualities, I would honestly liken it to coffee. I use it 3-4 times daily. It's a helpful addition to my day, one I've grown reliant upon, but I do not suffer the withdrawals some associate with pharmaceutical pain killers or other drugs and I have certainly never OD'd nor known anyone who has. 

Many states, after evaluating all of the facts, have elected to keep Kratom legal, most recently North Carolina where lawmakers voted unanimously to only ask for an age restriction. It appears that the states and the DEA are in disagreement about the imminent danger of this herb.

While the "opiate epidemic" is worrisome, this overreach by the DEA is tone deaf and unhelpful. It appears more political than anything else. In my opinion it would do more harm than good as it prohibits thousands of longtime beneficiaries from acces to this helpful herbal remedy and makes more everyday people felons. 

Please do not let false science, skewed data and hysterical untruths about this plant affect responsible access to yet another herbal remedy, seemingly all in effort to protect pharmaceutical companies' profit base.

documents.commentText: Hello my name is Adam Baker and I work for the United States Air Force. I dont personally use kratom or any other substances for that matter but I have a close relative who struggles with drug addiction. My sister has overdosed on opiates twice and is currently frequenting a methadone clinic. The problem with the clinic is that its incredibly expensive and its only open during regular work hours. Im not sure if this is the case with all methadone clinics but the one in her local area is only open for a very specific window of time. Sometimes her job interferes with her ability to make it to the clinic in the morning. This is where kratom comes in. She will take some kratom, not sure of the dosage but its a lot more affordable than the methadone. The kratom gets her through the day. Then the next day she makes sure to get to the clinic on time if at all possible.  I dont think she could have went directly from hard opiates to kratom but I do think that kratom could help her quit the methadone clinic. Which would in turn save her lots of money and maybe she could afford to get her son back. I believe that if kratom is made illegal my sister will either relapse on one of the days she misses the clinic or lose her job because she had to leave or come in late to make it to the clinic. Either way without kratom I dont expect shell be able to straighten out her life enough to regain custody of her child.

documents.commentText:
I am a 27-year-old female who has struggled with depression and anxiety throughout my whole life. My family spent hundreds and possibly thousands of dollars in attempts to find different psychiatrists different medications that might make my quality of life something I could enjoy. Then in college I was diagnosed with Endometriosis. 

Once a month I found myself in absolute agony for at least 5-days during my menstrual cycle and was taken to the hospital several times a year for being in so much pain I couldn't function properly. Even the laparoscopy I had done was a very temporary fix that ended up not working. Eventually my doctor proscribed me Tylenol 3 to help deal with the pain. I thought I had found the miracle drug that would finally allow me to live my life uninterrupted. But then I'd build a tolerance to them and they'd stop helping. So then he gave me percocets. Then oxycodone. 

Eventually my life had become focused around pills and getting more of them. They were the closest things I'd felt to happiness and I wanted that badly. Those days were the most miserable days of my life. I was an opiate addict. I let those painkillers ruin my life for a few years until I finally forced myself off of them and decide I'd rather just live with the pain than be addicted to something. 

Eventually I graduated, barely, and immediately moved back home with my parents and lived in pain, getting more and more depressed as I went through antidepressants that wouldn't work and dealing with constant cramps. I'd given up on things getting better. I often considered moving onto harder drugs since I knew I couldn't get painkillers anymore, but I hated that idea. There were several times where I honestly considered just ending my life. I was miserable and i was making the people around me miserable. 

Until my mom suggested I try some tea she'd read about on the internet. That was Kratom, and that was 4 years ago. The last 4 years have been the best of my life, because I feel like I can finally live it... I drink a cup in the morning and a cup at night, and that's all it takes. Because of Kratom my depression and anxiety are under control. I've since moved out, gotten a job as a piano teacher, cleaned up my act and am able to say I'm happy for the first time in years. I don't need to take any pain killers for my cramps anymore, and the idea that I once considered moving onto something much deadlier before I found this plant scares me so much. 

Kratom has quite literally saved my life, and I know I'm not the only one who has had this experience. I've never experienced any negative side effects. Taking away this tea would be taking away my ability to live a happy, pain-free, and productive life. If anybody actually ends up reading this, please take that into consideration. I know 27 doesn't sound very old to a lot of people, but to me it's been a lifetime. It took me a lifetime to find this plant, finally something that helps me get out of bed in the mornings. I don't want to lose that. Thanks.

documents.commentText: I am a 57 year old male who is an ordained minister. I first discovered Kratom in early 2004 while looking for an alternative to narcotic pain medication for treating chronic lower back pain and arthritis. At that time it was relatively unknown in the US and identified as being from the coffee family. I began using Kratom at that time and found that it actually was helpful for pain relief with none of the side effects of opiod pain meds. It is not a substance that has ever resulted in my being intoxicated. In smaller amounts it is mildly stimulating at best similar to coffee. In higher doses it may be somewhat relaxing, however I can emphatically state it is not at all comparative to prescription drugs I have used in the past such as opiods, tranquilizers, sedatives, etc..- I have seen this misinformation in the media and unless it is somehow being tainted with other substances or drugs plain kratom is nothing like those drugs. It has been almost 13 years of my using kratom, and the past 7 include regular and almost daily doses. I am very active and also extremely health conscious. I have regular medical check ups and lab work done every six months for thyroid/cholesterol as well as liver/kidney function and all tests have been in normal range. I have had two shoulder surgeries in the past 5 years and used kratom rather than opiod medication throughout the recovery. I must really emphasize that kratom does not impair you and something like Benadryl has a much more sedating effect than kratom in my experience. Although the significant benefits of Kratom are considered mostly anecdotal I have seen it proven to be nothing short of miraculous in saving several people I know personally from long term and severe addictions when no other treatments had been successful. It saved their lives. Please do not schedule this drug as planned. It has benefitted myself greatly but even more importantly it has actually saved, and will save the lives of so many others, especially with the current opiod crisis in this country.

documents.commentText:
I am firmly against the scheduling of Kratom.

I am not a drug user.  I am not trying to beat a heroine habit.  I'm a software engineer who suffers from chronic back pain.  I don't like to take acetaminophen because it's very bad for the liver, and I also hate to take ibuprofen because it gives me stomach aches.  A nurse friend of mine recommended that I try an herbal solution - kratom.  I rolled my eyes at the time because I assumed that a plant couldn't offer me any real pain relief.. otherwise I would have heard about it by now, right?  

I take two caplets in the morning and two after lunch, and my back pain is gone.  Incidentally, I also found that it was a more effective stimulant than coffee, which offers much more severe side effects.  I have been living caffeine and pain free since I discovered this supplement and I am truly floored by the idea that we are even considering a ban.

I had no idea that my government could reach into my cupboard and unceremoniously decide for me that I should have to live with liver damage, nausea, or back pain... because.. ?  I'm still not clear on the because part of all this.  Because it might act on the brain in similar ways to opiates?  Is this some horrific sin on its own, when it causes no demonstrable harm?  It was my understanding that the privilege of emergency scheduling was afforded to the DEA in order to combat the rapidly produced synthetic drugs that pose a clear and present danger to our public.  This is not happening right now... public opinion on kratom ranges from "What's that?" to "That literally changed/saved my life."  The number of deaths that are 'linked' to kratom is laughable to anyone with a college-level statistics class.  

I have done nothing wrong by availing myself of this natural form of pain relief.  You are not better than me because you use Advil instead... Or caffeine, for that matter.  The number of people killed by eating dishwasher detergent pods last year is much greater than the number (inconclusively) linked to kratom.  And hey ok.. folks are less likely to want to eat detergent pods so let's get away from the substance itself and talk about usage... You allow us to kill ourselves with alcohol and cigarettes, but you want to forbid us from the mild stimulant/pain reliever offered by kratom.  How in the world can you logically justify this ban?  

I am not a criminal.  Please don't make me one.

documents.commentText: As a practicing pharmacist of over 15 years, I have seen a lot of patients on prescription pain medication with opioids being the most commonly prescribed class of medications to control pain. These medications are somewhat effective at initially controlling a patient's pain, but continued use leads to several problems. The first problem is that the effectiveness is diminished over time. This is because new studies have found that opioid pain medications change the way the spinal cord and brain communicate. Unfortunately the narcotics cause an over sensitization to pain. This means that the patient eventually requires more narcotic medication to adequately control their pain. The patient in turn may be penalized as a 'drug seeker' which is also unfortunate for the patient. The patient is just looking to relieve their pain. A second problem is that a lot of these opioids also contain acetaminophen as an active ingredient. This acetaminophen takes it's toll on the liver, depleting it's supply of glutathione. Glutathione is a critical super antioxidant our body produces to ultimately keep our liver (aka our body's filter) running properly. Patients who take opioids containing acetaminophen for pain management can and eventually will develop liver issues or cirrhosis if use is continued. A third problem to this method of treating pain is that these medications can result in respiratory depression...where the breathing rate slows down and can ultimately be completely suppressed. To translate in layman's term, the patient stops breathing. This can happen in any patient. The patient can be taking it as prescribed and still run into this major problem.  Kratom is an effective pain reliever and does not have these dangerous side effects. I have witnessed a patient take narcotics to no avail of relief while I also witnessed the same patient have significant relief of pain after taking Kratom. This was a patient with multiple herniated discs. The relief was apparent with the Kratom and the effective time of relief  was longer than that of the narcotic opiods.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a employed, responsible, 47 year old man with chronic back and shoulder pain. I also suffer from GI issues and abdominal pain from multiple hernias and an inoperable hiatal hernia. And I have been taking the herbal supplement known as Kratom for over nine years to help me manage the pain, depression and anxiety that come from having to deal with these issues on a daily basis. 

To be clear, I have tried many doctors. I have undergone painful surgery, and have been prescribed powerful opiate pain killers like Vicodin, hydrocodone, and oxycodone to help me manage my pain. My medicine chest is overflowing with muscle relaxants, and prescription strength naproxyn, diclofenac and other NSAID pain killers. 

All of these drugs come with an assortment of side effects that are well documented by the medical community. And the byproduct of all these medications, make it difficult for me to be an effective provider for my family when I am taking them. The prescription strength nsaids have left me with GI issues that must be treated with PPI drugs like omeprazole (prilosec), and ranitidine on a daily basis. Furthermore, the omeprazole (prilosec) causes me to have chest pain and tachycardia as another side effect. And my cardiologist recommended this year that I discontinue usage of all PPIs in this class. 

This leaves me with very few viable options to treat my pain.  I can take the narcotics and suffer the slow, "muddy" thought processes, addiction, constipation, and difficulty breathing that they bring. Or I can take the nsaids and PPIs and suffer through the chest pain, tachycardia, ulcers, gastric reflux and irritation to my hiatal hernia.

OR, I can take an all natural, and SAFE herbal supplement like Kratom that comes with NONE of these symptoms. I can choose to take low doses of this herbal supplement that has been used to treat pain for thousands of years and that has been proven to be safe and effective by the community of people who have used it as part of their traditional medicine.

I have worked for the same company for over thirteen years. I am well respected by my customers, colleagues and my management in this company. And I have been responsibly using Kratom for almost ten of those years now - WITHOUT any of the complications or issues with addiction that have been reported in the news recently. Certainly nothing like the horror stories and narrative currently being pushed on the public by the DEA and FDA.

Kratom is a plant that comes from the same family as the coffee plant and is no more addictive than your morning cup of coffee. If this ban is ratified after December 1st, Kratom could be placed in the same class as HEROIN. At that point, the DEA and law enforcement agencies of the US will view me no differently then a Heroin-using street junky. I could go to jail!  Just for wanting to treat my own pain with a safe, herbal alternative to the powerful prescriptions that cause me horrible side-effects.

I have been responsibly taking this amazing herbal supplement for almost a decade, and I do not drink alcohol, or smoke, or use illegal drugs. I do not even like to take prescription painkillers. Every morning, I get up, pain or no pain, and I go to work to provide for my three little girls. Because that is what a good Father - not a JUNKY - does for his family. I pay my taxes, I obey the laws of my country, and I am a productive, honest employee. And now the US government could classify me as a felon - in the same category as a Heroin addict? That is ludicrous!

What is needed at this time is an EXTENDED period of responsible discussion with the medical community to properly address the debatable claims of negative side effects and rumors of danger to the public. The medical and scientific community need to be given time (and the funding) to properly research this amazing herbal supplement. What we do NOT need is a knee-jerk reaction to ban this herb due to the few debatable claims of death and addiction that have been associated with its use.

IF, it is determined that some form of regulation is required during this period of discussion and research, then let's work together to find something less draconian then requiring a prescription or an outright banning.  For example, we could restrict the sale of the herb to minors - much the same as we do for OTC medicines, tobacco and alcohol. Furthermore, many of us in the community would welcome some form of quality control to ensure product safety for human consumption. The integrity of tobacco and alcohol products is currently maintained by the Alcohol And Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau.  Why not do the same for herbs like Kratom?

There are so many other productive options that we could take instead of an outright scheduling or banning of this herbal supplement. Please keep the sale of this herb legal to adults and responsible individuals such as myself who depend on it for their daily activities and livelihoods.

Thanks!

documents.commentText: I'm a 29 year old Iraq war vet and recovering addict. I've experienced debilitating anxiety, trouble sleeping, and depression for over a decade. My life took a drastic turn about 5 years ago after a failed marriage and another dangerous bout with my addiction. At unequivocally the worst point in my life I found myself looking deep inside and wondering weather or not I would ever be able to turn my life around for the better. I had tried every recovery option known to man from abstinence based programs to maintenance programs. While researching yet another option I read about Kratom and decided to try it with very little belief that it would be able to help me. I had no idea that within a week or two this little known plant from Southeast Asia would have me looking towards the future with true hope and believe that I would be able to turn my life around for the better. In the months after the first experience I lost about 70 pounds and have continued to work out to this day. I cannot speak on behalf of anyone else, but this plant literally changed my life. More importantly it saved my life. It wasn't a magic bullet but rather a vehicle to help me get to a more stable place where I could become a responsible productive member of society. I now do something I absolutely love to do and have not had a single relapse since my first experience with Kratom. My anxiety is tolerable, and my sleep patterns are the best they've been since I was a teenager. Kratom is not for everyone, but very little in this world is. Personally I believe regulation would be best as well as an age limit. documents.commentText:
Hi my name is Tyler Owyen,
I was addicted to heroin and pills for a long time and had multiple failed attempts at rehab and getting sober. Eventually i was able to get clean using Suboxone that a doctor prescribed me. I have over four years sober now. However, at that point i was just addicted to the Suboxone. If I even missed one dose I would have terrible withdrawals.
Suboxone is known to be very hard to get off of. I've had two different Suboxone doctors tell me there's a very good chance that Ill be on Suboxone for the rest of my life. And they haven't seen anyone get off of it who's been on it for more than a month or so. People also always told me that Suboxone withdrawals are even worse than heroin withdrawals, which I later found to be true.
Knowing it would be tough, about 6 months ago I attempted to very slowly taper off the Suboxone. At that point I had been on it for almost 4 years. However when i was a few days into the taper, it was just way too hard. I couldn't do it. It was terrible.
So I got online to do some research and I joined a "Suboxone Taper Support" group on Facebook. Literally EVERYONE was saying that Kratom is by far the best thing to help. I researched Kratom and found nothing negative about it. Its all natural and there has been no overdoses.
So I bought some, and started to taper off the Suboxone again, but this time on Kratom. I cant even begin to explain the difference it made. The Suboxone withdrawals weren't too bad at all on Kratom, where without Kratom it was impossible for me. It's amazing.
I also want to note that I wouldn't consider Kratom to get you "high". It does put me in a better mood though. There are no negative effects whatsoever that I got from Kratom.
Honestly, even if Kratom didn't help people like me out, it would still be ridiculous to make this harmless supplement illegal. But its not just that. If Kratom was illegal, I gaurentee I would still be on Suboxone to this day. Kratom helped me so much and I know I'm not the only one. There will be plenty more people just like me who will need Kratom. Please don't take that away from them.
Thank you so much.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Dear: DEA 
 I am writing this short letter in hopes that its message will be heard by the reader. I am speaking for thousands of people but I am going to try my best to keep this factual, logical, and on my own person experiences. This is a personal outcry. I ask the DEA to read this with an open mind and a realistic understanding of the situation. My message that I want to articulate are reasons why Mitragyna speciosa, which is a cousin to the coffee plant. Should not be a schedule 1 controlled substance. This letter must be brief so I will do my best to convey my message clearly and logically.
 First I would like to say that I use Mitragna speciosa. It has helped me in my life more then I could ever describe in a short letter. My family will attest to this. I have been on pharmaceuticals since I was a kid for depression, anxiety, adhd, and others. I have struggled with chemical dependency for many years. It all started with the medicines the doctor prescribe for these disorders that I was diagnosed with. It eventually lead to the use of other narcotics. When all hope had seemed lost and I hit my bottom, I seeked help/treatment for the many problems that I was struggling with, including chemical dependency. I did not want to start taking the pharmaceuticals again that led me down a horrible path in the first place. So I turned to Kratom, I used it as an aid throughout multiple step of my road to recover. I would go into further detail about how it help but let's just keep it simple, it helped. I have now been sober(drug and alcohol free) over 6 years. I am finishing up my chemistry/biology degree and am going to persue med school. Through out this whole time from the start of treatment to now finishing up a college degree I have used Kratom for its many benefits. I would not be where I am at without it. In that time I have gone for yearly labs and checkups and have had no deleterious affects.
 Now that I have told you a little about my own expierances I would like to go over some facts as well as logical ideas pertaining to this topic. I would love to give detailed ideas and work cited pages but I do not have enough room in this letter to do so. Let's start at the top. I have just told you how beneficial Kratom as been for me and my life. Tens of thousands of people also attest to the same benefits and many more. Scheduling this as a drug and making this medicinal endemic herb uneccesible to the people and scientist, will cause major strife. You will sever any type of progress for a new medical benefits that could come from this. What if we are able to reduce drug addiction, which is now an epidemic in our nation. As well as have an organic pain/anxiety medicine that does not depress the respitory system to deadly levels. These are all possibliities for this plant. Lets look at how well it went over making marijuana illegal. Or how about prohibition, need I say more about how unsuccessful those cases where. Yet we have a plant that has been shown to have wonderful medicinal properties but our government is saying that it doesn't and are welling to make it uneccesible. As well as charge and incarcerate people if they are in possession, without providing substantial evidence that it is harmful. With that being said lets talk about alcohol, a drug people drink for fun, kills thousands every year, destroys families, and has little to absolutely no medicinal benefits. Yet we are going to incarcerate and patronize a person that is using an organic herb to try an alleviate ailments that they have. But a drunk stumbling fool is considered normal in our society. Lastly there was a time in this country where the idea of our government telling the citizens what they can and can't put in their body would have been absolutely unacceptable. Now a days we just rip the rights of people away. Tell them what they can and cant do. Even if you have no first hand expierances with the benefits of Kratom please see that this is not the American way. Telling people they cant consumer a herb that they find to so beneficial that it has given them their life back and made their life worth living.
 Please I beg of you to look at this with an open mind and take this into consideration. You will not only be saving lives but making people's lives better if you allow this herb to be easily accessible to people. We can find a proper middle ground. Set age laws(like 21+), when proper testing has been done give Information on packaging. Like warnings or proper dosages. Tax it, state and federal. Have fda make a certain standard that needs to be met, such as all organic or of a certain quality and safety. These are some ways that maybe you will find a compromise for the people that need this herb. Thank you for your time and I hope come December 1st you will tell the citizens of the is USA that you are not going to criminalize this wonderful herb.

A tsp. dose has a mild stimulate effect for about an hour of first taking it which equals to a cup of strong coffee, no more. A tbsp. dose begins acting as a sedative. You CAN NOT overdose on Kratom in the raw herb form. If you happen to take too much you WILL vomit it back up immediately. It  DOES NOT damage your liver, kidneys, heart, etc. Check the thousands of researches that has already been done. It WILL and DOES control pain better than most opiates AND it WILL help you get off of opiates and illegal drugs if you are addicted. When you run out of Kratom there is NO withdrawals like you have with everything else that you would use for pain. You just run out and within a day or two, the pain comes back. It is VERY EFFECTIVE in controlling PTSD, anxiety & depression, just ask my clients. It not only STOPS a migraine but continued timed scheduled use of  Kratom prevents you from having them. I have serious back issues & have had numerous surgeries & once walked with a cane. I no longer do so and unlike opiates that made me feel and act like a zombie, Kratom as given me my life back as well as it has with the numerous clients that I have. When you the DEA announced in Sept that you were going to classify it has a Schedule 1 drug, I called my clients to tell them I could no longer supply them and it brought a few to tears and that broke my heart. I've suffered from migraines since the age of 10 and I am now 58 years old. Since I began taking Kratom my migraines have slowly went away and I haven't had one in over a year now. Yes, I am a better and happier person without having to deal with so much pain and the fear of when the next migraine was coming. I do realize that others mix Kratom with illegal drugs, alcohol & energy shots and drinks and its those idiots that are messing things up for us the users and prescriber's that us it in the raw herb form. I totally understand that, but please DO NOT let those idiots control your decision and please DO NOT take our Kratom away from us. I would be forced to go back on the opiates and I do not want to go back to that miserable life again. So please, please Mr. DEA don't do this to us. 

Sincerely,

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am writing in reference to the recent plan to ban kratom by the DEA.  I am a college educated professional who works in the field of education. I had a serious spinal cord injury in 2008 and due to a heart condition am unable to take traditional opiates. At the time of my injury my heart condition was not yet diagnosed.  I was prescribed vicodin by my doctor after my injury but due to the symptoms I was having with my heart thought I would wait to take the pain meds until I saw my electrocardio physiologist.  My appointment was scheduled weeks ahead so I could only suffer in severe pain until I saw my doctor.  When I saw my heart specialist he told me about the dangers of prescribed opiates with respect to my condition. He also told me that the stress caused by my untreated pain was dangerous for my heart.  I discussed alternative pain med options with him. I found out about kratom not long after my injury and it has helped me in so many ways. 

I originally used kratom to help with my PTSD starting in late 2008 and it was clearly a miracle that it not only helped with that, but it also helped ease the extreme pain from my spinal injury. It allowed me to stay a productive working citizen because it kept the pain from my injury at bay and permitted me to keep teaching. I was not forced to take prescribed narcotics that make it impossible to hold down a full time job,  not to mention one that requires a clear thinking brain. We were also able to keep our home which we would have lost without an income.

I had spinal surgery in 2013 and do not need kratom daily for pain but I do use it occasionally to help with other things like my PTSD.  I had no problem stopping kratom and I am convinced it is a safe herb based on my extensive experience using it for many years. According to an article https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/11/161128132148.htm posted by ScienceDaily on November 28th, 2016, kratom may be a safe opioid alternative. These professional opinions must not be overlooked.

Due to the tens of thousands of deaths yearly from opiates, it is totally irresponsible for the DEA or any government agency to ban a plant that has been safely used for thousands of years and has not been directly tied to one death.  I am convinced that if kratom was not available to me, I would have been forced to take prescribed pain meds that would have killed me.  Please do not ban this safe plant because I am convinced that that act alone will kill thousands more a year.

I am currently working on my bachelor's in Philosophy, to further my education by choosing this bachelor's degree for Law School afterwards. It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose. I appreciate this comment period that is happening, so myself, along with thousands of others can tell our stories about why Kratom should be legal.

From the moment I began taking Kratom as a supplement for my health, it changed my life for the better and made me turn back into the smart, loving, outgoing person I once was before having an addiction to prescribed medications. I still continue to use Kratom to support my pain when needed, but I am happy to say I have never been addicted to it. I feel healthy, and more alive like I used to be. I am a true supporter that if it wasn't for Kratom, then I probably would have continued going down a nasty path from being addicted to prescribed pain medicine, and there is no telling what could have happened to me.
   Kratom has given me my whole life back. I almost lost everything due to my addiction from pain medicine that a doctor prescribed me. Before discovering Kratom, I didn't ever want to leave my home. I felt trapped because the medicine took over, and I relied on it to get through everything. Since discovering and starting Kratom, my life turned one hundred percent around. You can search Kratom in Google and just see ALL of the thousands and thousands of people that use Kratom for specific/different needs. It helps thousands of people from addiction, to an alternate source for pain, anxiety, depression, and much more. There is no one who even abuses it like the DEA is claiming it is used for. It cannot even be abused.
 Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses and has changed my life. documents.commentText:
Hello my name is Morgan Wokoun and I am 27 year old father of three children and I use kratom daily. I first got introduced to kratom three years ago by my wife the night before I went on terminal leave from the Army. While serving in the Army, I injured my back, both of my knees, and also started dealing with overwhelming anxiety and depression. I remember my first time taking kratom extremely well because that night was the first night, in over a year and a half (at that time), that my anxiety wasn't controlling me and I was pain free. I had made the decision to leave the comfort of having a salary and guaranteed housing in the Army because all the pain I was in, mental and physical. For the first time in a very long time, I didn't know what I was going to do next in my life. Life in the Army was very easy for me because all I had to do was listen to what my leadership said to do, and I would receive a paycheck every two weeks. At that time I had two children and a wife who depended on me to survive. Immediately after getting out of the Army I started my treatment and saw a civilian doctor who just kept me on the same medication I was on while serving, multiple pain meds along with antidepressants and antianxiety medication. The medication wasn't all that effective but at that point I was on pain meds so long that I became dependent on them and knew that I was addicted. I had put all my faith in the healthcare system and my families future depended on me being a functional member of society again, but that system failed me and instead of looking to fix the issues, they covered them up with medications causing addiction. Fast forward a six months later and I moved my family back to our home state of Massachusetts and had no healthcare coverage but still had an opiate addiction. My addiction grew and within two months was using heroin intravenously, and because of it almost lost everything, including my children. To keep my family together I had to get sober and without a doubt I would not have been able to do that without kratom. To me, kratom is much more than a way to battle withdrawals, because of kratom I don't need to take anymore of the medications I was on before. Because of kratom I am no longer crippled by my anxiety and back pain. Because of kratom I am an active member of society. That is why I am reaching out and giving a quick run down of my story, because without kratom I am truly scared of what will happen. Kratom has the potential to benefit millions and millions of people and banning it will only make our countries opiate epidemic worse. With all that being said I would like to thank anyone who reads this for their time and I hope in the end kratom will remain legal and more people can find out how beneficial the plant really is. 

-Morgan Wokoun

documents.commentText: Please do not ban kratom.  Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.  Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit.  Banning it would shut down all the promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment.  Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.  Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and increase the number of people who will die from an overdose.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Dear DEA, I'm a working tax paying member of society with no criminal record and I'll leave it at that. I'm against the DEA's intent on scheduling the actives in Mitrigyna Speciosa. First off I want to reference a paper published in JACS (DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b00360) which notes the novel action of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine in its G-protein-biased  partial agonism of the mu-opioid receptor, which do not recruit -arrestin following receptor activation, giving them a binding pose at the mu-opioid receptor that is distinct from that of classical opioids. This novel action is something that the people who take kratom have come to know from experience. Its vastly different from any illegal or pharmaceutical opioid. In my experience and echoed in many others testimony, it is very tame and free of side effects, much akin to coffee or aspirin and should be treated as such. But unlike coffee it can have a dramatic impact on peoples lives who suffer from chronic pain like me. Having gotten off of prescription pain meds due to dependency and side effects over 5 years ago I was struggling with debilitating pain that kept me from working regularly and enjoying life. My primary care physician suggested I go back to pain management. That was the only option she gave me and completely unacceptable. I did my own research and found Kratom. It has change my life for the better and I can say it is unlike any other opioid. It really is on par with coffee. I get a mild reduction in pain, just enough to function, mild stimulation less than coffee, and if I take too much it just makes me nauseous, a self limiting property of it, and if I take it too often, it just loses effectiveness. It truly is just about the most harmless substance there is yet with huge benefits for millions and potentially many more. My friend just got off heroin with it and is working again. My mother takes it occasionally for acute pain. As it is right now it is an easily obtainable remedy for the common person. Scheduling it or over regulating it would be a tragedy at this point with so many depending on it and with only more harmful and deadly alternatives. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am a 50-year-old retired patent attorney who has suffered from Willis-Ekbom Disease (otherwise known as restless legs syndrome, or RLS) most of my life.  It may sound like an innocuous ailment, but it is not.  At lease 2-3 times per week (and sometimes for several days in a row), I lay down at night to sleep and feel an itching sensation that I can only describe as ants crawling on my leg bones.  The only way to relieve the itching/crawling feeling is to stretch my legs, pump them in the air, and otherwise move them -- somewhat like rubbing my muscles over my leg bones to "scratch" them.  It doesn't matter how tired I am, I have to move my legs in such a manner to relieve the itch.  This goes on for hours -- sometimes lasting until morning.  Other parts of my body such as my rib cage, back and arms, have frequently been affected as well.  The sleep deprivation due to RLS has affected many areas of my life, and my constant movements at night have also caused my husband to lose sleep.

I consulted my family doctor, who prescribed Ropinirole, a common treatment for RLS.  It provided some relief at first, but then actually exacerbated my symptoms so that it progressively became much worse and happened more frequently.  Upon joining the Restless Legs Foundation (www.rls.org) and chatting with other members, I found that the exacerbation of RLS is fairly common with Ropinrirole.  I also supplement my diet with magnesium, potassium, iron, and other minerals which seem to provide some relief.  I am in good health otherwise, and do not imbibe in recreational drugs.  I rarely drink alcohol, as it seems to trigger my symptoms.

On the suggestion of some members of the Foundation, I tried Kratom.  The first time I used it, I was overcome by the immediate cessation of the itching sensation in my legs.  Unlike traditional opioids, which Kratom has been compared to, the relief wasn't centered in my brain.  With opioids such as hydrocodone, often a patient can still feel pain, but the "high" caused by such a drug makes it so that they no longer care about feeling pain.  On the contrary, Kratom does NOT make me feel impaired and, instead, immediately acts on the source of my discomfort -- the itch in my legs disappears entirely.  In the morning, I have absolutely no residual symptoms such as grogginess.

For the past few years, I have taken about 1 teaspoon Kratom whenever I have symptoms.  On e nights I do not take Kratom, I do not suffer from any withdrawal, nor do I ever crave Kratom. In this amount of time, I have not had to increase my dosage at all in order to consistently provide total relief from RLS symptoms.

Please do not take away the only supplement that has ever provided relief for my restless legs.  My experience with Kratom has demonstrated that it is no more dangerous than traditional pain relievers such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen.  While my education in Chemistry and Forensic Science (as well as Mechanical Engineering and Law) have enabled me to have somewhat of an understanding of the pharmacokinetics of the main constituents of Kratom, including mitragynine and its derivatives, it is evident that much more research needs to be conducted on them.  As a regulatory agency committed to the health and safety of citizens, you should encourage medical research on Kratom since it clearly has medicinal value for RLS, as a pain reliever, and most likely other uses as well.

documents.commentText:
I oppose the banning of kratom for the following reasons:

- Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

- If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

- Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

- Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

- Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

- Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

The War on Drugs has had a catastrophic impact on the trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. We need to restore that trust, and allowing for research and regulation of drugs like kratom will be a significant step.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA

I am a law abiding , tax paying citizen of these "UNITED STATES OF AMERICA," and as such I was under the impression that the government was supposed to look after my best interests, but when the DEA proposed to place kratom as a schedule 1 drug , my confidence in the government's ability to be rational was skewed somewhat. To place kratom in the same classification as heroin , and cocaine is ludicrous and reaching at best. I have been taking kratom for about 2 years now , I have severe pain issues associated with my lower back and degenerative disc disease. I have gone the traditional route with orthopedic doctors and therapy as well as taking narcotic pain medication under the advise of a physician mind you, and none of those measures have produced a positive outcome for me, and we all know that taking prescription pain medication for a lengthy period of time can certainly lead to a physical and mental dependence on those medications. I too was skeptical of kratom at first, and didn't think it would do anything for me , but after a couple of weeks of taking two servings a day , a serving being one cup of tea made from the plant, my pain started to dimish significantly and has been manageable ever since . I don't find myself ever craving kratom , but it definitely has worked for me. I am in the medical field and I see what drug addiction looks like on a daily basis at the hospital, and I don't know of anyone who has come into the hospital with a kratom related issues ever. In my opinion , this is nothing more than BIG PHARMA trying to corner the market on a natural remedy because it is taking away from their profit share bottom line. I sincerely hope that the DEA will look into all the comments and all the the research that has been done as well as additional research in the future. I truly believe that if more people with pain issues would give kratom a chance there would be far less opiate related overdose in this country, and if kratom were to be placed in schedule 1 category, there will be far more opiate related overdoses I'm sure. Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Kratom has been an invaluable aid in the recovery from my costochondritis. I developed it in June from too heavy of weight lifting and not listening to my body. It's a nightmare to deal with. Constant dull pain I feel every time I breathe, brutal, debilitating pain waves that bring me to my knees. The only pain control I knew was Ibuprofen and Aleve. I built a tolerance so quickly that taking 3 would only give me 1-2 hours of pain relief. I knew it was damaging my liver and body but I didn't care, anything to stop the pain. I didn't want to step up to anything more addicting either so it seemed to be my only choice. 

I reached out to friends who had gone through similar experiences and one suggested I try kratom. The results have been astounding. I do 4g in the morning and get 7-9 hours of almost 100% pain relief. Then I do 4g in the evening when the pain starts to kick back up again and it carries me through the night. I went from taking 20+ Ibuprofen/Aleve a day to zero. I'm still in shock how well it works for just being a plant. I like the fact there really isn't a tolerance with it either, I stick with the 4g and get the same pain relief every time. I don't really feel a "high" with it, it's more akin to a coffee buzz. It doesn't impair me physically or mentally in any way, at least the amount I've experienced it at, I haven't gone any further than the 4g. And I know for sure my liver is thanking me.

I can work at the computer and not have to take a "pain break" every couple hours and lie in bed with an ice pack. I can drive my car around and not worry about how the twisting of the wheel is going to mess with the pain. I can head out and not have to be concerned if I brought enough Ibuprofen to last me through the day. 

I might still be unable to lift weights but at least I don't have to deal with the vicious pain. I never really understood the struggle that people with chronic pain go through until I developed costochondritis. Luckily my pain is only temporary, I couldn't imagine having to deal with this every day for the rest of my life. I just wanted to offer the viewpoint of an athlete working through an injury. For pain relief it is simply the best of the best!

documents.commentText:
I have taken Kratom off and on for a few years to help with depression, anxiety, and related chronic headaches. It has been a very valuable tool to help with the process of overcoming my mental struggles, and I can happily say that my conditions have improved significantly over the course of time that I've been utilizing Kratom. Despite it being a very effective plant, I haven't had any cravings for it or withdrawal effects when I go off of it for months at a time. By comparison, its effects are in the range of coffee in terms of intensity, in my experience. That meaning, mild-moderate effects that become counterproductive and unenjoyable at any high dose, mostly due to nausea. By that I'm saying that it's not a plant that opens itself to abuse/dependence unless the person simply abuses anything they get their hands on.

Given how much this has helped people, and that it has done significant harm to essentially no one, banning this plant would be foolish, and would do nothing more for the DEA than to further promote the disrespect of the people for irrational and unscientifically knee-jerk policymaking. Huge numbers of former heavy pain pill and heroine addicts would be forced to go back to their old habits to manage chronic pain and other symptoms if this plant were to be banned, inevitably resulting in thousands of more deaths to add to the tens of thousands in this country that already die every year from heavy opioids and opiates. This plant needs to be accepted as the therapeutic tool that it is. It needs to be researched to determine the different effects of various strain compositions, as well as to determine a set of best practices for effective and safe use.

To be frank, the policies of the DEA have already done more harm than good to the fabric of society in this country. If you want to turn the tide and prevent the obsoletion of your agency, you have to start making policy based upon actual evidence, mechanistically based risk, and scientific method, not some fear-based authoritarian control freak tactics that are the hallmark behaviors of ignorant and insecure people. Otherwise, intelligent and informed people like myself lose all respect for your authority because it's akin to being conceitedly told how to eat healthy by an obese person who eats Big Macs every day and has never read a single book or science journal about nutrition.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I'm taking this opportunity to commit on your proposal to ban kratom. I'm sure you've heard the following. I hope you will take it to heart. 

- Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
- If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
- Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
- Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
- Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
- Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Sirs/Madams, we have placed bans on substances that never had any business being banned in the first place, causing us, as a country, to be behind more forward thinking countries. Hemp is one such substance. I'm glad to see the U.S. opening up to all the potential uses for hemp, as they are myriad. I honestly don't know a whole lot about kratom, but I do believe that we need to think of ALL the possibilities before we take any actions such as banning a chemical that is useful.

Thank you for paying attention to what we, the consumers, have to say.

Sincerely,
Debbie Schlinger
P.O. Box 69
Deerwood, MN 56444
sunflower033010@gmail.com

My life became endless days in pain in bed, when I thought enough time had passed my resistency to norco will have subsided I thought about trying that again and found it difficult to function in society as it makes me sleepy, a friend recommended Kratom and my life changed, I am able to get out of bed and function in society on a level I have not seen in years. documents.commentText:
I am writing this because there seems to be quite a dearth of commentary regarding the reason I use kratom. I am a law abiding, tax paying, professional citizen, father of three with no criminal record. I am not a deviant in any sense of the word. 
There is a lot of literature out there framing kratom as a treatment for opiate addicts and a possible treatment for addicts of many other drugs including alcohol. I have no drug or alcohol abuse issues but I can testify that when I use kratom it certainly reduces any desire I have to drink and so I can imagine that property would carry to other drugs as well. There is also a lot of literature regarding its analgesic properties to which I can also testify. 
That being said, neither of these are the reason I use kratom. I use kratom in the same way that I use coffee and kratom may be called a drug only with the fairness that allows coffee to also be called a drug. I do not drink coffee to achieve intoxication and I do not drink kratom tea to achieve intoxication. In the same way as you can drink too much coffee and feel uncomfortable, so it is with kratom. It is self-regulating. 
Coffee is used not to intoxicate but to augment ones consciousness, as is kratom. Both of these plants contribute to ones sense of well-being and neither one is more dangerous than the other. That is to say that neither one is dangerous to any degree which would give an informed reasonable person concern. It boggles the mind that the federal government is considering placing this unadulterated plant on a schedule which criminalizes it alongside heroin. This proposition is either being explored as a result of extreme incompetence and willful ignorance or as a result of special interest influence in the effort to eliminate a plant that could serve as natural, safe, and inexpensive competing product to existing or planned pharmacological products for pain relief, antianxiety, and or depression. I much suspect the latter. 
Prohibition and criminalization in regards to any drug has never been a successful solution and has always caused and continues to cause more problems than it solves. Weve made many mistakes in our drug laws in the past and the legacy of these mistakes has been new and dangerous forms of these drugs in ever concentrated and impure forms, a thriving black market to distribute them, and mass incarceration and destruction of lives that would otherwise not have been destroyed. Had the DEA criminalized the coffee bean in the past, they would have created an indestructible monster with all of those properties of dangerous concentrated impure forms, the thriving black market, and a class of incarcerated souls and destroyed lives. 
Kratom is a ground up unadulterated leaf as it exists right now. It helps millions across the world and harms a statistically insignificant few. If they choose, the DEA can create an indestructible monster out of this leaf, as they have done with the poppy and the coca leaf, or they can in the 21st century make a different decision informed by those past mistakes and let harmless leaves be harmless leaves. I do not break the law and I do not wish the law to break me.
Thank you for considering my opinion on this matter.

My name is Robert Hildreth.  I am 40 years old and work at a marina doing various manual labor and electrical jobs on boats, mainly sailboats.  I am writing to state my opposition to the proposal of placing kratom on the list of Schedule I controlled substances.  Doing so can only have negative results- not only for me but for thousands of others who rely on kratom for various different issues.

I began using kratom about 2 years ago. Before that, I was taking a prescribed narcotic pain reliever but was experiencing side effects common to those types of medications- drowsiness, upset stomach, anxiety, and withdrawal symptoms are just a few examples of what I lived with daily while taking Norcos.  Needless to say, these side effects not only had detrimental impacts on my own life, but on my work and relationships as well. I needed a different way to control my chronic back pain.

I began looking for more natural pain remedies and came across information on kratom.  I decided to do some research and give it a try.  Kratom has made a HUGE difference in my life for the better. It eases my pain without any negative side effects.  There are absolutely no withdrawal symptoms- it doesn't matter if I miss one dose or five. While it has not cured me, taking it as a supplement has significantly reduced my pain levels while allowing me to stay alert and less anxious.  I am able to do my job efficiently and have more energy to spend time with my family.  In the two years that I have been taking kratom daily, I have never experienced any hallucinations or feelings of intoxication from it nor had any feelings of addiction that are so common with Norcos and medications similar to that.  These are just a few of the benefits of kratom.  According to a recent Forbes article, Kratom research could, in fact, lead to new, less dangerous painkillersbut it will happen a lot faster if the plant isnt banned. The rest of the article can be read here.

Kratom has quite simply saved my life.  Before kratom, I was taking prescribed opiate pain relief, was unemployed and depressed.  Kratom has helped relieve my pain which made finding a job easier.  I am able to do any job asked of me at work and know that I don't have to stick to a strict medication schedule, worry about withdrawals/side effects and can work with less pain.  If I hadn't found kratom, I could very well still be unemployed, draining my state by collecting disability and/or assistance payments when I am young and healthy enough to work and support myself and my family.  My mood is better,  my energy higher and my pain lessened.  Classifying kratom with highly addictive opiates without fully understanding it's positive properties is not only unfair, it is irresponsible.

documents.commentText:
I am in opposition to the scheduling of any  plants in their natural whole form and am especially against the banning of Kratom.

I am a 37 year old  marketing executive from southeast Michigan. I have been successfully using Kratom for four years.

In the past I suffered from pain both physical and emotional resulting in periodic bouts of depression. Because I am a high performing, high functioning adult I do not have the luxury of wallowing in bed for days when depression comes on. (taking to to my bed was becoming a too frequent habit.)

I first obtained Vicodin via prescriptions after surgeries. They worked so well that I began using Vicodin periodically  due to physical pain that was psychosomatic, e.g. so distraught emotionally that my back would lock up and be inflamed and physically painful to the touch. I obtained these Vicodin both legally via doctor prescription and illegally from friends and family members. I prided myself on the fact that I never bought or stole Vicodin but I was aware enough to recognize that at any moment I could have slipped from a casual self prescribing user (about 1-3 a month  on average) to an addict.

Increased reports regarding the danger of Vicodin led me to pursue alternatives, that is how I discovered Kratom. Kratom has been a wonderful addition to my life. I am no longer dependent on Vicodin and now rarely use Kratom. The Vicodin dependency was probably mostly psychological for me. I was always anxious that  I would run out or not be able to get Vics if I had an episode and needed them. Kratom is readily available so there in none of this anxiety. I've experienced several years in a row of good mental health, (for the first time in my adult life) and so don't have much need for any opiods or opioid like products. I will say that without access to Kratom and Vicodin I most likely would not have entered these years of stability.

I am a trained herbalist and plants are magic. As you know most of our pharmaceuticals are derived or synthesized from active ingredients from plants. These plants have been placed here by God and it is our divine right to access them unencumbered. I do not want to have to  go to a doctor and get a prescription for Kratom, nor do I want it banned so I am forced to use pharmaceuticals It is unnecessary and unfair and a boon to only the corporate class and big pharma.

Lastly, I was under the impression that we are the most free country in the world. I demand to keep my right to care for my health needs as I see fit and not be treated as a cash cow and forced to take artificial medication that is bad for me instead of my preferred plant medicine. I am comfortable 'being the captain of my soul' and having the final say of what is and isn't harmful for me and my family. If you are truly concerned for the public safety you the FDA and NHI can team up and conduct studies regarding efficacy, active alkaloids, dosage, interactions etc. and dispense the information so we the public can be accurately informed of plants and their properties, benefits, and dangers. Let me be clear publicly funded studies not ones backed by corporate interests (bigpharma) which are easily and usually manipulated. My name is Milo Bennett. I am currently a kratom user and oppose placement of kratom on the Schedule 1 list or any legislation that would prevent kratom being sold as a dietary supplement.

I first used kratom in 2014 when looking at different supplements for back pain stemming from a lingering injury. I found information on kratom and the additional effects of relieving anxiety and having a calming effect also sounded appealing. I conducted research on online vendors to find the most reputable ones. I also researched responsible use of kratom as a dietary supplement and made my first purchase in the Spring of 2014.

My research paid off as I consider the dietary supplement quality to be very good as well as the instructions on how to take kratom. My goal was simply to see the effect on back pain and my mood that kratom would have.

I work in mental healthcare which can be mentally draining and results in social burnout. I interact with patients with persistent mental illness on a daily basis for my job. Kratom not only helped my quality of life and job performance by reducing back pain as my injury healed but it also improved my general mood as well, resulting in better time away from work to rejuvenate myself mentally. Kratom is valuable to those struggling with social anxiety.

I have used kratom off and on in the last couple years, finding no adverse side effects from use or quitting use of kratom. I have gone from once a day use to quitting completely with no issues.

Please consider this testimonial during your evaluation of kratom as a valuable dietary supplement. It is not merely a recreational substance but a dietary supplement that improves the quality of life for the average citizen.
