documents.commentText:
My name is Greg. I am 47 years old and have struggled with alcohol dependence and generalized anxiety disorder for the past 30 years. I have spent much of the last 20 years either in jail for alcohol related offenses or in rehab facilities. At one point I was homeless and addicted to alcohol and many illegal drugs. In 2007 I entered a rehab facility and came out drug free but have never been able to stop abusing alcohol completely. In the past decade I have been able to achieve 30 days of sobriety at best despite innumerable attempts. I always found my way back to alcohol to cope with my personal struggles including extreme anxiety.
 
I started using Kratom 1.5 years ago. I first tried Kratom in small doses hoping to help curb my alcohol cravings while at work and it helped to a degree. Then six months ago I entered a 7-day detox facility and when I came out I researched more about Kratom to learn more effective ways of using it and developed more appropriate dosages. I started to supplement daily with Kratom and am proud to say that I have now been alcohol free for six months, the longest period of sobriety I have ever been able to attain. Kratom has been invaluable to my success and it scares me to think about where I would be if it were to be banned or scheduled .
 
Not only does Kratom help me remain sober it also helps alleviate pain associated with past injuries allowing me to work on my feet for extended periods of time and remain productive. I know many other people who find significant pain relief through Kratom instead of using prescription medications which have proven to have so many dangerous side effects. Being prescribed such medications has turned them and every other person using them into a potential opiate addict. Kratom helps so many people I know to avoid active opiate addiction and escape becoming a tragic statistic in the opiate overdose epidemic that this country is currently battling.
 
Kratoms potential for abuse is not as perilous as some would like us believe. For me (and many others I know) Kratom has a ceiling effect since large amounts will cause nausea well before any enhanced euphoric effects. Sure there will be people who consume Kratom in a less than responsible way much like many overdo things they find good in their life such as food, coffee, soda, etc. but I believe that responsible use can be achieved via educating people better without using the types of propaganda and fear tactics that have been repeatedly presented by the government.
 
The known adverse side effects of Kratom seem pretty benign. Withdrawal is possible with abrupt Kratom cessation, but the symptoms are pretty slight, with headache, runny nose, and restless leg syndrome being the worst. That is quite harmless compared to withdrawal from opiates or alcohol and are not a good reason to schedule Kratom and take it away from so many people who find it helpful to them for so many reasons allowing them an increased quality of life. The benefits of keeping this plant accessible greatly outweigh any alleged negative aspects. 

People have reaped benefits from Kratom for thousands of years and in that time it has shown nearly no potential to cause death. 15 deaths are being attributed to Kratom worldwide in the history of its known use. In all but one of those there were other more dangerous prescription and/or illegal drugs involved and those 15 deaths pale in comparison to the number of deaths every day involving alcohol and tobacco which are legally used both responsibly and irresponsibly by adults in great numbers. Increased calls to poison control concerning Kratom over the last few years are more likely due to its increased popularity as more people learn about it and how it has helped so many people. I can't recall one case that involved anything more serious than the complaint of nausea and headache.

So I strongly urge you to not schedule Kratom in any of the 5 categories. Doing so will make it harder or impossible to obtain for so many people who can and do receive tremendous benefits from this plant. Perhaps some regulation is needed but scheduling this plant could potentially result in increased alcohol and opiate abuse, if not many unnecessary deaths from overdose of prescription/illegal opiates.

There is also information about some requests through the FOIA that are not being fulfilled regarding the footnote information in the original intent to schedule. This information is supposed to be accessible to anyone who requests it, and yet it has not been released to at least one individual upon request. There seems to be no transparency when it comes to this information. To be fair I hope that all requested information be released to anyone that has gone through the proper channels to obtain it.

Sincerely,
Greg Jackson

I started using Mitragyna Speciosa,  AKA Kratom four years ago. I've suffer with severe bipolar disorder and Chronic Pain in my back and knees. I began having issues as a teenager. I have been prescribed Paxil, Zoloft, anatriptaline, Valium, Depakote, and a few others. Nothing helped me. I had a motorcycle accident that severed my foot from my leg. I was prescribed perscription opiates. They helped for a very short time. A few months into using the prescribed opiates and they stopped working. So I was prescribed stronger higher doses, and that was the pattern for awhile. I tried stopping the opiates, which was the worst thing I've ever been through. The pain I was going through and the mental agony I experienced was tremendous. So now on top of my bipolar, I was dependent on opiates. I would feel good one month and another month or so I would go into a deep dark depression. I was either way up or way down. Which to me at the time was better than being severely depressed all the time. Either way, I was unable to take care of myself or my family with any kind of consistency. This pattern went on into my 30s. At the age of 32 I was introduced through differing support groups to plants and herbs that others claimed had helped them with similar issues. I tried quite a few and did quite a bit of research. Many did help. Then I began using Kratom. I found a combination of green vein, and red vein leaves that began to help me considerably. Once I found the strain and proper amount to take, I noticed and family members noticed an enormous improvement in my wellbeing in general. I've been taking Kratom Four years now. I feel stable and balanced and just plain capable. Im well into a career now as a CNC department supervisor. I've been working the same place for two years. Prior to this job I haven't been stable enough to maintain employment for any longer than 6 to 9 months. My family wife and children all attest to the difference this plant has made in my life. They feel as though they can depend on me, and they can and do now. I feel as though I'm clear minded, goal oriented, motivated, happy more times than not because of my using kratom. My level of chronic pain and fatigue has all but disappeared. Many other aspects of my life have improved as well I could go on.   That plant changed my whole families welfare not just mine. I beg you to keep this plant available to the public. Age restriction I agree with. Schedule of any kind I strongly disagree with. Hundreds of thousands of people benefit from this plant. I've seen testimonies from mothers that use this plant  and can now manage their families when before they found kratom they could not, fathers that have put down heroin or prescription pain killers and now lead productive lives, Teachers that suffer from fibromyalgia return to work, elderly whom suffer from severe arthritis become active and lead healthy lifestyles because of the benefits this plant has provided for them. Research must be allowed to continue. This plant must not be taken from the people. Our country is experiencing an opiate and pharmaceutical epidemic. This plant has brought many out of the grasp of that epidemic and shows great promise to do so for more. The pharmaceutical companies already have the alkaloids in the kratom plant researched and patented. They want to synthesis it, make it into something they can sell to the public. Everything they touch turns bad. Let the people choose to take this plant in its natural form. The pharmaceutical industry will make something bad out of it, and raise the price on it so much that it will cause hardships. This plant helps people in its natural form. I know my family and I's lives will be turned upside down and many others will also if this plant becomes inaccessible. Addicts will return to street drugs or pain pills, people will have to quit their jobs, vendors will lose their businesses, vital research that's going on right now concerning this plant will be halted, overdoses from heroin, and prescription drugs will spike tragically at very high rates, children will lose their mothers and fathers. There are dire consequences to taking this plant away. Please do not take away a plant that has the potential to thwart the opioid epidemic. 

I

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W 

I am a 56 year old responsible adult on disability due to Fibromyalgia, Chronic Pain, Chronic Fatigue, Psoratic Arthritis, IBS, Depression and Anxiety. I have had these conditions for 10 years, so I  have tried everything to help my conditions. This is my story.

I was prescribed Methadone, Oxycodone, Tramadol, Ambien,  Lexapro, Valium, Gabapentin, Simvastatin and Tramadol to be taken daily. This was just my most recent cocktail of toxic medications. I have been on every antidepressant and medications in the last 10 years.  I would sleep 14 hours a day most days, unable to do anything. I would fall asleep at the wheel driving 140 miles round trip to my pain management clinic. I had numerous car accidents because of the medication. I came down with a severe case of Palmar Plantar Pustulosis (PPP).  PPP is a form of Psorisis where you have pus filled blisters on your hands and feet. I had it on my feet so bad, that the blisters burst opened, oozed, cracked and bled. The blisters were even under my toenails. I could barley walk and when I could, I cried in pain.  I had this condition for 2 full years and had a add a Dermatologist to my monthly visit in the 140 mile trip.  Between my therapist, pain management doctor, dermatologist and all the medications listed earlier, plus the creams and pills for my feet, I was spending close to $300.00-$400.00 a month.

Due to my health problems, I was fired in 2013 and had to file for disability.  In April 2015, I no longer had any insurance and could not afford new insurance. My pain management doctor basically wouldn't taper my medications unless I could pay the full office visit, which I could not. When I called my pain management Dr.'s office as I was worried going off all those toxic medications cold turkey would be dangerous, the office simply told me I would not die. My only option was to stop all the medications . 

Going off all the opiate medications was unbearable. It was pure agony and I was seriously considering taking my life. I didn't sleep except for 2-3 hours a day for 3 full months.  The only thing at the time that was wonderful, was that after 2 weeks of stopping all medications, my feet completely cleared up and to this day PPP has not returned. My spouse and primary doctor were astonished and that led us to believe that  my PPP was due to all the toxic medications I had been on over the last years. My Fibromyalgia and other conditions returned full force.

I found out about Kratom, a natural supplement in June 2015 on a Chronic Pain board after I told my story.  She private messaged me and gave me the information and I researched it and decided to give it a try.  If it hadn't been a natural plant, I would not have taken it. My spouse and myself were amazed at how well it worked  for me.  It gave me a clearer mind, eased my anxiety, pain and fatigue away for several precious hours and I started living again. I wasn't sleeping all the time, I wasn't so whacked out on pharmaceutical medications. The most I felt was the effects of a good cup of coffee. It eased my muscle pain so I could sleep at night without feeling as if I was sleeping on a bed of rocks and tossing and turning all night. It was also inexpensive and I could afford it. I have used the same amount as I had a year ago.  I could walk my dog without almost collapsing, I could spend time with family and friends again after not leaving the house for almost 3 years. It literally gave me my life back, as it has for so many others.

Please do not take away my quality of life by making Kratom any other thing except for what it is, a natural plant and supplement.  I do support keeping it for age 18 or 21 and older, however, I can't see any one wanting to use it for recreational purposes as it doesn't give the user any type of reward or high.  I also support taking it out of head shops, gas stations or any other retailer that promotes it as recreational.  I fully support keeping it online and through legitimate herbal and supplement businesses that follow guidelines. My greatest fear is that I will no longer have access to a supplement that gives me back my quality of life, lets me be with family or have the price marked up so much that I will no longer be able to afford it as both my spouse and myself are on Social Security and have limited funds.  

The economic fallout will also be great if Kratom is drastically changed from a supplement to banned substance. From the farmers in less fortunate countries to the mom and pop businesses that have put their life savings in chasing their dream and opening herbal store fronts or online businesses. documents.commentText:
Thank you for opening this for public comment. I am a professional 48 year old mother and grandmother who has no arrest record and no previous issues with any type of addiction. I have never been in treatment, never missed a day's work, never failed a drug test. I am a person who takes the law seriously and believes that it is important to be a mindful citizen. I am also an occasional Kratom user.

In my case I have two autoimmune conditions: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis and Pernicious Anemia.  Additionally, I have markers for Fibromyalgia and Rheumatoid Arthritis.  These conditions are the result of an overabundance of inflammation in the body. Where possible, I manage them by taking care of the body appropriately. However, there are times with the inflammation flares up and the end result is deep joint and muscle pain, extreme lethargy, and an insufferable brain fatigue.  When these conditions flare up, I am sidelined. My quality of life is greatly impacted, my personal productivity comes to a grinding halt, and I am not myself.

I can go to my doctor to have prescriptions written for NSAIDs or for narcotic pain relievers to manage these flare ups; however, my personal research shows me that NSAIDs potentially damage the liver and narcotic pain relief carries a high risk of dependence. Neither of these is therefore a suitable option for me.

Enter Kratom. In researching potential legal, safe, effective alternatives, I learned of this plant.  It has been a godsend. I use it as needed, never use more than needed to manage my pain and energy levels, and discontinue use when I am not in an active flare up. As such, my risk of physical/psychological addiction is extremely low and my ability to manage my autoimmune symptoms remains effective. Moving Kratom to schedule I would leave me in a lurch. I would effectively have no known way to effectively manage my conditions without resorting to methods I've already discarded.

In addition to my situation, there are hundreds perhaps thousands of people just like me, who have found relief through what has always been a safe and legal natural substance.

I would like the DEA to consider six unintended consequences for placing this product on Schedule I.

1).  There will be a black market created where one did not exist previously, complete with all the negative side effects of any black market.  Best case scenario, people who legally rely on the import and sale of Kratom will have their incomes impacted greatly and tax revenues from the legal sale of this product will disappear.

2).  Potentially thousands of otherwise law abiding citizens will suddenly be converted into criminals and will suffer the consequences of their criminal behavior.  Loss of income, loss of jobs, housing issues, loss of respect in their communities, family disruptions and other natural consequences of criminal activity will result.

3).  Law enforcement and correctional communities, already stretched, will have to accommodate a swell in dockets, swell in jail populations, and swell in overhead and processing costs in managing this new class of criminal.  Our infrastructure is already bursting at the seams and we are already the most incarcerated nation in the world.

4).  Resources used for far more deadly drugs such as heroin, cocaine, and meth will be diverted to find and prosecute Kratom crime.

5).  Since Kratom is used as an abatement and alternative to more harmful drugs such as heroin, more people will be driven back to heroin to manage their true addiction. States like Alabama, who have banned Kratom are already recognizing that impact.

6).  Lastly, the DEA and FDA have already suffered much in the court of public opinion for government overreach. While this citizen recognizes these agencies have the unenviable task of securing public safety, it is difficult to understand the DEA's position here. 

Acetominophen overdoses that result in deaths claim 150 American lives yearly, and yet, Tylenol is an OTC medication found in almost all households. The DEAs claim of 15 deaths (14 of which in conjunction with other drugs) over a 5 year span is accordingly hard to fathom.

As a result of the above, I respectfully ask the DEA to reconsider not placing Kratom on Schedule I.  With heroin running rampant in our communities it is clear where the real demon lies and we need to fight it on many fronts. Removing a substance related to the coffee tree that has been used for hundreds of years effectively and safely throughout the world is not the answer. I am living proof that it can be used responsibly and for a legitimate purpose without any negative implications.

documents.commentText:
In reference to Docket No. DEA-442W

My name is Levi Beers and I am strongly against the placement of the herb Kratom into any schedule of the United States Controlled Substances Act. I'm a responsible 34-year-old father of 3 children (ages 4, 3 and 2), loving husband to a Registered Nurse and the owner of my own web development company in Pennsylvania.

I suffer from Degenerative Disc Disease and Spinal Stenosis. In 2014, genetic testing confirmed the "HLAB27" antigen, a marker for Ankylosing Spondylitis. This agonizing condition causes my spine and hip bones to inflame to the point of paralysis for a period of hours to days. My treatments have included opiates, steroids and invasive surgeries.
Opiate therapy was a disaster to my life. For years doctors prescribed morphine IR after surgery and 10mg hydrocodone tablets for daily pain management. These caused me to spend a majority of my time so impaired that I could not work or do anything of social value.

My first born son died in 2009 from a Congenital Heart Defect. Unable to handle the emotional pain associated with his death, I began drinking to avoid facing reality. This developed into a 5-year addiction to alcohol. I lost many relationships and at my worst, I was unemployed, receiving welfare assistance and completely homeless. Even after an arrest and conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol, I still could not stop drinking. After my 2nd probation revocation I was sentenced to 120 days in jail.

Before beginning my sentence in 2014, I discovered Kratom. Taking Kratom as a supplement to other natural vitamins & minerals along with a healthy diet enabled me to engage in physical exercise and greatly improved my quality of life. I found that the symptoms of my alcohol withdrawal became easier to manage. In 2015, thanks in part to Kratom, I was finally able to break completely free from the nightmare of my 5-year hard alcohol addiction. I am currently 1 year sober without relapse.
One of the many benefits of Kratom for me is that unlike opiate or steroid therapy, I do not have to take it every day regardless of my condition. Frequently there are days where my initial morning natural supplement regimen (which includes devil's claw, Kratom, turmeric and a number of minerals) is so effective that I do not take any additional supplements for the rest of the day. When I do not take Kratom on a strict schedule, I am not bothered by distressing withdrawal symptoms like the ones I experienced when doing the same thing with hydrocodone or morphine. With those prescription medications, skipping even one dose would cause severe flu-like symptoms. While I do disagree with the placement of Kratom into any schedule, I agree with actions like those taken by the Health Department in Denver, CO requiring businesses selling Kratom to comply with strict regulatory guidelines.

These regulatory measures require: "A consumer advisory is on all applicable menus for Kratom products served for on-site consumption in Denver stores; A consumer advisory is affixed to all Kratom products intended for offsite consumption that are sold in Denver stores; Labeling is affixed to products intended for offsite consumption to identify the product (e.g. ground Kratom leaf) as well as the packager/ manufacturer; Kratom products must be handled in a manner to prevent contamination from poor personal hygiene, unclean equipment, toxic chemicals such as cleaners, and other sources of contamination (www.denver.gov)" Perhaps an additional public advisory could include directing people to visit fda.gov/alerts/kratom for additional information.

Kratom has significantly benefited my life and the lives of my wife and children by allowing me to optimize my physical health with the help of a natural compound. By supplementing with Kratom, I do not have to take dangerous and addictive prescription medications like hydrocodone and morphine. Since I have begun using Kratom, my dose has actually gone down over the last year. Currently, with specific strains and direct suppliers from Indonesia, I am able to take as little as 1 dose every 48 hours and no more than 3 doses in 24 hours in conjunction with other natural supplements and minerals.
Kratom is not a cure and it's not a stand-alone treatment. However, when Kratom is combined with other natural and healthy steps towards a better life, it can significantly aid the user in achieving and maintaining sobriety as well as reducing chronic pain, anxiety and depression. Many people would benefit from more studies being done on Kratom. Quite possibly we could find that Kratom is the key to unlocking this country's opiate epidemic. I request that the DEA/US FDA approach Kratom scientifically by performing studies to help further explore the use of Kratom in the United States while allowing it to remain available to people during that process.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May concern,

I recently learned that the DEA was considering making kratom illegal.  Based on my research, it doesn't appear that there is sufficient justification to make kratom illegal (or a schedule one drug).  I found that there is a dearth of information about kratom within the scientific literature.  In my opinion this lack of information kratom should not be used as a basis for making it illegal or a schedule one drug.  A lack of information about kratom is not evidence of kratom being dangerous.  To the contary I have spoken with about a dozen people who regularly use kratom.  Many of these people use kratom because it helps them stay calm and reduces their pain so they can get through the day.  Many of these people were taking prescription opiates that had extreme risks of dependency and made them feel groggy in a way that kratom doesn't (since it's effect is allegedly extremely mellow).  Many of these people have been benefiting from the medicinal effects of kratom for years and in some cases over a decade...to take that medicinal benefit away from people without sufficient evidence of a danger posed to the American public by Kratom is a miscarriage of justice.

To be 100% clear, I have not used kratom or any illegal drug for that matter...heck I generally tell my doctor not to prescribe me anything because I will refuse to take it unless it is absolutely necessary and not being prescribed for palliative reasons...I barely drink coffee or alcohol.  So I don't have "a dog in this fight."  

Whether you ban kratom or not it will not effect my life in any way but I recognize that a kratom ban will likely HURT some of my fellow Americans.  On that basis I cannot in good conscious sit idly by without saying something about this.

This country and society is clearly moving to a rationalization that while highly dangerous drugs should remain illegal, relatively safe recreational drugs (or supplements such as Kratom) should be legal.  Let's be honest with each other Marijuana will be nationally legal within 12 years for recreational/medicinal purposes.  There is no need to double down on the failed policies of the past by banning a substance that has clear medicinal benefits with essential zero risk of serious side effects.  (Yes, I read about the 15 deaths over the last 2 years, the vast majority of which appear to be due to a cocktail of drugs and/or suicide).

The arc of history is long but it bends toward justice.  Throwing people in jail for using and selling kratom will not make this country safer, it will not help anyone.  Rather, it will literally hurt people, who benefit from the medicinal benefits of kratom, and you'll create a new class of non-violent, otherwise law abiding, offenders.  Please, don't create more injustice by establishing a regulation that will result in honest/hard working people going to jail for a non-violent offense.

In closing, please don't double down on the mistakes of the past by banning a substance (schedule 1) that has clear medicinal benefits with little, if any, serious side effects.  Further, there is no rational/factual basis for banning Kratom.  Wait until there is sufficient scientific research to draw a factual conclusion about Kratom.

documents.commentText:
Health Benefits Of Kratom Leaves

Some of the most interesting health benefits of kratom leaves include their ability to lower blood pressure, relieve pain, boost metabolism, increase sexual energy, improve the immune system, prevent diabetes, ease anxiety, help with addiction, eliminate stress, and induce healthy sleep.

Kratom Leaves
Native to Southeast Asia, kratom is a tropical deciduous tree that is widely used throughout the region for medicinal purposes. The scientific name of this evergreen tree is Mitragyna speciosa, and it has had a very interesting history, including being banned in Thailand (despite being indigenous there), as it was a natural substitute for opium, thereby affecting the economy of the country. It does have many morphine-like effects, but that isnt where the benefits of kratom leaves ends. Also, there is no addictive quality of kratom leaves, which is very valuable given some of its long-term applications for human health.kratomleaf

The majority of the health benefits of kratom leaves are derived from the unique chemical compounds and nutrients found within the leaves of the plant, including a wide range of alkaloids and other organic substances that affect many of the organ systems of the human body. The plants leaves are widely chewed in countries where the tree grows naturally, and some high estimates suggest that up to 70% of the male population of Thailand chew anywhere from 10-60 leaves each day. The calming, soothing effects, as well as the undeniable health benefits of the leaves, are clearly positive in nature, which is what causes such a controversy. Essentially, kratom leaves are a substitute for opium, a highly addictive and dangerous drug, yet these leaves are seen as perfectly harmless, as regular as having a snack between meals. Now, lets take a closer look at some of the fascinating health benefits of kratom leaves.

Having experience kratom myself, I can attest to this information. 

Source: https://www.organicfacts.net/health-benefits/other/kratom-leaves.html

documents.commentText:
Greetings:

My name is Paul. I am an approximately 40-50 year old professional who owns his own company. We employ a number of people in the professional services (HR) industry.

I am opposed to the DEA putting kratom on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances. I started using Kratom about 4 years ago. I have been treated for "Attention Deficit Disorder" ("ADD") for decades, and eventually grew weary of depending on Adderall, or Concerta, or Ritalin, Vyvanse - all of the pharmaceutical options for treating ADD. Those are *okay* options and I'm grateful they exist, but I never really felt fully healthy when taking them.

I wanted an herbal or natural alternative that would leave me with few or no side effects, that I could quit taking periodically without feeling withdrawals, and which the best evidence I could find would indicate no short or long-term damage. 

The pharmaceutical options are relatively safe, but would leave me fatigued, if I wanted to stop them, I would experience withdrawal, and the verdict is out on whether my long-term use caused any damage (doubtful). Their effect would fade as I built up tolerance and I felt like I was just kind of poisoning myself.

Kratom has treated my symptoms in a subtle way and allowed me to go without pharmaceuticals. I've tried Kratom WITH pharmaceuticals, and without. And don't need the pharmaceuticals. Perhaps because my doses may be low, but I don't feel fatigued after taking it, withdrawals are no concern when I stop taking it, and it helps me keep the focus I need in order to run and co-manage my business. I take 1.5 tsp every 4 - 5 hours and for ME it provides the same therapeutic relief as the pharmaceuticals. My dose does not change, nor does its' effectiveness seem to.

As I have combined Kratom with my other life-style processes, I have a solution that works for me. I imagine there are many others in similar situations as mine. I do not want to go back to pharmaceuticals as a long-term solution to my needs, and believe me, I have taken "non-medicine" ownership of my "condition" and it is working.

I have read studies describing both the benefits and negatives of it; for me it works, and again, I hope you do not make it a Schedule 1 controlled substance, to me it doesn't seem to fit the criteria. And I hope that research monies are committed somehow (though not your domain) to fully researching it's potential, if it is made a Schedule 1 substance.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

My name is Seth Naugle and I am writing as a concerned citizen of the United States. I am a 27 year old entrepreneur, currently running a successful video production business in California. I live a healthy, active lifestyle, work to preserve our environment and try to promote peace to those around me and also through my work. In addition to all of these attributes, I am also a regular user of Kratom, or Mitragyna speciosa. 

I am writing to you today to share some of the very positive effects Kratom has had on my life since I began using it in July of 2015. I first looked to Kratom as a healthier alternative to coffee because of its stimulating effects while not containing caffeine. And since then, the use of Kratom has vastly improved my sense of motivation, alertness and most noticeably my work ethic. For me, it truly does promote a sense of well being and encourages a positive outlook on the world. Now the true redeeming attribute is that Kratom can do all of this in small doses without any sedation or noticeable side effects. Since I started using Kratom, I have become exponentially more productive, my business is thriving, I am getting amazing reviews from coworkers and my romantic relationship has become more stable and loving. All of this, plus kratom has virtually eliminated my past habits of consuming alcohol and smoking cigarettes. While it could seem that I now simply take Kratom regularly instead of these other common vices, but it does not serve the same purpose as these other vices did, which were inherently indulgent and became habits through physical addiction. And now, the huge list of negative effects from these other habits has not only been eliminated, but has been replaced a slew of very desirable attributes.

It is my firm belief that Kratom should not only be kept legal, but intensely studied for medicinal purposes and hopefully promoted in the future as a method of rehabilitation for individuals addicted to drugs, alcohol or cigarettes, depression and overall low energy. It seems to me that this ban of Kratom could lead to a repeat story to that of Cannabis, where a potentially lifesaving natural substance was illegalized before its full medicinal potential had been discovered. I also fear that placing Kratom under Schedule 1 regulations will force the product and ultimately the industry into the hands of criminals who will undoubtedly try to continue importing Kratom, which will promote more international crime activity. 

I know that I am not alone in my support of Kratom use. And I know I stand with thousands of constructive members of society that are able to reach their full potential and positively impact the world around them with the help of this organic substance. Similar to coffee or yerba mate, Kratom has the potential to positively impact the economy of the rural areas where it is produced and therefore improve the quality of life for not only individuals, but whole cultures around the world via fair trade systems.

So today, I plead with the members of the DEA to keep Kratom legal, and do this with the consideration of those whose lives have been changed for the better because of this plant and in consideration of those who will be positively affected by Kratom in the future. Think of all the junkies that could be saved from their addictions, the aging grandparents who find new vibrance in life, or the sharp entrepreneurs who are better equipped to promote their  businesses and create more jobs for the future --  these are the people who will make the worth of Kratom much greater than the sum of its parts.

documents.commentText:
Normally I would not get involved in something like this, but I feel so strongly on this topic that I don't think I could live with myself if I did not speak up.

Kratom is an incredible plant with a myriad of potential benefits to the medical community. I don't claim to be a doctor, but I do try to stay as informed as possible on topics that I think are important, and kratom is no different. Through the many hours of research I have done on kratom, it seems pretty clear to me that the benefits of this plant far outweigh the negatives. The preliminary research on kratom shows its tremendous potential in areas related to mood stabilization, anxiety, depression, opioid maintenance, opioid tolerance reduction, PTSD disorder, and many more. For the DEA to make kratom a schedule 1 would be doing the American people a severe injustice, and I beg them to do their due diligence on kratom before writing it off as completely devoid of medical uses. If a layman researcher like myself (and I have always prided myself on my objective nature, so I am not a "kratom fanboy" by any means whatsoever) can find such promising data on kratom and it's medical uses, then I have no doubt the brilliant folks at the DEA can find it as well. Being the optimist that I am, I tend to believe the DEA does in fact have the American public's best intentions in mind, so I implore you, the DEA, to please give kratom the chance to undergo the necessary research before you destroy that opportunity forever by placing it on the Schedule 1 list of drugs. 

To close the above thought, I would like mention a few destructive substances that, if they were illegal, would most definitely make the schedule 1 list. Those two well known substances are alcohol and tobacco. According to the Center for Disease Control, alcohol and tobacco together killed 120 times more American's in 2013 than all other drugs combined (I will provide a link to the source at the bottom of this document). This to me is a staggering statistic, and a group for which kratom does not belong. Kratom is closely related to the coffee plant, and while some reports vary, there doesn't seem to be a single death related to kratom use ONLY. All deaths supposedly related to kratom almost always involved other drugs, or in a few instances, substances that were passed as kratom but were in fact something else entirely (like the research opioid, O-Desmethyltramadol). In my opinion, if something should be considered a schedule 1 drug, it would be alcohol. I have seen first hand the destructive nature of alcohol, tobacco, heroin and cocaine, and kratom DOES NOT belong anywhere near this group of destructive substances. So, again, I beg the DEA to look at statistics like this and truly consider the ramifications of making kratom a schedule 1, because doing so would eliminate the possibility of further research into a plant that shows such promise. 

Lastly, I would like to touch on my personal experience with kratom and how it positively affected my life. When I was 19 I had to have surgery for something called Meckel's Diverticulum. Due to the immense amount of pain, I was administered high doses of powerful pain meds during my time in the hospital. To help ease the transition off the pain killers, I was discharged on 10mg Percocets administered 3 times daily. 

This ultimately kicked off a multi-year prescription opioid addiction, and one that I could not get salvation from. That is, until I found kratom. Where everything else had failed, kratom succeeded. I used the plant for roughly 3 weeks and then stopped. Miraculously, the withdrawals were mild and manageable and I successfully detoxed off the opioids I could not seem to kick.

Today, I am a full time college student who is nearly finished with my B.S. in Computer Science from a very accredited Michigan university. I am on track to graduate with honors, and my plan is to complete my graduate work at Northwestern University in Chicago. I can say with 100% confidence that this would not have been possible without kratom. It literally saved my life. 

I am not a current kratom user, but I still have such a great respect for it because of what it did for me. Please, DEA, I beg you to try and look at kratom from a completely objective viewpoint. I strongly believe that banning this plant will be detrimental to not only the American people, but the medical community as well. Thank you.

     What infuriates me the most is how the dea classifies it as an 'opiate' or 'opioid'. IT IS NOT DERIVED FROM THE POPPY PLANT, NOR IS IT SYNTHETIC. I have taken vicodin and codeine. documents.commentText:
My name is James Estes (70) and my wife is Diana Estes (68).  We are both retired.  Our son, Jonathan (36) is self-employed.
Our position is that Kratom is a natural, God given botanical substance that has too many medicinal benefits to be outlawed for American adults use.  Not only should it not be put on the DEA Schedule 1, it should be removed from the watch list and be allowed to be freely available to the public as any other supplements without a doctors prescription.  In addition, FDA restrictions in every form such as import limitations, customs scrutiny and holds, as well as restricted access to bank services for vendors should be abolished.
My wife has used Kratom for a couple of years, ever since she became aware of it to relieve terrible back pain and fibromyalgia, as well as to once again enjoy renewed energy.  Our son has used it for several years for anxiety and depression, as well as recurring muscle pain.  Neither have experienced any negative side effects from the various strains they have used.  
In addition, I have personally heard from many other users that could not do without it.  They have found that it has dramatically helped them to overcome opiate addictions caused by abuse, as well as medications given to them by medical doctors for pain after surgeries and accidents (i.e., automobile, industrial, and the like).  Without it they have no non-drug alternative to stay off substances like opiates and heroin.  It is a certain death decree for some of them if it is banned.  Others tell how they have used it for migraine and everyday headaches.  One banker shared how his boss was out of aspirin and he offered him some Kratom.  Within minutes his boss came back in and told him his headache was amazingly gone.  And, others tell how they used it effectively as a sleep aid, for relaxation, and mood enhancement.  These are not hearsay, but actual emails from people we know.   And, interestingly, there was no discussion of negative side effects from long-term users, just praise for the good they experienced.
In September 2016, the DEA stated that Kratom should be put on Schedule 1 because of supposed related death and calls to emergency services.  Since then it has been proven that other hard drugs were involved with the cited deaths, not just Kratom.  Calls to emergency per year were about a 135 average over five years.  However, these statistics were not shown or considered in comparison to other substances such as alcohol, sugar, and peanut butter to only mention a few which make Kratom stats insignificant.  And, what about 78,000 calls a year about bad reactions to Tylenol?  There was no comparisons at all to legal addictive drugs prescribed by doctors.
The DEA/FDA needs to forsake chasing after the low-hanging fruit of Kratom in your war against drugs.  Kratom is a dietary natural supplement, not a drug.  It can help fight the upsurge of opiate and heroine addictions.   It has been used for centuries around the world, and for decades in the US, for medical purposes.  Yes, any substance can be abused.  Case in point: look at alcohol to only mention one, and there are many more for which you have statistics, but they are not on Schedule 1!   Before Kratom is put on Schedule 1, or even left on the watch list, there should be supportable and comparable statistical, scientific evidence that it is in fact a dangerous substance.  What has been put forth so far does not meet that criteria.  It makes Kratom look like an amazing botanical, that it is, and should be available to all Americans.
There is a mass amount of literature about studies that have shown Kratom is safe for uncontrolled use by the public.  Canada undoubtedly has a library of literature as well as to why they made Kratom a legal supplement available to everyone north of our border.  The DEA/FDA has already received the epistle from the American Kratom Associations attorney as to the chemical makeup of natural Kratom leafs, which is similar to coffee, and other related facts that differentiates it from an opiate drug.  You are a government agency that has access to data and research capabilities way beyond our comprehension.    It is now time to step forward and abandon pharma and western medicine lobbyists influences, partisan pressures, and personal beliefs.  These are the very forces against which the DEA/FDA are supposed to protect the public.  No one can make a better decision for each adult of the American public than the individuals themselves!   Yes, please protect us from the scams, but otherwise level the field of decisions to a full gambit of reasonable possibilities.  Please do not make this decision for us!  -- James H Estes II

documents.commentText:
Hello friends, 

I'd like to tell you about the personal affect Kratom has had on my life. When I was 22 years old I was admitted to ER with severe abdominal pain. I found out that I had a condition know as Pancreatitis, where cysts had developed along the organ responsible for both regulating blood sugar and breaking down carbs, fats, proteins, etc. Pancreatitis is a notoriously painful condition and treatment requires heavy doses of painkillers. I was hooked up to a Dilaudid pump, which injected concentrated doses of a pain killer stronger than morphine directly into my blood stream. The pain in my abdomen was so intense however; that I needed to take Hydrocodone in addition, to simply mitigate some of the pain. Recovery from pancreatitis was a long and difficult journey. I lost over 20 lbs in 9 days in the ER and an additional 15 lbs throughout the next few months. In all I lost more than 35 lbs from the terrible condition. The pain from pancreatitis lingered for months and I continued taking opiates to simply find a degree of relief. My body grew dependent on the medication inevitably.  I eventually began experiencing withdrawal-like symptoms and sever depression if I did not take the medication. I was subsequently diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder to which I credit (in part) the role that opiates played in deteriorating my well being. I was introduced to Kratom by a friend and was initially uninterested as I had assumed it was some "legal smoke-shop drug" that you hear about on the news. I was told that it was a natural plant and that it was completely safe, which sparked my curiosity. After some on my own research I concluded that Kratom did seem to be an alternative worth trying. I was willing to try almost anything to alleviate the dependence I had on the pain medication that was having such a negative impact on my life. Not only did Kratom alleviate the pain I experienced from Pancreatitis, but it also did wonders to restore my enjoyment and ambition that had been deteriorating. I take Kratom on a regular basis for its array of benefits. It has helped with my mood in a profound way. It comforts my physical ailments, whether pancreatic pain or a common headache. It has helped boost my appetite and restore my weight. I have never experienced negative side effects from Kratom, other than drowsiness which could also be beneficial on occasion. I have stopped my consumption of Kratom on multiple occasions and I can attest that my physical dependence on Kratom is relatively non-existent compared to that of the opiate medication. I can't understand why anyone would think that prohibiting an adult from taking care of their own mind and body with natural remedies is acceptable. Kratom is a wonderful plant with numerous beneficial qualities. I truly hope your Department honestly and fairly considers the evidence. Kratom has made my life and the lives of countless others, profoundly improved. Listen to what the people are saying. Listen to what the facts are saying. Listen to what nature is saying. Please save Kratom.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

I'd hope that you'd know how it works, being as the organization is trying to supress the herb, but, here's how Kratom works: Kratom uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6. In the long-run, if someone's getting a pay-off for stopping Kratom, they could eventually also make money from Kratom.

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes that Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects. Here's a link to use for that: http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v.

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But, it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms (as in opiates). Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder where FDA's heart is?

 I am busy with my ladies Bible study's, Church group, my children's school activities, and have even regained the strength again to do gentle sports like canoeing and archery. I take Kratom.

Jana Makela

documents.commentText:
I am a 62-year old Caucasian male with a long history of Treatment-resistant depression who has undergone (unsuccessful) treatment with nearly every psychotropic medication and somatic therapy currently available. I live with my 85-year old Mother, who is my primary caretaker, and have been unable to function in the workplace for the past 8 years, my only source of income being Social Security Disability.

By way of extensive Internet research of depression-related forums, I learned of the plant-based psychotropic substance Kratom. After my very first use of this substance a little over a week ago, it was if my chronically and severely depressed brain was 'reset' --- an observation made by my psychotherapist for the last 9 years. He compared my outcome from that very first Kratom ingestion with that of ElectroConvulsive Therapy (ECT). During my first visit following my initial use of Kratom, I genuinely smiled twice during our session, a facial expression my therapist had never previously seen during our many years of working together. 

Traditional psychiatry has failed me on every occasion in terms of brightening my mood and alleviating my persistent sense of dread, whereas Kratom pulled me out of the depths of MDD after only the one usage of the substance.

I plead with the DEA to end all efforts to label Kratom as an illegal substance. I was in an unrelenting and downward spiraling of my mood, and truly believed that were it to continue, I would have no choice but to end my life. Kratom has literally eliminated that sense of impending doom. Placebo effect? Extremely unlikely for 2 reasons: 1) I have had high hopes for a number of new medications I have been on only to experience failure, and 2) I did not have much confidence at all that an herbal remedy could outperform thoroughly tested and FDA-approved medications. 

Take away Kratom, and I fear I would once again fall into the downward spiral that had but one eventual, and tragic, action to escape the clutches of severe, chronic, and treatment resistant depression.

Regards,
Gary Mordini
gary.mordini@gmail.com

Despite being properly geared, I still suffered multiple injuries that included a broken leg, arm, hip, and pelvis, all of which currently have had hardware put into them. I had to learn how to walk again, and use my arm correctly, and while I am on the road to a full recovery, every day can be a struggle because of the pain these weak points give me. I was prescribed oxycodone, hydrocodone, and Flexeril to deal with these problems, and they certainly help with the pain, the side affects greatly outweigh the benefits. The thought of addiction scared me so much, as I've lost close friends and family members to it. 

This is where kratom comes into play for me. For a while I forced myself to deal with the pain until it was unbearable, and then I seeked alternatives. I found kratom and while I was a bit skeptical at first, I was blown away by how well it works at actually making me feel like I can function in every day life without pain. That, and without a high or withdrawal that prescription painkillers can give you. I only take kratom two or three times a week, only when needed, and it would devastate me if my right to have it legally would be taken away from me. I am strongly against a ban, as I'm sure is obvious in this comment. I believe that if there is concern in the eyes of the DEA, then more research should be done before doing anything like an emergency scheduling. To whoever reads this, thank you for taking the time out to hear me out, I am definitely hoping for the best as I do not want to be forced into possible addiction. America is in an opiate crisis as it is, I don't want myself or those I love to become statistics when there's something out there to help them in the same way as prescription drugs without risking their lives.

documents.commentText:
Making kratom illegal makes little sense. It improves lives by helping recovering addicts compensate with a harmless supplement. I use it to relax after a stressed out week in place of alcohol because it makes me more social and I don't feel bad in the morning. I have never been addicted to it, nor do I see much potential for addiction. Yes, I like the way it makes me feel, but taking more will not elicit a stronger feeling. In the morning I feel refreshed, but I don't feel like I need to have more or crave it. When I heard it was going to be illegal, I easily abstained from consuming it for 2 months because I wanted to conserve the little I had left. 

I think people get the idea that kratom enthusiasts take a bunch of it and then "veg out" for hours. At least for my friends that enjoy it and myself, kratom is just a way to improve experiences. The well-being experienced while taking kratom helps introverts overcome anxiety to talk to new people; the enhanced positive feeling helps ingrain memories more deeply, from simple acts like riding a train with friends to ice skating. 

Kratom is also very safe. There have not been hospitalizations in which kratom is the sole contributor to the pathology; it is always a case of mixing kratom with "hard drugs." Adding a warning to not consume kratom with other drugs should be sufficient to assure its safety. There are hundreds of over-the-counter drugs that can have serious interactions when taken with other OTC drugs, but warning labels are all the FDA requires. For instance, nearly 500 people died in 2015 due to acetaminophen-induced liver failure with thousands more hospitalized, but no one is crying for tylenol to be taken off the shelves. I can confidently say that kratom is safer than most OTC drugs on the market, which shouldn't make safety a concern. 

In conclusion, kratom improves the lives of thousands worldwide. It has a low potential for abuse and addiction, and is safe. Banning it in a time when drug laws are increasingly getting more lax with substances like THC makes no sense, and moving it to schedule I makes absolutely no sense. Keep kratom legal; let people enjoy their lives a little bit.

documents.commentText:
The action to schedule kratom by the DEA is a mistake. Simply put, kratom is a benign substance. It is a completely safe and natural plant that has provided not only myself, but innumerable others with a better quality of life. Additionally, kratom is not an addictive substance or one that is in any way a risk to public safety. If the DEA continues with their plan to schedule kratom, it will not only erode trust and relations between citizens and the DEA, but will detrimentally effect thousands of law-abiding, contributing members of our society. 
    I began supplementing with kratom two years ago. I had overcome one the most difficult times in my life - - a drug addiction. In treatment, I was prescribed an opiate maintenance drug known as Suboxone. I had taken Suboxone for around a year, but there were many side effects which hindered my quality of life and ability to perform day to day functions. As an opiate, Suboxone also carried with it the risk of overdose through respiratory depression and potential for abuse, along with being equally as physically addictive as other opiates. Not long after, I did not want to be on Suboxone. I wanted to live a normal life; however,I found that getting clean from my prescribed opiate maintenance drug was even harder to quit than my original drug of choice. I didn't want to be on Suboxone anymore though, so I did some research and found a natural supplement called kratom. Kratom was a miracle for me. It allowed me to get off of Suboxone without having to miss work. I found that I could lead a normal and productive life with the help of kratom, with no risk of harm to my health and no risk of addiction. Without kratom, my life would in a much worse place. I finally finished up my bachelor's degree, am looking into graduate school for a doctorate, and have a great job bartending and managing a restaurant. 
     I understand that the DEA's ultimate goal is to help protect US citizens. It's a difficult and admirable job; however their efforts to schedule kratom are misguided. Kratom is a wonderful alternative to potentially harmful substances, and have provided countless people with a new lease on life. This scheduling effort represents an unprecedented overreach of the DEA and the federal government, and following through will damage relations among the DEA and the general public. Together, we can prevent immeasurable hardship on thousands of people by allowing kratom to remain legal. We can mend and strengthen relations between the general public and government agencies like the DEA if we listen to common sense, scientific/empirically backed data, and public sentiment. Ignoring those key factors in an effort to overregulate will only hurt law abiding citizens in the Kratom community and further tarnish public perception of the DEA. it's time for the DEA to focus its efforts on the actual dangerous substances and leave Kratom alone. Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
Any move to ban Kratom in the United States is going to have drastic negative effects on drug usage, health, and freedom in American society. I strongly encourage the DEA to abandon all attempts to place kratom on a list of controlled substances (emergency or otherwise). Kratom has been used by humans for centuries and, for centuries, it has been safe and effective. Only in recent years have deaths or adverse reactions been attributed to Kratom usage, notably in the Western world and when used in the presence of pharmaceutical drugs. Indeed, the hysteria around the alleged deaths attributed to Kratom have been easily disproven. Even if the numbers were real, however, the amount of people who have had serious side effects from Kratom are miniscule. 

In addition, Kratom has provided an avenue of escape from addiction for countless individuals. The number of people using Kratom to break the cycle of heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine, alcohol, and many other drugs is staggering. For the DEA to ban Kratom would be incredibly hypocritical and counterproductive for an agency that prosecutes the war on drugs and claims to want to rid the country of addictive and allegedly harmful substances.

Furthermore, Kratom has been very important for many people in the control of pain and other health conditions that pharmaceuticals could either not control or produced too many side effects to use rationally. Many individuals suffering from Fibromyalgia and other chronic forms of pain are having their lives returned to them because of Kratom. 

Lastly, in the United States of America, it is abhorrent that the DEA can even consider banning a plant and/or medicinal substances because of fear, misinformation, and paranoia. Free individuals have the right to consume plants if they so desire. If they are not free to do so, then they are not truly free. 

I am asking for rationality and reason to be applied to this decision and for the DEA to immediately back off its plan to ban kratom. We are not looking for a ban and further research nor are we looking for legalization with a prescription from a doctor. We are looking for what we have had all along  free access to a safe, effective, plant that has returned so many lives to people who had previously lost hope.

documents.commentText:
Hello, 

Kratom should not be a scheduled substance. 

It is a simple herbal remedy, that many people consume in much the same way that they consume Echinacea, mulberry, activated charcoal, turmeric, or melatonin. It is not distilled or refined, just as these other herbs are not distilled or refined.  

It is not dangerous. Every report that I have read about kratom "deaths" has actually involved other dangerous drugs. It is impossible to say that kratom caused these deaths, when any injury is more likely to be related to one of the other substances that the person had injested. Alcohol is a very, very dangerous substance. It kills many, many people every year. Yet alcohol is not scheduled. People are allowed to take their own risks with alcohol, which is really only consumed socially. People should also be free to take their own risks with herbal remedies, such as kratom.

The War on Drugs is a failure - and plans to schedule kratom are an extension of this failed war. Many people enjoy kratom very much, as a normal cup of tea, or as a replacement for coffee. If you make kratom possession a felony, some of these people will simply choose to risk becoming felons. This will contribute to a further decay of our families. Children need parents, brothers need their sisters, and we all need each other. Kratom consumers are very normal people with jobs and families. Incarcerating them for consuming a tea made from a leaf will destroy more lives than this tea leaf ever could. These sorts of policies lead to urban blight, cultural vaccums, and high crime rates. I do not support any of these things.     

I believe that the DEA has been bought by pharmaceutical companies. This is not democratic. Pharmaceutical companies have contributed massive amounts of money to fight against medical marijuana campaigns. Regular citizens cannot keep up with these expensive campaigns. Seeing yet another herb banned because pharmaceutical companies do not like it is morally wrong. The compounds in Kratom are in the process of being patented. That indicates that they are valuable. The pharmaceutical industry does not want to lose this value. They want to take this herb away from Americans for their own financial gain. I am sick of our government selling us out to these corporations, and destroying our communities in the process. 

Kratom is already a large industry. My hometown, St Petersburg FL, has 8 tea shops which sell kratom almost exclusively. Forcing these businesses to lose such a large source of revenue will likely cause them to shut their doors. These are small businesses run by regular Americans. It is unethical to jeopardize their businesses so that some pharmaceutical company can cash in on its patents. I am consistently shocked at how anti-small business our country actually has become. The DEA is now looking to play its part in shutting more tea houses, vendors, and putting more sales people out of jobs. I am very disappointed. 

Some claim that it is a powerful aly in the fight against opioid addiction. Opioid addiction is claiming many lives. I belive this to be the direct responsibility of pharmaceutical companies (who have pushed pills which were known to be addictive and death-causing) and the DEA. There are high recidivism rates among drug users because the prison system is not effective at helping or curing people of their addictions. The DEA simply arrests people and incarcerates them into a broken system. It destroys the families of those suffering from drug addiction, instead of helping them back into society. These people do not want to  be addicts. But they are not being helped in any way. Instead of addressing this issue, the DEA wants to make another herb a criminal offense, continuing this cycle of addiction and pain. SHAME on the DEA!

documents.commentText:
Hello DEA, 


My name is Maxwell Morris, I am 29 years old, and I work as a small business owner. After hearing the potential ban of Kratom, a supplement I have been using for well over 2 years, I was devastated, and could not understand why this wonderful plant could ever be defined as a schedule 1 narcotic. Kratom has helped me in many aspects in my life. Most importantly it has helped with my chronic back pain, that I have been experiencing since I was 17 years old; my injury was due to a weight lifting accident. I was a collegiate football player, and continued being active by running, and lifting weights well pass my college career. This passion to stay active has put me in the situation where pain is mandatory and inescapable. I have been through the standard painkiller prescriptions, and found no outlet that was beneficial to my life; in fact it was detrimental. Painkillers are extremely addictive, and not the solution for people who have chronic pain. Not to mention that I have had friends die from painkiller and heroin addiction. Painkillers are the gateway drug for heroin, which I am sure you are aware of. Kratom is not a drug, and is not addictive. It is simply a plant that is a relative of coffee, and has stimulating and painkilling side effects; it is not an opiate. If there were to be a ban, I don't know what my options would be to treat my pain. You would put me in the uncomfortable situation of wanting to break the law or live with crippling back pain. I know life isn't always fair, but I can't help but think how unfair it would be if the DEA decided to make Kratom a schedule 1. I can't make sense of it, and it selfishly feels as if life is out to get me. I would kindly ask you to not punish people for your lack of experience, and information about the plant. We fear what we don't know, so please educate yourself on Kratom, and I know you will feel similar to what I feel. Hopefully this plant can positively effect your life or a loved one, as it has done with me. Please do not ban Kratom, it has been a life saving, life changing supplement that many more people should be aware of. By allowing Kratom to stay legal you are literally saving lives. If you ban Kratom you will be putting many lives in danger. Again, please listen to the people in this comment period, and continue your knowledge on the subject. I would like to thank you for allowing the comment period, and I hope the Kratom community is being heard.

documents.commentText: I am a 46 year old professional who has been using Kratom for nearly 6 months now. After 2 years of being physically dependent on opiates for back pain, I was switched to Suboxone for 7 years. When I quit Suboxone, it was a roller coaster ride from the abyss. I had severe physical and mental withdrawals for nearly 60 days and once those were over, other issues that I'd never had before taking Suboxone, lingered. It was very difficult dealing with the long term effects the Suboxone had left me with. Even after 2 years of being off Suboxone, I was having terrible insomnia, digestive issues (IBS), depression, lethargy, irritability, severe lack of motivation, anxiety, heart palpitations, high blood pressure,  and many other symptoms. Because I was TERRIFIED to take another prescription to try to counteract all these long term effects, I started researching online to find some relief in a natural, safe, healthy way. I had come across Kratom on many forums, but was reluctant to try this as I didn't want to end up back in the same boat I was with Opiates and/or Suboxone. But I was literally at my wits end. I made the decision that I would at least try it and see if I could get some relief. It was simply amazing how it turned everything around within a few hours of taking it the first time.  The first thing to go was the lethargy. I felt like getting up and getting started on projects or chores I'd been putting off for months or even years. Then I noticed the irritability and anxiety subsided greatly enough for me to want to start interacting with my family and friends again.  Basically, I got up off the couch and became productive and social. I hadn't had this in many, many years. It was a major undertaking just to get into the shower and go anywhere, besides work. I didn't feel like my thinking was clouded as it was on opiates/suboxone and I didn't have a craving to take more within a few hours.  To make this a schedule 1 drug is beyond comprehension to me. I can honestly see how people who have been physically dependent on opiates, might turn to Heroin to find relief.  Although I never went down that path, I cannot judge people who have because I "Get" what they're going through and desperate times cause people to take desperate measures. I truly believe this is a proven alternative to help those that may not have the resources or ability to take themselves out of the game, and enter a re-hab facility.  As a whole, we need more resources to help with the growing epidemic of opiate use, heroin use, etc.  Not to mention, this is great supplement for many who just need help with dealing with the things that might cause them to search out ways to fill voids; such as depression, anxiety, true physical pain, etc. I have not suffered ONE side effect from taking this natural supplement and I can go long periods of time without taking it and don't go into instant withdrawals like I have so many times before when taking prescription opiates. I truly pray everyday for an "epiphany" moment by the agencies that want to take this out of game. It will be extremely counterproductive to the end outcome.  This is about people's lives and should no longer be about who can make money off this God given plant.

I am a Nationally Registered Paramedic and have a degree in biology from MUSC.  I began using Kratom in 2012. I have Rheumatoid Arthritis and have been prescribed numerous narcotic pain medications in addition to disease modifying drugs and TNF drugs. I am unable to work as a paramedic while taking narcotic medications for obvious reasons. In researching options for inflammation and pain control, I discovered Kratom. The active ingredients in Kratom allow me to work and live a full life by addressing the painful inflammation and joint swelling associated with RA. If Kratom is scheduled, I will be forced into disability and will not be able to work in emergency services. 

As a paramedic, I see the horrific crisis our nation has with narcotic pain medications. I see very young children overdose. I have had to tell a mother her son was dead, due to an opiate overdose . I do not feel comfortable having those drugs in my home and available to my children or their friends. While I have never suffered from addiction, I see numerous people that have become addicted to illicit narcotics, following a legal and necessary prescription for opiate pain medication. 

I completely disagree with the decision to include Kratom in to a C1 class. This tree has been safely used for thousands of years. I wish to maintain the freedom to choose natural, plant based therapy for my health conditions. Please careful consider this decision. There are literally millions of Americans that have chosen to use this plant. To date, there are no deaths that have been attributed only to Kratom. There is no evidence of respiratory depression associated with Kratom. There is little evidence of addiction. The same statements cannot be made of opiate based medicine. The number of opiate related deaths in the past 5 years have exceeded 100,000. This plant can be safely and effectively used as a treatment for addiction. There is no evidence that a user experiences any form of withdrawal when stopping Kratom abruptly. The same cannot be said for opiates. 

Finally, Kratom is not an opiate or benzodiazepine and should not be considered as such. There is no scientific evidence to show anyone has ever overdosed on Kratom. This is a safe and effective natural option for numerous conditions. 


Sincerely, 

Allison Nelson, NRP

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

As we are all thoroughly aware there is a opiate addiction crisis in America and in the world at large. In fact, I have several acquaintances who have discussed their issues we me at great length.

In each instance, these poor souls were weened off of opiates with other opiates or synthetics that emulated the effects of their chosen opiate based drug/s.

The acquaintances in question all began their sad journey by first taking prescribed medications. Some did so at a PCP's/GP's/MD's behest, to quell some acute or chronic pain they were suffering from. However, all of them, barring one [4 in total], eventually turned to black market heroin.

As you well know, there has been a sharp increase in the demand for black market heroin and the streets are now becoming littered with cheap and dangerous versions of this drug. 

As we continue to see legalization of the harmless drug cannabis, cartels are turning to alternative sources of income, one of which is the growing and processing of poppies. 
These scourges of the earth, you so diligently fight against daily, are becoming wealthy on the misery of others and there is something you can do to dip into their fiendish funds. Discontinue the rescheduling of another harmless plant so many turn to, to cheaply, safely, and effectively help remove their desire to continue to fund real terrorism. 

Kratom users are doing society a service by using this legal alternative option and are spending their hard earned dollars elsewhere. Kratom users are directly freeing up your, and local PD's, resources to help clean up the streets of other dangers drugs. You should not punish those who are attempting help you in your endeavors. On the contrary, you should release a statement thanking those folks for making the safe and legal decision to help you in your fight.

I urge you to seriously consider all the benefits that will come from keeping this safe and effective plant legal and to reconsider all the dangers that will befall society if the wrong choice is made.

documents.commentText:
Greetings,
I am a 41 yr old married man with a young son, living in Colorado.  I am a real estate professional with a very successful small business that I started this year after kratom helped in healing me.  I wish I didn't have to use the "Anonymous" comment, but I prefer to keep my identification confidential.  I am absolutely 100% opposed to the DEA putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances.  Kratom has been a life saver to me and making kratom illegal for me to purchase and consume would have a terribly negative effect on me and my family.  Here's a summary of my story:  I was addicted to alcohol and opiates for many years and just could not get sober.  My alcohol and opitate addiction was fueled by chronic pain resulting from a long, competitive career in a very physical sport. I have had some surgeries on my back and suffer from chronic back pain. I found kratom a little over a year ago when I was trying to get sober and now I have been sober for over a year now (14 months).  My last drink of alcohol was >14 months ago, and I have not taken any other prescription meds or even marijuana, which is legal here.  The only 2 "drugs" I consume now are coffee and kratom, with the occasional dose of ibuprofren for inflammation.  Kratom has drastically improved my life.  Before I got sober with the help of kratom, my life was a mess.  I had a newborn baby and a failed business.  In the >14 months I've been sober and only using kratom and coffee my life has done a 180.  I consider myself a very good father , friend, and family member now and I have an incredibly successful real estate business.  And my chronic pain is under control.  I'm even playing no-contact sports again!  I will be skiing again this season if kratom is still available to me.  Without kratom, I would probably have to stay off the slopes :(    Kratom has given me my life back and my family has the real me back as well.  Truth is, I was headed towards an early grave with my alcohol and opiate abuse before getting sober with the help of kratom.   Please I beg of you please do not take this incredible life saving herbal remedy away from us.  Regulation, yes that is understandable.  I absolutely do not want kratom readily available to kids.  I would not want kratom to be adulterated.  And I do not like the labeling on many kratom products.  
I know there have been some ER visits from kratom.  I was curious to know how these statistics compare to the number of ER visits from caffeine overdoses and I came across this New York Times article: 
www.nytimes.com/2013/01/12/business/more-emergency-room-visits-linked-to-energy-drinks-report-says.html   
This article says there were 20,783 ER visits from caffeine overdoses in 2011 alone.  Some caffeine energy drinks are marketing "getting high or getting jacked" on caffeine.  I have also seen some kratom labeled poorly and obviously targeting young people looking to "get high".   I think coffee and kratom are valid comparisons, they both don't make you feel very good if you take too much, and they also come from same plant family from what I understand?  These are the only 2 substances I use now that I am sober, and I do in fact consider myself a sober person with my use of only coffee and kratom.

Thank you so very much for your time and consideration of my comments.  I was devastated in early September when I heard about the 9/30 planned scheduling of kratom. And I was angry.  Then you announced that the 9/30 planned schedule was being cancelled and I was incredibly relieved.  It showed me the DEA cared.  That you heard and listened to kratom users who have had so much suffering relieved with this natural herb.  THANK YOU for that.  I will now anxiously await your decision after this comment period.  I hope and pray that I will still be able to legally consume kratom.  My life has changed immeasurably since I got sober 14 months ago, and I can't wait to see what the next years of sobriety bring me and my loved ones. I only consume kratom and coffee, nothing else.  

Sincerely,

Sober and grateful Kratom user
