documents.commentText:
re: 	URGENT -- DO NOT BAN THE SALE AND USE OF KRATOM

The DEA is insistent on banning the purchase and use of kratom.  Apparently they feel as if Americans are in immenent danger and that kratom is an opioid-like substance. Now, you're likely wondering "What's kratom?"  It wouldn't surprise me -- very few people are aware that kratom even exists. 

It is a gentle herbal supplement used primarily by older individuals to provide safe, non narcotic pain relief from arthritis and other aches and pains. I personally use kratom due to arthritis pain in my hand. I use kratom ONLY for flare ups and stop using it as soon as the pain subsides. I have never experienced withdrawal symptoms with discontinued use. 

There are many users who obtain relief from opiate withdrawal.  Since I've never been an addict, I can't describe its benefits for withdrawal. What I can  attest to is that kratom is NOT an addictive drug, it is not a synthetic party drug, it is not popular with millennials -- many of whom have never heard of it. The demographic of a typical kratom user  is 45-65 years old, suburban, middle class, employed. Generally all law abiding people. 

Kratom is not used merely to obtain a "high".  On the contrary, users quickly develop a tolerance to the "euphoric" side effect. Any attempt to misuse kratom to obtain a "high"  will result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and jitters but it will NOT result in respiratory arrest.

Another serious matter would be shutting down an entire industry. This ban would likely put tens of thousands of people out of work.  You must seriously consider the domino  effect as well.  The loss of this industry will cause irreperable harm to the economy. 

Yet another fact to consider is that President Obama worked very hard to overturn prison sentences of nearly 400 non-violent offenders. Adding a law against the sale and use of kratom will refill the prisons and overcrowd them with thousands of peaceful, law abiding people to become felons.

I've never even been arrested in my 57 years of life. I won't break the law, so now I'd have to begin the use of prescription narcotics. My doctor has offered to prescribe percocet, 10mgs, 3 times a day. I truly don't want to go there. I don't want to become an addict at this point in my life.

There is a group of senators (bipartisan) who are starting a "Dear Colleague" letter opposing the ban. I sincerely appreciate their concern in this matter and their effort to at least research kratom before banning it.

I'm sure you know that as soon as the media runs the story about the pending ban, EVERYONE will want to try it--it'll be that "wanting what they don't want you to have" category. 

Please consider the importance of keeping this mild herbal supplement legal for sale and use. I know you will do the best you can. 

Sincerely appreciated.

documents.commentText:
In reference to docket No DEA-442W
Please keep Kratom legal. It is more than just a "substitution" for those wanting to rid themselves from a life of opiates or worse. Its not just another pain reliever, though it can help so many Americans who are living with chronic pain. It is a natural alternative to so many who chose to have control over their own lives. It is a way to be aware and conscious and in control over what we choose to put in our bodies. Natural and safe alternatives should never be banned. There are to many medications out there with a long list of black box warnings. Kratom has been shown to have a very low rate of adverse effects compared to the cycle of medications Drs throw around at patients, many of which in themselves are only a trial and error solution by Drs. Kratom is way less harmful to the people's health than many medications. Many medications do not have the long term effects even known yet, Kratom has been used for centuries. As I watch TV and see all the commercials for lawsuits of medication once prescribed heavily, the truths are now being shown that many had far greater risks. So its no wonder people are turning to more natural forms of retaining their own health. Kratom has had some bad forms out there it has been mixed or sold in ways not in the best interests of the many Kratom consumers out there. Listen to what is heard, we are fighting for just the plain leaf, nothing fancy, no different than many herbal teas.
My own health problems include Ankylosing Spondylitis, An chronic inflammatory arthritis, it has no cure. It is a daily battle of pain and fatigue that no amount of medication from Drs is relieving, I choose NOT to go the rout of many that includes taking pain pills. For many years I chose to go the alternate route taking only Tramadol. But that to now is turning out to more of a dangerous drug than the people were lead to believe. So I went on a search of natural alternatives many of which is botanical in nature in a way to not strictly to "treat or relieve" symptoms of my disease, but just to create a functional quality of life where I can continue to be productive member of society for as long as my body will let me. I don't feel wanting to do the right things for my body should ever be considered a felony. Kratom is one tool I greatly want to keep in my arsenal of alternatives to (chemicals) pills. Drs promote diet changes first and this is a very heathy way to accomplish that over taking medications.
I use Kratom, I would recommend my friends and my family to use Kratom, It is a viable option in anyone's health and well being. I have helped friends who have been in the opiate mill conundrum. Given pain meds to live life with chronic pain, then without warning have everything just cut off. No assistance offered for weening down, adding to the deaths by opiates alone are those cut off and living disastrous bodily effects when they are left with zero help. Kratom has helped them to smoothly transition through the dangerous withdrawl effects at the hands of.... Well you fill in the blank here for me.
Kratom can be as individualized as are people. No one medication fits all, neither does Kratom. Call me a "tree hugger" I choose live a more natural life choosing plants over pills to find my comfort. Choosing to live with things found in nature in pure forms, not processed - pre packaged additives. I don't want to live to be 200 preserved by my foods I eat, I want to live feeling good NOW. More  people in this day and age where chemicals are becoming the norm in every day food and even the drinking water. Now that Kratom is known to be consumed by the user let us now label it accordingly and give sellers the chance to actually educate on usage and finding known contradictions.. I support some regulation to ensure we get pure natural leaf Kratom available to us and ensure the product is safe, and in the hands of responsible consumers. Kids will play, Sniffing glue, gas and paint, and mixing over the counter medicines, yet that is still available. Take a cue from that for marketing of Kratom. 
Kratom If it were so dangerous to people it would not now be as popular as it is, as more and more people learn and understand the benefits of this plant. Like anything we put in our bodies, we as the consumer must do our own research and always it is "do the benefits outweigh the risks" and with Kratom this is proving to be way more on the side of benefits, than any risk involved. Deaths are so low with the use of Kratom. There is no "high" associated with it. Kids are NOT using this as a new recreational drug. Because there is no benefits like that. Common sense is the only thing lacking by people getting such adverse effects with Kratom. Something you can see is not lacking in the Kratom community of users. Kratom is not an iminate danger to the public. Please allow us our plant and our choice to use it.

documents.commentText:
Dear Regulatory Officer- 

Thank your providing a forum to allow a rational discussion on the proposed regulations of Kratom. Kratom is not a  mainstream or pervasive substance. However, to the small population of those that use it for its effective medicinal value, this is an important topic. 

I have been using Kratom on a regular basis for both it's medicinal and social lubricant qualities. I have suffered from pain due to severely flat feet and abnormal bone structure in my foot and ankle area. Kratom is an available and cost-effective alternative to supporting my pain management. I find that it is not highly addictive; Kratom is certainly not as addictive as the drugs that doctors will prescribe one for pain. It's safe and therapeutic. 

Kratom is also a great alternative to drinking alcohol in a social setting. Alcohol is dangerously intoxicating. Kratom does provide a "buzz" to the user but it does not detriment one's ability to drive or function. Also, Kratom does not cause hangovers. 

In summary, I recommend reconsideration of the proposed regulation of Kratom. 

Best Regards,

Benjamin Jones
144-B Weybridge Circle
Royal Palm Beach, FL 33411

documents.commentText:
As a 31 year old female, I have been consuming kratom for the past 4 years. I am responsible enough to hold myself accountable and I am aware to consume this leaf in moderation. What is completely backwards to me, alcohol fits the "schedule 1" classification to a "T"  but yet, its possible to buy and consume alcohol anywhere. More people die daily from alcohol than yearly from kratom. The problem lies within the companies and businesses that are synthesizing kratom. Kratom in its whole, natural state is safe and helps combat, not cure, different ailments. Kratom is NOT a cure for anything. Kratom is an aide. This battle with scheduling kratom is a battle that is being fought and won by multibillion dollar companies like Big Pharma. I cannot understand the logic behind wanting to ban kratom. The numbers do not add up and even the FDLE does not find any risk while consuming kratom. So there have been 660 poison control calls referring to kratom between 2014-2016. seems like a lot, right? Lets put that number into perspective. The first 7 months alone of 2016 there were 6,500 poison control calls in which Tide Pods were causing a hazard.
In South Florida, kratom has had a slow steady climb in sales. Over the past decade kratom has not caused any problems. About 4 years ago, a woman chose to blame her sons suicide on kratom. Meanwhile  the man had 4 pharmaceuticals in his system that had side effects of suicidal tendencies.
Look, I am here trying to give you all these facts about why kratom should not be banned. You have already made up your mind. This public comment period was just to appease the consumers, to make it look like there was actually a care given. The only thing I can really say, please do no schedule kratom. Kratom improves my quality of life. I cannot go back to the way things were 4 years ago and thats what terrifies me. Kratom for me is not a cure, its an aide. It assists me in my daily routine just like coffee would. You wake up and drink your coffee, and I wake up and consume my kratom. Why do I choose to consume kratom? Well that's easy. I choose kratom for energy. I choose kratom because it uplifts my mood. I choose kratom because its a clean energy and I dont crash when it wears off. Now, tell me why you choose coffee? For energy, for your mood.. I bet you tell people not to even talk to you before you have finished at least one cup of coffee. I know I'm right, because I used to be the same way.
My point is, there is so much that still needs to be learned about this leaf. If kratom becomes a schedule 1, all research that is being done will come to a screeching halt. there were 150k people that signed the petition to keep kratom legal. Financially and economically, all those people that are purchasing kratom are paying taxes and are hard working americans. Our country is now at the point where we are legalizing marijuana nationally! This should have been done decades ago. Why are we going to take 2 steps forward and then 3 steps back? This war on drugs is not working. It never has and it has only made things much worse. I do believe it was Abraham Lincoln that said prohibition does not work. Im not against regulation! 18 years and older is not a bad idea. How could you live with yourself banning this leaf that helps so many people, but yet keep alcohol and tobacco legal and able to be purchased anywhere. Please reconsider. There has to be some kind of compromise that you and we could come to where we feel that we the people matter.. because Big Pharma creates customers not cures. Let us make the decision to choose natural over pharmaceutical. Last I checked we lived in the free world, only oddly enough it does not feel so free.

documents.commentText:
Prescription painkillers almost cost me everything I had. My family, friends, and finances. Kratom was an important tool in my abstinence. It allowed me to resume my life, build a stronger foundation away from dangerous drugs. I was no longer shopping on the black market, nor engaged in criminal activity. This gave me more pause before I would commit any form of crime. I never robbed anyone, only myself. But I was certainly not an upstanding citizen due to violation of the law by using prescription drugs. When a person is already considered a felon for doing a drug, it is easier to justify committing other crimes. People begin to see themselves as criminals, because that is what their government tells them they are.

Many others may have used Kratom to help stop that awful cycle of abuse and get back to a regular life. For many it has functioned as a stepping stone to ease the powerful pull of withdrawal. People do not steal from family because they want to, they begin to feel a physical need to, in order to stop the severe mental and physical pain of withdrawal. Kratom has never caused me any adverse effect, but it's awful tasting and it only works up to a point. Kratom is a mild substance.

The DEA should consider the ramifications of abruptly making tens of thousands of people who use kratom become criminals. It is undeniable that some of them will turn to the black market. As a self-employed taxpayer who has risen up out of a miserable life, I'd like to see federal resources expended toward stopping the flow of heroin and other drugs into our country. It would also be absurd for a person in possession of kratom to be incarcerated and turned into a felon, who cannot get a job, and become one more ex-con on the streets.

I would not mind to see the FDA use its authority to ensure the authenticity of kratom in some fashion, but it is not a plant that needs heavy regulation. If anything, the drug the DEA proposed to ban along with kratom (U-4770 I believe), that is dangerous, as people may put that substance into any number of drug concoctions, or put it into kratom making it unsafe. Ban the things that are truly deadly and do pose public health crises. 

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

Please don't ban nature; it really is quite a beautiful thing. I don't know if you've ever tried Kratom but if you have I hope you have had only positive experiences with it. I, myself, have had many positive experiences with the plant and, in fact, have had some not so pleasant experiences. Mostly, I want to focus on the benefits of Kratom treatment but I do not want to undermine those concerns that there may be about this plant. I use the plant to treat my panic attacks and sometimes when work is just too crippling to do, Ill treat myself to a healthy dose (~7 grams or so) of some good ol fashion nature and cruise through the day. I know this may seem strange or scary to some people but it makes a lot of sense. As a plant in the coffee family, it contains its own psychoactive ingredients that can influence your heart rate, breathing rate, and blood pressure while also altering the mood. The difference under question is how and at what cost?
Personally, I have done a lot of research about the effects of Kratom and from what I can gather, virtually none of accompanying risks of conventional opiate use, or alcohol use, or benzodiazepine use are present with Kratom. The one (maybe) potentially concerning side effect is the fact that it is a blood thinner. Therefore, those with low blood pressure probably shouldnt be using this plant as they may faint. Besides that, there other minor concerns that also come with many different medications such as itching, upset stomach, drowsiness, but nothing life threatening that I have found. I have heard of the potential for addiction but I will address those concerns in the following paragraph because that needs special attention.
The way in which American society treats addiction is so terrible because we have demonized certain drug users and praised others. We dont view addictions to substances such as coffee, or even alcohol to some extent, because they are a normalized part of our culture. In this manner, it has become so commonplace to require a cup of Joe or to in order to survive the day and a couple drinks at night to relax and unwind from a hard day. Were we to see a marijuana user or Kratom user taking their substance throughout the day, the average person may think lesser of the user because these substances have not been normalized yet by our society. Having experienced and seen the experiences of those who have abruptly terminated coffee, marijuana, and kratom usage (not all at the same time, that would be unbearable), by far the worst effects were experienced from coffee withdrawal. Mind you, the psychological effects are quite similar and include the inability to focus, lethargy, irritability, depression, and many more. However, coffee withdrawal also comes with physical side effects such as headaches, muscle pain, nausea, and other flu-like symptoms.
I for one do not care so much to think about the negative side effects, as these are typical of overuse of any substance. Instead, I choose to focus on the benefits and why some people may use a plant such as Kratom. Many people, including myself, like the idea of natural medicines because nature has fine-tuned the production of such wonderful compounds that can be used to treat various ailments. Kratom contains compounds that can be used to cure insomnia, depression, anxiety, high blood pressure, overactive appetite, relieve pain, improve the immune system, block withdrawal symptoms of addiction to opiates, as well as prevent diseases such as heart disease and diabetes. The schedule 1 classification of this plant would essentially discredit any of these properties and instead demonize the plant and its users. Furthermore, it will cause major issues associated with its distribution.
Right now, farmers simply sell Kratom as their crop and vendors distribute it across the country and the world. Making this illegal would cause tension between buyers and distributers that could potentially become violent, as has happened with other illegal substances. I see no reason why this plant cannot be simply regulated in a manner that does not allow for this potential. Making it illegal is only going to cause an underground market, which is going to take many lives. Furthermore, this plant will probably also be laced with who knows what type of opiates, rather than being exactly what we want it to be, which is pure unadulterated Kratom. If you really do not see the potential destruction that will be associated with the Kratom ban, please take a second look at the history of prohibition, specifically marijuana, cocaine, and heroin. Since their prohibition, usage has risen significantly, as well as the risk potential due to the fact that they are unregulated. If you dont want to see the type of violence and destruction that you see from the drug trade associated with Kratom, please keep it legal.

My name is William Trimbath. I am  69 years old. I retired this year after teaching for 35 years at a vocational technical high school. I served my country from 1967 until 1969 in the Quang Tri province of Vietnam as advisor for army intelligence. I have known about Kratom for some time but became personally acquainted the value of Mitragyna Speciosa when my youngest daughter became afflicted with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder after a sexual assault in her early twenties. Our family also became afflicted as the symptoms became so debilitating that she was unable to continue living her life as she had done prior to the trauma. She was an active student and worked for charity including a year as an Americorp Volunteer. After the assault, she had symptoms that disabled her and made her bed ridden. Though she was severely disabled, she worked her hardest to pursue available treatments and none worked. She soon became helpless. The available psychiatric treatment for PTSD has failed young people like my daughter and veterans like myself. When she discovered Kratom she made a quick recovery and is now living her life again. We have our daughter back and should not have to worry about losing her again. I know there are many thousands of honest and good people just like her; consuming Kratom to cope and live with conditions of chronic pain.To schedule Kratom would be to abandon them, us and the families all over again.

As this natural remedy is being threatened - we are all making ourselves acquainted with the science and politics behind this proposed decision. It has not gone unnoticed by anyone that Kratom is more effective and affordable than prescription drugs. I do not want to believe I risked my life for the freedom of my country and it's economy for such a consequential and important decision to be made hastily or for the interests of organizations and not the people. My children and the countless veterans who know about Kratom should not be denied the relief they have found - most after losing many years to pain; physical and mental. Mitragyna Speciosa is not a danger to society. I am against the proposed scheduling of Kratom. Thank you for your time, William C. Trimbath

documents.commentText: My name is Wesley f Wilson sr, I'm a 54 yr old father, grandfather and carpenter /woodworker currently employed for 14months with a custom home builder in Augusta Georgia. I was taught my trade by my late father Harry f Wilson to whom I'm eternally grateful. I've inheirated degenerative disc disease from both my parents and have suffered great pain for over 20 yrs. Also I suffer from depression,anxiety, alcohol and drug addiction. I'm also a diabetic and have had a big toe fusion surgery  on my right foot. I've been treated for chronic back and foot pain leading to narcotic dependency I started drinking and using prescription drugs trying to find pain relief for my physical and emotional disabilities over 30 yrs ago. I worked with the same company for over 20 yrs doing construction and maintainence. I was fired in 2006 because I was unfit for duty because of my addiction. I  had turned into a full blown junkie. After unemployment I tried jobs in the same field with various employers being let go for being physically unable to perform the required duties. After being laid off in 2011 from a yr job I suffered a drug overdose resulting in a 9 day coma. My kidneys failed and I was hospitalized for a little over a month. I needed a kidney transplant and was put on dialysis as well as a list to receive a donated kidney. Getting ready for my twice a week dialysis appointment I received a call from the Dr saying tests showed that my kidneys had regained function. Thank God. I tried to get clean and sober, entered Aiken barnwell mental health hospital having outpatient treatment. I'm grateful to the staff at this caring and compassionate State treatment facility. I overdosed again on morphine and xanax resulting in another 3 day coma followed by yet another rehab hospital in Aiken SC. I'm very lucky to be alive. I was unable to work and had a disability hearing pending when I discovered the plant kratom. This was the end of 2014. At the time I was on 3 different antidepressants as well as taking narcotic pain meds again. K Seeking some kind of relief . For the first time in over 20 years I immediately felt that there might be hope for my addiction ,severe depression and suicidal thoughts. I had tried everything and truly believe I was at the end of my rope. I didn't think kratom would work but stayed with it and continued to improve. In a few short months I was off all of the antidepressants as well as pain meds. Went to work for a housing developer where 14 months later I remain a valuable employee. I've even received a pay raise and am off public assistance. Kratom has been the core reason for my improvements. I was working when my disability hearing was held so I told the judge that I enjoyed working and didn't want to go on permanent disability benefits. He denied the request for my receiving benefits and I remain working today. I buy kratom online in the form of pure ground leaf and use it for my general well being daily. I truly believe that I would be dead had I not discovered kratom. So, I beg of you, please do not place kratom on the scheduled drug list. I honestly don't know what I would do about my pain. I've had no side effects at all and my blood sugar levels are great. My pain is still here but somehow I am able to tolerate it. I have no desire to use drugs or alcohol anymore. Thank you so much for your time and the work you do. Please consider my comments and thank you again. Sincerely Wesley f Wilson sr.

Docket No. DEA-442W

It is my sincere belief that now is not the time to ban another plant, regardless of its effects. Kratom helps people, but even if it was doing harm, which it is not, scheduling would only result in more incarcerations and opiate overdose deaths. 

We have an opportunity to put an end to the opioid epidemic that is affecting the lives of millions of Americans and Kratom is helping to do just that NOW. Yes right NOW, and yes, more research is needed, but in the meantime this plant is saving lives as we speak. Prohibition would be contrary to both of these things. I cannot stress this enough, Kratom is helping people right now. The very thing that we are discussing banning is saving peoples lives. 

Beyond all of this, Kratom is helping people in other ways. People suffering from chronic pain, depression, PTSD, anxiety, alcoholism, etc., are finding relief with the use of this natural plant. Prohibition would, at best, limit their options to a choice between otherwise dangerous pharmaceuticals that they have found to be less effective, have worse side effects and are also addictive, or, a life of prolonged suffering, and at worst, turn them into criminals for seeking the safe, natural relief that they deserve as human beings.

I ask that you please consider my thoughts on this matter while making your decision.

Sincerely, 
 A.G.

documents.commentText: I'm petitioning the scheduling of this drug into schedule one solely because the current system of classifying and scheduling drugs isn't an effective way of treating and helping people who have a problem with drugs. The best way to treat someone who has a problem is to allow them to be open about their problem/seek help, and to provide them with ways to combat their addiction, not to label them a criminal, resulting in even more frustration and isolation from the drug user. Science and psychology has essentially proven that the main cause of drug addiction is lack of personal connection in their life. By labeling them a criminal, it only results in making them more of an outcast and less likely to seek help. So with this in mind, I am against the classification of this drug as schedule 1, because it will only result in labeling them a criminal. The only support I would have for classification of drugs would be to take the criminal offenses away from the drugs, so people are able and more willing to seek help without repercussions, but still know the dangers of the drugs due to their classification.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I am a 62 year old married settled man in Ar.  Due to horrendous chronic severe pain, I was put on hydro-type meds.  They had horrendous side effects and after a few weeks did not work.  This was for tendonitis, arthritis, plus I'm autistic and have CHF.  Pain affects me badly.  

The amount of opiates (my other option from kratom) would kill me within a month (if lucky).  God was looking down on me when he led me to kratom. I was taking Tramadol, and while it "worked" somewhat, the side effects were very uncomfortable, and I didn't like a cloudy head. 

Whatever stories you are getting, KRATOM GAVE ME NO MORE A CLOUDY HEAD THAN ITS SISTER HERB COFFEE and it was MUCH harder to stop coffee which I've done several times, than kratom. (I've not succeeded with coffee yet which is my last "vice").  Kratom was hardly a vice.  It was/is necessary for me to fight horrible inflammation and severe chronic pain. 

I stopped kratom when it was banned in Arkansas.  It was banned improperly; which I'm sure you know. It was to be banned a week later than it was, was advertised as such so that we could have time to discuss it, and they sneaked it in (the ban) a week early. 

But even with the illegal ban, I've abstained.  My wife and I neither smoke nor drink nor take illegal drugs.  

The Kratom is very necessary for my pain.  I can't understand why my government would protect me from such a benign plant, when it is terrorists, etc of whom I'd like to be protected. 

I have no problem with kratom being treated as alcohol (18+), but I feel that way about alcohol and ANY herb. There are herbs out there much more psychoactive than kratom that are legal, but I have no interest.  Been there done that 40 years ago.

I just want my pain going and not ruin my heart with prescription drugs (what is left of it) and kratom offered that luxury at a very low price. 

I took not a gram more after 4 years of taking it on and off than I did the first day. I was happy and our marriage was working well.  I went from bedridden to occasionally mountain hiking with my wife.  I can think straight.  I'm a published writer again (hadn't written in years due to the arthritis) etc.  

Please allow us (responsible kratom users) safe access to it.  Anyone who is using it as a "party drug" is going to be highly disappointed. It offers no such "feeling" as wanting to party.  Like Ginko Biloba, St. John's Wort, etc., it offers me focus and a good concentration while, for about 3-5 hours absolutely no pain where I usually have it most. 

Thank you for your consideration.

Richard 

PS My beloved wife, age 59 gets terrible regular menopause hot flashes.  She tried kratom as a long shot; she'd tried everything else, and it worked 100%; nothing else even came close.  This kind of thing is so important for our lives and marriage. Please don't punish us for our pain. We didn't want it, and we don't want to take chemical drugs for it.

Dear Sir or Madam, 

I am writing with regard to the proposed ban on Kratom.  I'm a devoted wife and mother. Due to issues with my spine I've been in considerable pain and, at times, bedridden because of it.  I was prescribed painkillers and was taking the same dosage for five years. I did not want them yet they were, regrettably, my only option. They made me ill. There is occasional neuropathic pain, but it is far less than what I experienced while taking opioid pain meds. I also have asthma, and this plant does not expose me to the risk of respiratory distress that is present with prescription pain medication.  I humbly urge and implore you to not ban Kratom. 


Respectfully Yours, 

Stephanie

documents.commentText: In reference to Docket No DEA-442W.  I am a 38 year old Father, Husband, Engineering Supervisor, and responsible adult Kratom consumer.  I strongly oppose any scheduling of the tea leaf Mitragyna Speciosa.  However, I am not opposed to making the tea leaf only available for people over twenty-one.  I have severe back pain as well as issues with depression.  These problems caused me to be out of work for a good part of my adult life.  I tried many prescriptions for both of these issues.  Pharmaceuticals not only did not help me, but made my brain very foggy.  The worse I became, the more chemical medicines the doctor put me on.  It got so bad that I just stayed at home and collected welfare, becoming a menace to society, the economy, and myself.  One day I woke up and decided that I had enough of this life and that I needed to find a way to get better since the medicines prescribed were only making me worse.   I looked online and found Kratom.  I was skeptical at first, as I did not think something natural could help me.  When I received the Kratom, I made a tea and gave it a try.  It helped me feel better.  It did not cure my pain or depression, but it helped me enough that I could start working on myself and my life.  I have been taking Kratom for eight years now.  I am now married with two children that I take great care of, and I have a wonderful job making more money than I ever thought I could.  I have also completed many college courses since I added Kratom to my supplement regimen.  Kratom does not make me high, lower my inhibitions, or leave my brain foggy as things such as pharmaceuticals and alcohol do.  I have had blood work done and many doctor checkups since I started taking Kratom, and I am the healthiest and happiest I have ever been.  I feel it is our God Given right to use what was given to us on this Earth to help better our health and life.  I strongly believe that is the way it is meant to be, and I do not understand requiring someone to go to the doctor to receive a prescription for a plant.  Also, with the health care system in the state that it is in, who can afford to go to the doctor, or get a bunch of prescriptions, plant or otherwise? I definitely do not want to have to take the chemical versions of Kratom, that I feel certain are pending release.  If pharmaceutical companies want to make a chemical version of Kratom that is their right, but I should still be allowed to take the safe pure leaf.    If Kratom was dangerous or made you high, how did my life and so many others get so much better thanks to hard work and this tea leaf? I know what is beneficial for my life and my body, and Kratom has been a great addition to my daily supplement regimen.  It has helped me to feel good enough to start working on my life, mind and body.  My life has gotten so much better in the last eight years.  Please do not schedule this tea leaf, or make it difficult for people to acquire.   Kratom consumers have been safely taking this leaf for many years and still living a healthy productive life.  It has been safely taken for at least centuries in other countries, and at least twenty years in the United States.  If it was dangerous it would have caused problems in this country many years ago.   Instead, Kratom consumers are regular people that vote, work, and contribute to our economy and society as a whole.  We should be able to decide what supplements to take to better our life as long as we are not hurting anyone or becoming a burden on society.  I fear making Kratom scheduled would do the opposite of the intended effect.  It would hurt many people and families, as well as the economy and society as a whole, by taking working people out of work and leaving people with less safe options for their own health.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has done nothing, but positive things in my life. It has improved my quality of life 10 fold and giving me a life I never thought possible. 
In 2009 I ruptured a disc in my back at work. I was 22 years old. I went to a doctor, i didnt know at the time, that was a "pill doctor" I had never done drugs before this. For 3 months he through pills at the pain until I read online to ask for an MRI. I did and a rupture in my L5-S1 was found. I had surgery and after surgery felt great, but I had sever withdrawl. I went back to that doctor and asked for more pain killers and did so for a year until my life was falling apart. I was married and had 2 kids. My pill addictiom created many problems in my relationship. I went to rehab, but the damage was done. I continued to have marriage difficulties and ended up relapsing then finally separating and going down a very dark period in my life.

Luckily I went to prison. I was in prison for 2 years and was released March 2015. I lost righys to both my sons and my father adopted my oldest. I had ambitions of getting to be in both my sons lives. I spoke with a friend I used to use with and ge explained he was clean and living a good life. He explained kratom. Shortly after I tried kratom hoping it would help with ongoing back pain. I have Degenerative disc disease, as well. It did help to my amazement. I ruptured anothee disc summer of 2015 and refused to go on any pain killers. Kratom helps without all the negative effects of narcotic pain killers. I now have full custody of my oldest boy, an amazing fiance, a house, and last but far from least a beautiful 2 month old baby girl. Not bad from getting out of prison a year ago with a garbage bag of clothes.

I understand pharmaceutical companies wanting to create drugs with active alkoloids. They should it works, but dont stop Americans from the freedom to naturally improve their health. We are supposed to be the most free country in the world. Why does it seem like we continue to lose freedoms everyday. If we stay on this path what freedoms will be left for our children. The people are not asking to be protected from natural supplements. I thought The People is what our amazing country is all about. Please unite with The People and lets work towards making sure our country stays a country for The People.

Thank you for taking my comment.

young people are going to take drugs in peer pressure situations, even though they may be illegal. If we tell teenagers that Kratom is just as dangerous as Heroin, teenagers who try Kratom may conclude that Heroin is not dangerous.

Kratom has transformed my life. My mother was a Heroin addict, and when I was very young, she shared Heroin with me. I was just a child, I had no idea that what I was doing was wrong, dangerous, or illegal. I was young and I trusted my Mother. I wasn't able to function in everyday society. Once I was older, I couldn't maintain a relationship, romantic or otherwise, I couldn't hold a job, and I hated myself. I didn't understand that Heroin was taking those things away from me, because I was sheltered and coerced by a figure I thought I could trust.  

Once I was old enough to leave that toxic environment, I discovered Kratom. In just a few months time, I was sober. I did not experience any difficulty in "quitting" Kratom. I am now completely clean and sober, and I would be remiss if other people sharing a story similar to mine never got the opportunity to be saved. Even if Kratom were scheduled and prescribed to addicts, it would become too expensive for an addict to afford, not to mention poor people suffering chronic pain. For Kratom to undergo a transformation like that would literally be sending thousands of people to their graves. It's a substance that is self regulating, the potential for abuse is not strong enough - it's just not "fun". The only people using it are people who need to manage their pain, it's not the type of thing someone can abuse for a "good time". In fact, it's a rather uncomfortable experience; it's the opposite from what an addict is looking for. 

Thank you.

My name is Jen and I am 34 years old.  I have been married for close to 10 years and have 2 step kids (20 and 22 years old) and one biological son (5 years old). I am a student at KU working towards a Bachelor's degree in Information Technology, and reside in Lees Summit, MO where my husband and I just purchased our first house. 

About  4 years ago, I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia, a disorder that causes widespread chronic pain and shares similar symptoms as MS. Lupus, as well as many other autoimmune disorders.  I have been on many medications including opiate pain killers to help alleviate the pain. I spent a great deal of time feeling dopey, forgetful, drugged, and addicted to the opiate painkillers prescribed to me. I though there had to be more to life than this. So I started  doing some research on natural options.

About a years ago, I discovered a supplement called "Kratom" and it changed my life completely.  This all-natural supplement is in the same family as coffee and provides more pain relief than any opiate pain killer I have been prescribed. I didn't feel drugged, in fact, I had more energy than I've had in years. Not once have I experienced withdrawals or anything more than a little nausea due to taking the supplement on a empty stomach.  I feel the same way when I take vitamin B complex or my multi-vitamin on an empty stomach. 

Once being bound to my bed or couch, I am now able to be more active, play with my 5 year old son, run errands, go to school, cook, clean, etc.  All things that people take for granted that I could finally do.  I also can work out again and am doing better in school.

Losing this supplement would revert my life back to a miserable, couch-bound, and chronically ill, wife, mother, and student. It would devastate my life and relationships I have with my friends and family as well as the future that I am working so hard to achieve. I beg you to reconsider your stance on Kratom. It has helped so many people and would be a tragedy to those that depend on it to remain a functional member of society.

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a vital botanical supplement that works wonders for arthritis and pain management, and is non-abusable because any overuse causes extremely nauseous reactions. This notice of intent to schedule the "drug" (which are actually just chemical constituents of nature's botanical, not some dangerous "drug") is entirely immature and unfounded. The fact that this alleged "ban" comes along at the same time that Big Pharma is patenting synthetic chemicals that resemble these active constituents, in order to treat pain and anxiety and depression just blatantly shows how the DEA is lobbying for Big Pharma's control over the Kratom industry.

As I'm sure you know by now, the Botanical Education Alliance and American Kratom Association are pulling for stricter indications and stronger focus on purity/safety. However, while this is nice and reassuring, people who take Kratom know what amount works for them, and the only ER visits have been from polydrug use, not "Kratom intoxication" - the latter would make one vomit the Kratom and render it rather useless, floating in the toilet. But it won't land you in the emergency room. There has been a humongous outpouring of caffeine related ER visits compared to anything regarding Kratom; not to mention, Kratom is no more habituating than coffee and shares it's extremely minor day-after tired feeling. This makes sense, and it tells us that, while Kratom is a member of the coffee family (fact check me), Kratom is probably safer than coffee. At least, if you're using substance-related ER visits as your measuring factor of harm.

The community behind this plant is not seeking recreation; they are trying to live functional lives in the face of pain, fighting through it in a docile manner (especially compared to these ridiculously, incomparably addictive opioids and opiates prescribed by Big Pharma.

Of Kratom is put on schedule I and people lose access to it, you will proceed to see the worst opioid epidemic this country has ever seen. I've already read plenty of stories of people turning back into the zombified versions of theirselves on western medicine pain management therapy, and it has already ruined enough lives to take things this far. Let Kratom be, and trust that the Botanical Education Alliance will protect the Kratom using community from any hazardous sources/vendors of the powdered herb.


By the way, there are bigger flies to kill. Ever heard of fentanyl analogues, or U-47700? They are readily available and pure on black markets. I don't want to see people turning to dangerous opioid drugs or things like "Lean/Sizzurp" in place of something that was previously helping facilitate existence, rather than letting it wear away in front of you. We're already in the middle of a heroin epidemic. It will increase so rapidly after the potential scheduling of Kratom that it will be like a zombie apocalypse.

Kratom is a WELLNESS SUPPLEMENT that attenuates opioid withdrawal (without carrying the dangerous constipatory or respiratory depression side effects), eases depression for people who have no luck with western medicine, and obliterates unfounded anxiety from anxiety disorders. It is non-addictive (at least not more than coffee; Google "Kratom and Forbes" for a well-written subjective account of a writer trying to convey how docile Kratom actually is and respectively how demonized it is by this country and the DEA in particular.

Save Kratom. Save the people.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

 I am 25 years old. I live with chronic pain from illnesses that are considered terminal. I have not been able to work for the past few years because of my pain. I also had to take time off school since just walking to class is too painful for me. However, when I found Kratom over this past summer, my life changed. Within two weeks of taking it I was able to get a job. I do aftercare at a school and on Friday I was even playing dodgeball with my kids. From not being able to get out of bed 4 months ago, to playing dodgeball a few days ago, it is safe to say Kratom gave me my life back. The thought of Kratom becoming a schedule 1 drug is terrifying. How can a plant that you make into tea to help relieve pain or give you energy, be classified the same as something like heroin which has killed dozens of my friends. Kratom is in no way addictive. However, the caffeine found in coffee can be addictive but yet no one is trying to make coffee a schedule 1 drug. If the thought of that sounds crazy to you, that's how crazy the idea of Kratom being scheduled 1 sounds to me. My friend who has some similar health issues as me tried to get me to try Kratom for over a year. I kept blowing her off because in my head I thought how the hell can a plant help me when I need to take 200+ mgs of OxyContin and/or morphine daily. She finally got me to try it over the summer and I instantly regretted not trying it sooner. It makes me feel like a person again. I can work, go back to school, and just be normal. Not groggy all day from the pain meds, or in too much pain to get out of bed. My quality of life is at an all time high right now. If Kratom becomes illegal, I know I will spend how ever much time I may have left, in severe pain in bed. Kratom is allowing me to actually live. It doesn't change how sick I am, but it does give me reason to keep living until I can't anymore. Not spending the rest of my time in bed is my only wish. Please do not schedule Kratom or make it illegal. It is a tea leaf that just helps sick people like me. The way I'll live the rest of my life is in your hands. I'll either be happy and enjoy life, or be miserable in pain until my body finally gives up. This is my life being messed with, I know you will do the right thing.

documents.commentText:
I'm dying. 
I am only 44yrs old and have been ill since I was a teenager due to a genetic disorder. I became much worse in my 20's and by the time I was 30 I was started on opioids to control my pain. I was finally properly diagnosed when I was 34 and fully bedridden to relieve strain on my heart and increase my lifespan . All that can be done is to treat symptoms, there is no cure, so for 8yrs I lay in bed on increasing amounts of medications including high doses of Norco Morphine and Soma. I lived in a fog. I slept my days away. 
I have been married for 22yrs and have 4 amazing children. My husband and kids did not have me in their life like they deserved for those 8yrs and I feel like that was precious wasted time. 
I am medically educated with licenses as an EMT, EMT-I, Paramedic, Operating Room Tech, and Diagnostic Medical Sonographer. I understand how important medications are to us but have learned that we need nature too. 
Just 2yrs ago as I realize quality of life for me is much more important than quantity, I searched the Internet desperate for help that doctors weren't able to provide. I found kratom and after much research decided I had nothing to lose by trying it. 
The very first day using this herb I went half a day without needing (or even wanting) my opioids. I have a new energy similar to really good strong coffee but no jitters. I cannot handle coffee normally as my condition has caused heart failure and I cannot handle harsh stimulants. I was alert!! I was able to spend time out of bed and with my family. I now spend anywhere from 6-10hrs of my day out of bed (which is huge for me) and am able to do some small chores around the house but mainly it's time I have with my family.  I am able to spend this precious time with them now and only wish I had found this herb sooner. 
I am now on the very lowest doses of opioids and only taken on really bad health days despite the fact my health is rapidly deteriorating. I have no negative side affects from kratom and my body is highly sensitive to medications normally. We all deserve to be able to do what is best for our bodies and this is best for me and countless others. Please don't take this away. Utilize this plant to help people! Allow us our promised freedoms to use natural supplements and help people get healthier again. Allow me to spend my end of life with my family. This herb deserves further research and testing, closing that off will only hurt so many people and one day it may be you that is in need of it. We need MORE options to alleviate illness symptoms not less. We need to see these testimonials as a beacon of hope that nature can help some people and be open to that idea. We need to embrace what nature has provided and not make everything about big pharma and money! Save this herb and help change lives!

As an epidemiologist investigating health outcomes associated with supply-side drug control policies, I strongly urge the DEA to withdraw the proposal to place mitragynine into Schedule I. 

The established pattern of prohibition leading to emergence of yet-more hazardous substitute products gives policy makers good reason to reconsider using that instrument as a means to protect public health and safety. Until safe, effective, and accessible alternatives are available to Americans who use kratom, this policy places our population at undue risk, and should be avoided in observance of the precautionary principle.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement Kratom; there should be no prohibition.

While the FDA is looking into it, most Americans have never heard of it.  Why?  Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it!  Quite the contrary.

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain.  Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Kratom works by using a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation and respiratory depression.  In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies (http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6).

A leading researcher notes regarding Kratom that Thailand is considering legalizing it as a safer alternative for meth addicts.  U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects (http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v).

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk.  But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms.

Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, more dangerous, and harder to kick.  Yet the FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban Kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance.

Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize Kratom?  Because that is exactly how this looks.

documents.commentText:
I am an environmental service worker at a local hospital and would like to state my opinion and belief that Kratom should remain legal. Approximately three years ago, I was prescribed anti-depressants after being diagnosed with depression. My psychiatrist, at that time, prescribed me with a few different SSRI's and a dopamergenic. I know that for some people, anti-depressants may work, however they had an adverse affect on me and the side effects far outweighed the benefits. I found that the SSRI's made my depression worse. I tapered off the medication, which was difficult, even though I was only on them for a couple of months. At that time, I heard about Kratom and decided to give it a try. I consumed Kratom for approximately two months in the wake of my negative experience with prescription medications. Kratom did not cure or treat my depression, however it noticeably enhanced my quality of life. I still struggled with depression and I still had anxiety, however, Kratom helped promote a sense of well being that made it possible to get through those two months and still be a productive member of society. To further expound upon how Kratom has helped me, yet not treated any condition of mine, I would like to go into detail about just what my condition is. Recently, I discovered through a gene test that I have a genetic mutation of the MTHFR gene and this means that my body does convert folic acid into methylfolate which is the precursor to serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine. I have been supplementing with a prescribed medical food, L-methylfolate, which has targeted that genetic anomaly and balanced it, therefore increasing my serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine levels safely and naturally without any adverse affects. Also, my serotonin transporter has a genetic mutation where the presynaptic transmembrane protein (SLC6A4) has an intermediate risk of being non-response. Essentially my serotonin levels can pool up, therefore generating large risk with any intake of a prescribed SSRI. This also means that my glutamate levels are higher than the average person, which can generate large amounts of anxiety and also create insomnia because your brain cannot turn off. I would like to reiterate and say that Kratom did not fix these gene mutations and increase my serotonin levels like L-methylfolate has, nor did it force my glutamate levels down like a prescribed medication would. However, in that transitory phase of my life, Kratom safely helped promote a healthy lifestyle and gave me the energy to continue working. It's a safe alternative to caffeine and I would like to compare and explain why Kratom is safer than caffeine. I consumed a lot of caffeine in my years prior to my experience with Kratom, and it damaged my health. Caffeine acts on the adrenal glands, which is the bodies primary defense against stress. With my genetic variations, stress and depression were amplified, and when my adrenal glands were exhausted, I had no physiological defense against that stress which contributed to developing GERD and other digestive imbalances. Kratom has proven to me to be safer than caffeine and has not had any negative impact on my body like caffeine has nor has it inhibited my bodies ability to fight stress. In fact, some of the many alkaloids found in the kratom plant, act as an immunostimulant, which has helped my body fight off infection. Granted, when it comes to fighting bacterial and viral infections, there is no replacement for proper diet and sleep. I implore the FDA to do rigorous testing of Kratom and allow for data to be put fourth from many reputable and independent sources in order to prevent bias. 
  I would like to pose a few questions to the regulatory agencies that have read this comment in addition to thanking them for taking the time to read my testimony. Firstly, I would like to ask the DEA as to why they chose to pursue a ruling over Kratom before the synthetic substance, U-47700. I am aware that they have stated their ruling to schedule Kratom was in the interest of public safety, and I believe public safety should be top priority. However, as reported by FoxNews in June of 2016, research chemical U-47700 was directly responsible for fifty plus deaths nationwide in a span of less than a year. This poses a much greater danger to public safety than any recorded threat of Kratom, however legal action was first initiated against the natural plant Kratom and not synthetic chemical U-47700. This leads me to my next question, will the DEA publicly release the footnotes that were the basis for their decision to schedule Kratom under the FOIA?
 In conclusion, Kratom has been legal for over two decades in the US and has never caught on as a recreational high. It does not incapacitate the brain like alcohol does and has a long history of safe use. Please keep Kratom legal.
 Thank you for your time in reading my public comment and considering my questions. May you all have Happy Holidays this year.

documents.commentText:
Hello, I am writing to you today about a great injustice which is about to befall our country. As of September 30th, the D.E.A is going to reschedule Mitragyna Speciosa, also known as Kratom, to schedule I. Just to refresh, the DEA definition for a schedule I is as follows:
Schedule I drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse. (A DE. DEA / Drug Scheduling. DEA / Drug Scheduling. https://www.dea.gov/druginfo/ds.shtml. Accessed September 1, 2016.)
With the phrase, "no currently accepted medical use," in mind, I would ask you to refer to the link to the article below from "The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association," which states explicitly:
"Evidence suggests that kratom is being used extensively for both medical and nonmedical purposes. Recent studies have shown that kratom contains a variety of active compounds that produce major pharmacologic effects at opioid and other receptors. Kratom and kratom derived drugs may potentially be used for management of pain, opioid withdrawal symptoms and other clinical problems." (Prozialeck, W. C., PhD, Jivan, J. K., BS, & Andurkar, S. V., Phd. (2012, December). Pharmacology of Kratom: An Emerging Botanical Agent With Stimulant, Analgesic and Opioid-Like Effects | The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. Retrieved September 01, 2016, from http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2094342)
The doctors from the above article, and the numerous journals they cited throughout their article agree that kratom is currently being used for the medical properties of the plant, and further study and research is needed, "Further research on the therapeutic uses, toxic effects, and abuse potential of kratom and its constituent compounds are needed." (Prozialeck, W. C., PhD, Jivan, J. K., BS, & Andurkar, S. V., Phd. (2012, December). Pharmacology of Kratom: An Emerging Botanical Agent With Stimulant, Analgesic and Opioid-Like Effects | The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. Retrieved September 01, 2016, from http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2094342)
If we allow the DEA to reschedule Kratom, Mitragyna Speciosa, we will be removing a potentially lifesaving medicine as well as criminalizing a wide swath of our country's population overnight for possession of their medicine.
There are numerous accounts across the internet from veterans, teachers, professors, normal everyday Americans which Kratom has helped ween off of opioid addiction and manage pain. Sure, these people could be lying because they want to get intoxicated, but to what end?
Kratom should be scheduled, that is a fact. If we truly want to foster innovation in this country and live up to the true "American exceptionalism" we have built ourselves up to, we should not establish the schedule of Kratom as any higher than Schedule II. At that level we can foster and federally fund research while reigning in the free-for-all market that currently exists. Once sufficient research from universities and pharmaceuticals has been completed the DEA can re-schedule kratom as it sees fit, but there is no reason to stifle research of any drug.
Also, bear in mind, states could behave in the same manner they did with Cannabis, rebuking the federal government and the DEA by legalizing the drug in their state. The federal government and the DEA find themselves in a very untenable position as the movement grows and more states legalize Cannabis. This piece-meal approach to legalization is dangerous with widely varying statutes and regulations at the state and even local level. Reasonably scheduling Kratom would eliminate the need for heavy handed action by the states' politicians to preserve and advocate for their constituency.

documents.commentText:
I am a healthy, 25 year-old, male college graduate, and a very hardworking, successful individual within my career. Kratom has personally helped me immensely in coping with anxiety, depression, and chronic physical pain. I have been using kratom supplements, and researching kratom for nearly 4 years for several of the beneficial effects. I do not believe there is much of a debate on whether kratom is safe. Even with little research concluded at this time, one can assure you that kratom is one of the absolute safest, pain-killing supplements there is today, even when comparing OTC painkillers, like Tylenol and Advil, which are both known to be extremely safe, yet have caused far more deaths than kratom. Kratom use has been recorded for thousands of years and has never been proven to be the standalone cause of a single recorded death. In the research that has been completed, kratom has shown to be a very safe, useful, non-addictive supplement that has several benefits, with very few drawbacks. Kratom is also one of the only supplements with pain-killing properties that does not cause respiratory depression, which is the leading cause of death in opiate overdoses. Scheduling this plant to any degree at this time would not only be irresponsible and unreasonable, but it would put research to a halt, forcing American citizens back on harmful prescription drugs that are known to be dangerous and addictive, with no resolution for the issue in sight. This supplement needs to remain completely legal, and available to all American adults, or else those in need will suffer, and if history has taught us anything, prohibition of kratom at any level will lead to unintended, adverse consequences, such as more addiction, incarcerations, organized crime, overdoses/suicides, etc.

I have heard from many users who turned to kratom after being unable to function properly on pharmaceuticals due to their addictive properties. Kratom doesn't "cripple", or kill, its users. In this substantial opiate epidemic, there is a great chance that kratom can help those addicted to opiates, and as the people are claiming, it already has. Research shows that kratom does not create addicts; in fact, research shows that it cures them. This is a plant that is helping millions, being erroneously and negligently outlawed. I am afraid scheduling kratom will have contrary and unintended consequences. In states that banned kratom, Alabama specifically, opiate usage and deaths went up considerably after kratom was banned in the state. In Florida, the FDLE issued a report that said "no pervasive health issues have been attributed to the ingestion of kratom products in Florida". North Carolina also recently decided not to ban kratom after hearing testimony from people who benefited from the supplement; instead of an outright ban, they made it legal for adults ages 18+, which would be much more beneficial to the cause and is known in recent history to have much less unintended, negative consequences.

The American people are overwhelmingly in favor of keeping kratom legal, as it is much less dangerous to consume over synthetic drugs on any regular basis. The American people should have the right to safely and freely use this plant as a substitute of the dangerous, addictive, harmful drugs that are still being legally over-prescribed by medical professionals, which are responsible for the deaths of nearly 19,000 Americans per year, as well as the additional 10,500 who die from heroin; many of whom became addicted to the drug while taking their legally prescribed pain medicine. It is no secret that the healthcare system in America is seriously flawed and is even influenced by major pharmaceutical companies for the sole purpose of creating wealth, often at the burden of the American people. Outlawing kratom would only amplify this issue, giving more power to the same corporations that are benefitting from the American people remaining addicted to harmful substances, and would even put responsible, moral, law-abiding Americans in prison, simply because this natural supplement helps users cope with their ailments. By scheduling kratom at any level, the American government would be forcing its citizens to choose between either consuming harmful, synthetic drugs, which they do not want to consume, and/or suffering; denying ones' basic individual liberty to live a happy, healthy life in America. Most users do not want to take kratom supplements, but rather choose the lesser of two evils when dealing with chronic pain, depression, addiction, anxiety, and even PTSD. Not everyone is blessed without ailments. Millions of Americans and I, including many injured US Army veterans, whom I've heard from, will suffer without kratom. It is unethical to forbid these users a supplement that they could not imagine living without. Kratom must be kept legal for all American adults for our country to progress, and not regress further into the opiate epidemic we are facing today.

My name is Rachel Smith, I am 39 years old and work as a herbalist, health coach and licensed practical nurse. I discovered kratom earlier this year, in February I believe it was, as I was researching alternatives for pain control for my late husband. Brad (my late husband) was diagnosed with pancreatitis when he was 19 and was diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis in January 2015 (age 40). His condition deteriorated rapidly from 2015 until his death on May 4, 2016 at age 41. During the last 16 months of his life, he suffered excruciating pain, depression, anxiety and addiction to his prescription pain medications. His functionality declined to the point that he was primarily bed bound, only getting up to walk to the bathroom. We did everything doctors told us to do but he continued to get worse and his pain medications continued to provide less and less pain relief. When I came across information about kratom, we decided to try it, after all what did we have to lose? Amazingly enough, on the days when Brad used kratom, he hurt less, he was a little more active, his appetite increased, nausea decreased, he was more alert and talkative, he felt lighter spiritually and emotionally, his mood was improved; he was a lot more enjoyable to spend time with. The differences in my late husband's entire demeanor and activity levels were very noticeable between the days that he would take kratom and those when he did not. On the days that he took kratom, he was more like himself before his health declined so much. I am extremely grateful for those days with kratom. I sincerely wish I had discovered kratom years ago as I believe it would have helped my late husband have a better life than what he ended up with. 

I decided to take kratom myself. I noticed that I slept better, I had more energy, and I felt better all around. I had a very large uterine fibroid that resulted in me having a hysterectomy in September 2016. Kratom helped me to remain functional and able to keep working prior to the surgery when I had excruciating pain from the tumor. Kratom has helped to balance my mood and sleep since the death of my husband and I believe that it helped me to recover from the surgery as well. Kratom helps me to remain functional when all I would want to do was lay in bed on a heating pad. Kratom helped my late husband and me deal with several health concerns. 

I firmly believe that kratom is extremely beneficial as a supplement for physical, mental, emotional and spiritual wellbeing and should not be added to the list of scheduled drugs. Kratom is a naturally occurring, God given plant and should not be made into an illegal substance. It has proven useful to countless individuals over the centuries and should remain available to people who wish to supplement their health and wellbeing with it.

I both suffer from chronic pain and work in healthcare and have seen first hand the destruction brought on with the opiate epidemic. I have used low doses of opiate pain relievers for over a decade- low dose- no escalation in dosage or drug types.

When I first read about Kratom, after the proposed ban, it captured my curiosity and I acquired some at a local shop and was interested in whether it might be a viable alternative to prescription pain medications. My first trial was a disappointment as the effects were not remarkable. I dismissed it for awhile until another article caught my attention and I did a bit more research. This led to me understand that different varieties and colors have vastly different effects. With this knowledge, I acquired samples of five different strains. These Kratom powders were of much higher quality than my first trial and with the first dose, I noticed a significant analgesic effect as well as clarity of thought contrary to that which is largely diminished with my usual hydrocodone. Additionally, when the effects wear off, the Kratom did not leave me tired and grumpy.

Other strains do make one sleepier. Some were more likely to dull my thinking. The point is- That they all had DIFFERENT effects and characteristics.  

After reading up on this, and discovering that there are so many in the community who are currently using Kratom to treat chronic pain, I think it would be highly irresponsible to ban this medicinal plant.  With the increased regulations on opiate pain prescriptions, doctors are more and more hesitant to prescribe them and many patients are left with nowhere to turn.

I also might suggest that the gateways be opened to allow for further study of Kratom and its compounds as a viable alternative to opiates- which have left in their wake, a long trail of casualties.

My name is Brian Dougherty. I'm 27 and I live just outside of Philadelphia in Pennsylvania. At a young age I was diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome, which has since been reclassified to fit under the umbrella of Autistic Spectrum Disorders. Along with ASD comes a slew of afflictions such as ADHD, depression and low mood, anxiety (including social anxiety) and a few other things. I have been struggling in the past four years since the death of my mother and living with my father has been far less than harmonious. 

It has been nearly impossible to find a doctor to help me with my problems in the past few years. The ones I've seen prescribed me a few different anti-depressants and antipsychotics, or even stimulants and other drugs with awful side effects.

While it isn't perfect, Kratom (or Mitragyna Speciosa), which is actually a cousin of coffee, has been a godsend for me. It has been helping me cope with all of these afflictions. It completely eases my social anxiety which helps me talk to people, it boosts my mood, helps me focus on things that need to get done including chores and exercising, and also alleviates the low mood nature of my depression. I've been taking it in addition to or in place of coffee, in fact, as coffee very much upsets my stomach. And, due to its chemistry, kratom has actually regulated my unfortunate digestive issues!

When I found out about the emergency scheduling of Kratom, I immediately started crying. This is a heinous approach to a nonexistent situation. I have had zero negative effects from kratom since I've started taking it, with different blood tests to prove it. It'd be awful if it was scheduled into a category worse than the very harmful and addictive drugs 'methamphetamine' and 'cocaine'.

Please, have it in your heart to join me and many other Americans that this substance has benefited to help keep Kratom legal. We can't do it alone. Your help would me more than appreciated! Thank you so much.

documents.commentText:
Dear Regulators,

Please do not place Kratom on any drug schedule.  The last thing we need you to do is to reduce access to any freely available tool for pain management and substance abuse control.  

If Kratom were truly dangerous, that would be a different story.  But side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.  Also, Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

There are social reasons to keep Kratom freely available, in addition to the humanitarian ones.  Let's keep our resources focused on substances and unscrupulous companies which are damaging to people.  

Thank you for your consideration,
Tom McCurry

To whomever it may concern, 
    I'm very ashamed to admit that around 8 or 9 years ago, I slowly became an opiate addict. In the beginning it was occasional use, and by the time that I was ready to seek help, I had pills on my nightstand to take 15 minutes before I even got out of bed. I discovered the buzz as a very motivated feeling that made me much more social, and I was able to work very long hours. My first encounter with oxycodone was when I hade my wisdom teeth pulled many years before it became an addiction. In 2007 I found out I was going to be a father, and that's when I truly realised that I had a very large problem on my hands. So, I decided to seek help from a specialist. I went to a psychologist once a week, and a counselor on another day. I felt it was the proper thing to do. The psyc doctor was very crude and not interested in any history of abuse or anything in my life, she simply wrote prescriptions for suboxone, and claimed I was self medicating for "add", in which she prescribed adderall  ( a highly addictive amphetamine).  These two medications combined gave me extreme anxiety and night terrors, so she then wrote another scipt for another addictive drug, a benzodiazepine called klonopin.  Ilived like a zombie for 4 years on this cocktail of dangerous and even lethal combo of drugs for approximately 4 years. I no longer wanted to be a slave to these pharmaceuticals and naively decided t stop cold turkey. By the end of the first week my misery from withdrawal symptoms was so awful I was on the verge of suicide,  ironically enough, thats when i descovered the organic herb kratom during a web search  for help. I ordered a small amount and had it shipped priority. When the package came I believe I was at the peak of w/d. I very skeptically  made a tea out of the ground up leaves,and drank it. In about 15 minutes, my symptoms were still there but probably cut in half.  I had a feeling like " I can get through this!". I have continued with great success to stay away from dangerous prescriptions,, both legal and illegal for the past 5 years. Instead of chasing pills out on the street, If I get an urge to relapse, or have a few too many drinks, Im at home with my family making a harmless kratom  tea. Comparing kratom to these dangerous opiates, would be in the same ballpark as comparing methamphetamine to coffee. Kratom alone has not a single death on its hands. I ask, with much respect, please consider the thousands of people that this gentle herb has greatly improved the lives of. People from all different walks of life. At, a time when prescription drug abuse has become an epidemic along with heroin, it would be down right irresponsible to make it unavailable to the people. Thanks for your time, and I know that you will do the right thing. 
Much respect. 
Dominic
