documents.commentText:
I am writing because I am deeply disturbed and adamantly opposed to the Drug Enforcement Administration's announcement that it will temporarily add Kratom (mitragyna speciosa) alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine to the list of Schedule I drugs, effective September 30, 2016. 

Personally, Kratom has affected my life in nothing but a positive way.  At the age of 19, I was prescribed benzodiazepines (Xanax, Klonopin) for PTSD, Panic Disorder, and Generalized Anxiety Disorder, as well as Paxil for depression.  I became addicted to these drugs, which led me down a devastating path for ten years.  In September of last year, I decided to change my life.  

A friend of mine, who is a nurse, told me about Kratom and how it was being used across the world to help people stop taking dangerous opioid and benzo prescriptions.  I started drinking Kratom Tea about three months after I stopped taking my prescriptions.  After a few weeks of using Kratom, the anxiety and depression that had plagued me for years was starting to subside.  

I have now been using Kratom for 10 months and I feel that I have made more progress in the last ten months than I have in years; such as successfully treating the underlying issues of anxiety disorder and major depression.  This amazing plant has changed my life.  I am now a college student, I work part time and raise my daughter as a single mother.  I stopped drinking alcohol and currently do not take any prescription medication.  I do not think that I would be thriving as well as I am without the natural, medicinal properties of Kratom.

I honestly fear for the addicts in our country if Kratom is banned.  I believe there will be more overdoses and death due to people finding other ways to relieve their physical, mental, and emotional pain.  In the handful of states where kratom has been banned, such as Alabama, the number of opiate-related deaths increased significantly following the implementation of the ban. 

Thank you so much for your consideration in this matter.

Sincerely,

DeeAnna L. Dempsey

documents.commentText:
I am a 31 year old teacher, and strongly oppose kratom being listed a schedule 1 drug.  While I am not a kratom user, it disturbs me deeply that the government would take such a strong action against an herbal medicine that has little to no evidence of harmful attributes and thousands of potential benefits reported by users.  This substance has been used casually and medicinally throughout the world, and aside from a small number of deaths associated with kratom (15 since 2010) all of which were in conjunction with other known illegal substances, this substance has elicited little to no known deleterious effects. 
Assigning this substance a schedule 1 narcotic would eliminate any potential research being conducted by scientists outside of heavily controlled government funded trials, and criminalize the activities of many productive members of this society.
It would be unnecessary and counterproductive to outlaw this substance.
Thank you for your consideration,
Wyatt Hesemeyer

documents.commentText:
My name is John, Im currently 28 years old and in my last semester of college, on track to graduate with a B.A. in less than a month. I first began using kratom about eight years ago after spending the preceding two years repeatedly trying and failing to break an addiction to opiates which began as a result of knee surgery. Kratom went a long way in terms of decreasing my cravings and withdrawals without leaving me intoxicated, and I truly believe that I would not have been able to quit using opiates had I not discovered kratom. 

While I still use kratom occasionally for pain relief from more minor issues (normally just when I have a cold), quitting daily use was not a challenge by any means, which leads me to believe that the concerns people have expressed over addiction to kratom are entirely unwarranted. Additionally, I have not suffered any adverse health effects as a result of kratom use, and regular liver and kidney screenings (which were done because of an unrelated concern) during the period that I was taking kratom daily, always showed normal function and enzyme levels. While I know that one persons experience isnt necessarily representative of the larger population, given that there are thousands upon thousands of reported kratom users in the US at the moment, I think that if kratom were any sort of threat to public health, these issues would have become apparent in scientific literature long ago. I believe that banning a natural plant that many people find helps them with a number of different problems, but that does not pose a threat to its users health, would be completely counterproductive.

A ban on kratom also scares me because I worry about the possibility of relapsing into opiate addiction if I ever had to undergo another medical procedure requiring the use of strong anesthetics (and there is a strong likelihood that I will have to undergo another knee surgery at some point), but also because such a ban would greatly limit ongoing and future scientific research on this plant, depriving everyone of any medical potential it may hold.

documents.commentText:
My name is James Wilkerson and I use kratom to treat chronic pain. I was able to stop taking prescription opioids (which is a good thing since it is almost impossible to get a prescription these days) and have been able to manage my pain with this inexpensive powdered leaf. If you search around online you will be able to find reports of people who have used kratom to treat their chronic pain.

Importantly, while Kratom offers similar relief from pain as the opioid drugs such as Vicodin and Percocet, it has never produced concerning results not even stomach upset. It has some similar action to opioid medications I have never experienced deleterious side effects using 4-5 grams per diem.

While Kratom is currently unavailable to me here in Alabama, I strongly support it's continued availability elsewhere in the country and the correction of the ban in Alabama.

Note for the record that I am a 57 year old white male in regular health other than extremely painful osteoarthritis (for which there is no cure). Kratom was an extremely effective pain reliever for over three years and I am devastated that it is no longer available here.

Do not subject others to my fate!

documents.commentText:
I am a 50 year old disabled male from Metairie, LA.
I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. This would put kratom, a plant helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally, on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.
 In 2007 I was diagnosed with both rheumatoid and osteoarthritis, a disease that burdens me with daily persistent chronic pain, and is causing the deterioration of my joints. Later in 2008, I was diagnosed with the bone disease avascular necrosis in my left hip. This added more severe, often unbearable, chronic pain to deal with in my life. In Feb. 2009, I had a core decompression, bone graft, and titanium implant surgery on my left hip. Most excrutiatingly painful thing I've ever experienced in my life. Walking(limping with the assistance of my trusty cane) would never be the same again. The rheumatoid arthritis kicked into high gear after this. Flare-ups were worse than any worst case of flu one could imagine having. The bad flare-ups still are. On top of all this, I still have to deal with eye disease and ocular migraines. I was born with macular dystrophy. In 2001, I began having many problems seeing, so I got a referral to a retinal specialist. Lattice degeneration was added to my list. As the years progressed, retinal holes had to be lasered closed, a diagnosis of Pseudo Foster-Kennedy Syndrome was added to my list, and then in May 2015 I had an optic nerve stroke(Non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION)) in my right eye, leaving me legally blind in that eye. In October of this year I was diagnosed with glaucoma to add to my list. The opthalmologist told me every layer of my eyes are diseased, and that I basically have the equivalent of the eyes of an 80 yr. old man. This explained my headaches. The debilitating migraines I get some days are also unbearable at times. But, chronic pain is my way of life. It is a daily struggle to deal with it. The doctors prescribed medicines that I hated the way they made me feel(not myself), and the side effects of these medications that were supposed to be helping me soon outweighed any supposed benefits. As my diseases advanced, I decided to take it upon myself to start researching Native American and Asian culture natural plant based/herbal medicines. It was my studies of southeast Asian cultural traditional natural plant based medicines medicine that led me to the Kratom plant. I soon discovered that the powdered leaf of this plant when brewed as a tea did wonders for my way of life, especially dealing with the constant chronic pain. No negative side effects ... ever ... and my chronic pain was bearable to where I could function at least somewhat normally(considering my limited mobility ability). I also noticed that I wasn't having near the rheumatoid arthritis complications/flare-ups as when I was taking the doctor prescribed pharmaceuticals. Inflammation seemed to be kept in check, too. The kratom plant has helped me tremendously, safely and effectively, in the 6+ years that I have been using it brewed as a tea. Kratom changed my life for the better. When the DEA announced its letter of intent to ban this medicinal plant leaf as a Schedule 1 substance on August 31, 2016, I was devastated. Panic, sadness/depression, and soon anger began to set in. Another freedom was being taken away at the hands of government overreach. I'm left questioning whether or not this is still America I'm living in, land of the free. I thought that I have the right to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. I'm not a criminal. I don't drink alcohol, or use illegal drugs. I'm a responsible 50 year old law abiding adult citizen. The fact that I'm trying to improve my health and well being with medicinal plants is a threat to whom? No-one! No harm, no foul. I'm not doing anything to anyone else, or their property, by drinking kratom tea. I'm living my life the best way that I can. Living with constant chronic pain isn't easy. Kratom has improved my quality of life where the medicines that my doctors prescribed previously have failed. The leaf of a tree brewed as a tea can effectively improve my life of chronic pain, safely. Years of experience prove that. How is that a hazard to me, or anyone else? It isn't. Perhaps it would be better for the DEA to concentrate their focus on the real deadly drug problems spiraling out of control in this country ... Prescription opioids/opiate abuse and the heroin epidemic. It is my opinion that the medicinal plants are part of the solution.

documents.commentText:
My name is Jamie. I'm 40 years old, I have an 18 year old special needs daughter who suffered a traumatic brain injury as an infant and is a brittle Type 1 diabetic, has severe ADHD and behavioral issues, thyroid disease and a seizure disorder. I also care for my elderly mother who suffers from advanced COPD and vascular dementia. I work a full time job as an overnight stocker at a big box store. 

I take kratom to help with issues stemming from chronic IBS-D and depression and anxiety. I have taken a myriad of medications for these things over the years, all with unwanted side effects. Kratom helps me deal with these things with no side effects. It does not make me drowsy, or "up" or high. It just lessens intense stomach cramps and stabilizes my mood and allows me to work a demanding physical job and have enough energy to handle everything I have on my plate. 

I realize I'm only one person, but I implore you not to place kratom in Schedule 1. I and the majority of kratom users are responsible adults from all walks of life and are productive members of society who simply wish to lead our lives without too much suffering. Please let us continue to use this plant and let us live our lives and take care of ourselves. 

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern of the FDA, 

I can equivocally state that should you reach a decision to ban Kratom people will die needlessly, and vastly more harm will have been done based on a fearful reflex and arbitrary statistics. Kratom is demonstrably harmless both in my own life and in the scientific literature.

As to my own experience with Kratom, I have used it for 5 years for anxiety. Prior to my Kratom use I took SSRIs and alcohol which drained my personality, sex drive, and general joie de vivre. However, with Kratom my quality of life has substantially improved, I attend a tier 1 law school, receive good grades and volunteer in my local community. My story is not unique, Kratom users are average moms, dads, students, and employees who want to find an alternative to the toxic substances that are literally killing Americans daily. Scheduling Kratom at a time when our President has stood for releasing thousands of non-violent drug offenders would create a whole new class of peaceful persons eligible for arbitrary prosecution and sentencing. There are over 24 peer reviewed studies pointing to Kratom's safety and no one has ever died due to Kratom alone. Based on the criteria the FDA and DEA are applying to Kratom, any substance not statutorily protected from the CSA's reach could be banned based on a rush to judgment by executive agencies who are meant to protect us. Please reconsider what you are doing, not only will it substantially harm me, but all of my loved ones in our community who have used this wonderful plant to get off more harmful substances. Your decision is not some abstract ruling that will not be felt by anyone, quite the opposite, people will die going back to heroin, and personally I will be forced to go back to the SSRI's which took so much of my personality. 

Please do not ban Kratom, it simply does not meet the criteria of even the most harshly dispensed 8 point test.

Back Off!
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am psychiatric registered nurse, and I work in an inpatient psychiatric hospital where we serve people with severe mental illness. We also detox patients from drugs and alcohol. I regularly hear tragic stories about the effects of addiction in our patients' lives, most often opioid addiction. Individuals from every walk of life are losing loved ones to this terrible, yet treatable disease. I believe we should provide addicts with as many resources as possible to get clean and remain sober. If this includes the use of kratom (and/or its compounds), a plant in the same family as coffee, common sense says we should keep this plant legal, at least until its benefits and negative effects are thoroughly researched and compared.

Here are some statistics to consider:

In 2014, there were 18,893 overdose deaths related to prescription pain relievers, and 10,574 overdose deaths related to heroin (29,467 total deaths) (https://www.regulations.gov/comment?D=DEA-2016-0015-0006). Over the past 2 years, this epidemic has increasingly run rampant, and there are more and more cases of opioid/opiate overdoses each year. Additionally, the rate of opioid abuse by adolescents has increased, which means our children are becoming addicts, which often results in them squandering their future or losing their lives.

Every day, over 1,000 people are treated in emergency departments for misusing prescription opioids, which adds up to 365,000 each year (http://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/data/overdose.html). This is a huge financial burden, but more importantly, lives are lost. There are numerous users who overdose and die before reaching the hospital.

Additionally, addiction is often dually diagnosed with mental illness, which is another issue in itself. 
  
It is suspected that 15 deaths in the United States between 2014 and 2016 were kratom-related. However, there is no evidence that kratom is the sole contributor to an individual's death ( Warner ML, Kaufman NC, Grundmann O (2016). "The pharmacology and toxicology of kratom: from traditional herb to drug of abuse". Int. J. Legal Med.).

So, how is opioid addiction treated now? One of the most popular methods involves doctors prescribing buprenorphine (subutex, suboxone). Not everyone has insurance or the financial means to afford this medication, and many do not have access to doctors who are qualified to prescribe this medication. Meanwhile, kratom can be purchased online and delivered to their doorstep. As a result, kratom and/or its compounds could potentially be an alternative form of treatment for this population.

So, please, I beg you, compare the aforementioned statistics: 29,467 total opioid/opiate deaths in ONE year (2014) vs. 15 potential kratom-related deaths in two years. 

Does it still make sense to ban kratom and its compounds before we rigorously research and explore its benefits? No, not at all. It's simply an illogical, irresponsible, and immoral knee-jerk reaction Even if kratom reduces the number of lives lost by a small percentage, it is worth it. 

Think of the lives and relationships it could save, psychiatric disorders it could prevent, and its health benefits. 

At least give it a chance. 

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am the face of a chronic pain sufferer. I am a 50 year old mother of 3 who suffers from debilitating chronic pain, panic & anxiety disorder, and depression. I am also a recovering alcoholic (11mo!). I am very concerned regarding the potential scheduling of a natural botanical called Kratom, which I have found to be a safe and effective herbal remedy, related to the coffee family, and consumed like a chamomile tea. 

In the early 90's I was diagnosed with Endometriosis and by 2001 I had been diagnosed with Major Depression, Fibromyalgia (which no one really knew much about), TMJ, and learned I had hypothyroidism. It was wonderful being able to put a label on all the ailments I experienced but I was also immediately placed on the pharmaceutical superhighway and felt like I lived inside a doctors waiting room. With each new side effect of a previously prescribed drug, I was given yet another drug to take to combat the side effects. After multiple various doctor visits, surgeries, and being on the strongest pain med available at a very high dosage, along with antidepressants, muscle relaxants, and various other meds, I simply could no longer function. All the joy in my heart, left. I lived in a fog, my memory waned, I couldn't focus, I had no energy or stamina, I couldn't properly parent my children, and I developed a dependence on alcohol just to be sociable, and to dull the pain that the prescribed medication wouldn't touch. No person should have to live their life around the schedule of taking 15 different medications, doctor's appointments, or depending on alcohol to function, which in itself created more problems and worse pain. Ultimately, I lost my full time job of over 16 years, and I almost lost my life after having collapsed into a coma. I woke up feeling like such a failure; as a mother, as an employee, as a citizen, and as a human being.
 
Upon leaving the hospital last December, void of any other substances in my system and a God given determination to find a better way, I decided to go a more holistic route and discovered after much research, a natural botanical called Kratom. I had never heard of it before but after reading testimonies of the experience of others, and information available including scientific research, I decided to try it. To my delight, with this wonderful plant I was able to wean off many of the prescriptions (including the pain medications), therefore reducing the many side effects of those drugs. I was also able to no longer depend on alcohol to self medicate. I don't have a taste for it, there are no cravings, I don't need it. Supplementing my treatment plan with this God given botanical has allowed me to focus again on something other than my pain. It has given me energy where before I had none, and I have begun to live life again. And although I know it will be a long road back to the person I once was, I have hope.
 
Now the government intends to ban Kratom, making myself and all those benefiting from its healing powers into criminals overnight! I finally find a natural way to gain my independence and be productive, and that avenue is now threatened. This I just do not understand.  Where are my unalienable rights that are guaranteed in the Declaration of Independence upon which the government is supposed to protect? Why don't I have the right to pursue happiness? Where is my liberty, my FREEDOM TO CHOOSE? It should be illegal to criminalize nature! We Americans should not be mere pawns in the DEA, the FDA, and big pharma's game of chess. Many chronic pain sufferers will have no choice but to be bedridden again. Many will go back to being drug addicts as well. Not by choice, but by necessity. If Kratom does indeed become illegal, some of us will not even survive. I know of many military vets whose lives have been saved due to Kratom. Those who fought for our freedom, why is our government now taking away theirs? And mine. 

I don't want to go back to that dark and lonely place, that place of being a non-functioning, unproductive, bedridden sick person, instead of the vibrant person I can be again thanks to Kratom. It is not a road I want to go down again. When the greed of our government overrules quality of life there is no justice and all is lost. When you can't live life free from pain by using what nature provides, so others can line their own pockets, there is no freedom, only pain. 

An acceptable and more responsible route to take would be to place regulations on Kratom. Regulations for strength and purity, age limits and warning labels. An even better route to take would be to let the kratom community (such as the AKA) self regulate following the guidelines set forth by the FDA, but please do not place this on the scheduled list of drugs. It needs to remain available to us in its most natural form, inexpensively, and from responsible vetted vendors. Kratom is not a drug, it is a God given plant.
Thank you for your time and consideration.
DEA-2016-0015

I want to start by saying that kratom saved my life. I was an athlete through college, which gave me many injuries and lifelong pain. I was prescribed an opiate pain medication. Within six months, I was addicted. I started selling everything I owned in order to support my habit. I am a single father, and was mentally absent from his life. This is when I first seeked help.
   After I finally admitted that I was slowly destroying my life, I checked myself in a detox program. I spent a week there, left, and immediately started using again as soon as my pain and anxiety became too much to handle. This cycle continued for over a year, until I waa arrested for selling property that didn't belong to me. My eight year old son watched his father get put in handcuffs and thrown in jail. This was a turning point in my destructive cycle. I began researching different methods of staying sober and living a productive life. This is when I found kratom.
   The first time I tried kratom, I immediately knew that I was onto something great. My pain and anxiety just disappeared. I noticed no symptoms of euphoria, however being pain free was euphoric in itself. It was an immediate difference in my life. 
   I have now been sober for over two years. I still use kratom at times for my pain and anxiety, but I also go periods without using it at all. It is definitely not harmful or addictive. My son is much happier now to have his father back. I am back in college. My life is improving daily. Kratom is to thank for saving my life! 
   Thank you for reading my comments. It is very important that kratom remain legal. There are lives being saved on a daily basis thanks to this plant.

documents.commentText: My name is Jennifer and I'm a 39 year old stay at home mother to a 14 year old daughter and a 10 year old son. I have been married for 15 years to the love of my life, who also happens to be a public servant as a firefighter/paramedic. Prior to being a full time mom, I worked at an advertising company for 10 years. I am a college educated woman, graduating at the top of my class with a degree in English from a private university. I am a volunteer at my kids' middle school and was a Girl Scout Troop Leader for 8 years. I am also a chronic pain sufferer due to bulging discs in my lumbar spine from a car accident in 2008 and was diagnosed with a chronic pain and fatigue disorder called fibromyalgia in 2015. See, I gave some basic information about myself and my life first, because I want you to see me for the upstanding member of society that I am before I told you about my pain problems. That's because I'm not an addict or a drug seeker, as we with chronic pain are often assumed to be.  I'm just a regular suburban wife and mother that is unlucky enough to suffer from pain and fatigue every day of my life. Before I was introduced to Kratom by a woman in my fibromyalgia support group, my only relief came from narcotic pain killers. I always receive my medication from a reputable specialist and always take it as prescribed, but because there is such a high risk of abuse, addiction and side effects, I must comply with urinalysis and blood tests to qualify for the medication. Since I started taking Kratom a few months ago, I've been able to significantly decrease my use of these pain killers. That's a load off my mind because I've been concerned for some time now about the long term effects of these medications on my health. I've done as much research as possible on Kratom and I can't find any evidence of Kratom causing any dangerous side effects at all. From what I've read and from my experience, it's also not addictive, which as you know is a huge problem with opiate pain killers. It's also not possible to overdose on Kratom. It seems to be a safe way to significantly reduce my pain and fatigue, and that it does. It has improved my life so much in the short time that I've been taking it. It's given me hope that I now have a safe and effective way to manage this debilitating disease that I will suffer from for the rest of my life unless a cure is found. Instead of classifying this supplement as a class 1 substance, we should be thanking God and celebrating that there is a safe and effective alternative to narcotic pain medication.  For the life of me, I cannot understand why making Kratom illegal is even a consideration! I suppose it's difficult to appreciate the importance of Kratom in the life of someone like me if you've never suffered from years of daily pain and fatigue.  Every day I had to fight to keep this disease from dragging me down into depression and hopelessness.  I know that probably sounds dramatic, but imagine feeling flu-like fatigue and body-wide pain every single day, knowing that you will never get better without becoming depressed. Trust me, it's a struggle. Kratom has given me hope. Please, I'm begging you, don't take my hope away.

I have been using Kratom almost DAILY for over 2 years.  First, I tried it as an alternative method of dealing with a [diagnosed] anxiety problem.  The Kratom worked so well that I was able to ween myself away from expensive anxiety medication I've been taking for ~10 years.  Now, instead of medication, I drink (1) cup of Kratom tea every morning, and (1) cup every afternoon, and my anxiety "problem" is controlled (i.e., no longer a problem).  When I'm not able to have my Kratom tea for whatever reason, I have absolutely no problem whatsoever going days without it (i.e., it is NOT addictive).  My only complaint is that is doesn't taste very good.  I also suffer from Restless Leg Syndrome.  If I have a flare-up, I drink a cup of Kratom tea and the problem goes away for 4-6 hours.

Since using Kratom, I've found other benefits from it.  My blood pressure, prior to using Kratom, was borderline high.  I was on the cusp or requiring blood pressure medication.  When I use Kratom somewhat regularly, I find my blood pressure is consistently reduced to a level my doctor finds healthier.

Last, Kratom has benefited my digestive system greatly.  For many years, I've been plagued by acid reflux, indigestion, diarrhea, and constipation.  When I drink Kratom somewhat regularly, my acid reflux and indigestion is MINIMAL.  Also, my bowels are much better regulated with the Kratom.  Instead of diarrhea and constipation, I find my bowels are better regulated than ever before, presumably due to the high fiber content of Kratom tea.  Also, at ~$1.00 per cup, it is extremely affordable!

I have had NO negative side effects from Kratom.  NONE.  Again, my only complaint is that it's like drinking dirt.  However, the benefits have been tremendous for me, and I would hate to see Kratom banned.  A ban of Kratom would force me back to a doctor to find other, more costly remedies for problems I manage well today with Kratom.

Please contact me for more information about my Kratom success story.  Please, for the love of God, don't ban it.  Do proper research.  It is certainly NOT addictive, nor is it even remotely dangerous unless it is extremely concentrated, which requires expensive chemical processing of which most people don't have the capability.  it just tastes bad!

documents.commentText:
I oppose the proposed ban on kratom for the following reasons:

 1.  If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
 2.  Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
 3.   Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.
 4.   Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

There is no legitimate reason to ban kratom.

documents.commentText: What we want from you is to support Kratom users in the fight to keep Kratom legal and stop BIG PHARMA from keeping people addicted to their opiate medication. There are many of us that utilize Kratom for our ailments and treatable conditions such as chronic pain and opiate addiction. Taking Kratom away from those people  Kratom has played an important role in my life, says Maximum King, who suffers from chronic back pain; due to degenerative disk disease and two disk herniations, I constantly have to deal with pain, Kratom makes it possible for me to get through those difficult moments without subjecting to opiate drugs or other narcotic pain killers. Max has a past history using opiates, before he hurt his back, he never want to use opiates again. Kratom is a savior in my life, not only has it helped me with my pain, it has also been a huge contributor towards keeping me away from opiates which is major. Max prepares Kratom into a drink with hot water and organic Kratom leaf powder, which he buys online from a vendor out of Pennsylvania that sources their Kratom from farmers all over the world. The price for an ounce usually ranges from 8-15 USD, you can buy it in bulk in its leaf powder form or premade into pills or resin. Kratom is not addictive and does not lead to withdrawal symptoms, except when egregiously abused. First off, we should clarify exactly what it means to be addicted to a substance like Kratom. Under the technical definition, an addiction is a physical dependence on some substance that creates a strong and harmful need to this thing regularly. Addiction causes a literal rewiring of circuits in your brain that makes you dependent on constantly having some chemical compound. Kratom is not addictive in this sense, making it quite different from other natural pain medicines or drugs like opium and heroin. However, Kratom may be habit forming or cause some type of psychological dependence if it is continuously abused for long periods of time. the addictive potential was considered to be less than the caffeine in coffee.

documents.commentText:
Re: Docket No. DEA-442W

I've tried most scheduled drugs at some point in my life. Even though I often enjoyed the experiences, I completely understand why they are controlled substances. I believe the DEA is acting in the American public's best interests by controlling them. 

Including Kratom among those substances would be flatly absurd. It's eyebrow-raisingly incongruent with the nature of the substances which are already scheduled, and would very much hurt a small, sincere and productive segment of the population who enjoy the effects of kratom for non-chemical relief from chronic pain, anxiety, opiate addiction and more.

If you have not yet tried kratom, I suggest you do. I feel certain you will agree with me that it is miles away from a "fun" drug, and you will understand within one experience with it that it has almost no potential for abuse.

Kratom has a lot in common with other herbal/natural nootropics people take to better themselves. It has nothing in common with drugs people take for fun, or to forget their current reality. That includes marijuana and alcohol.

I began taking kratom last year because I heard it helped some people successfully manage depression and social anxiety. I was diagnosed with both many years ago, but find the side effects of SSRIs and other prescription treatments VERY detrimental to the quality of my life.

Kratom helps me not feel terrified of every one and every thing. It helps me to not obsess over negative details and instead see a broader, healthier, more complete picture. It helps me feel ok.

Since I started including kratom in my nutritional supplement regimen, where it takes a natural place alongside substances like 5-HTP, Vitamin D, green tea and fish oil, I've vastly improved the quality of my life. My small business has taken off and is making twice the profit it was before kratom. I've started working out several times a week, and have toned up and lost weight. My relationships are healthy and satisfying for the first time in my life.

Dread, which used to be my go-to mental state, rarely makes an appearance these days. I feel a normal level of self-confidence. I feel motivated to succeed at life.

Please leave kratom alone. We who benefit from it in ways we're deeply grateful for will appreciate your lack of action more than words can express.

PS - The proposed scheduling of kratom has had an effect I don't imagine the DEA expected or desired. It brought kratom widespread focus and attention, and much of that attention is coming from the young people I imagine the DEA is seeking to "protect" from it. Now people who will not benefit from kratom are interested in it because they believe it will be an enjoyable "high." I'm sorry the attention you've paid kratom has had this effect. But it's really not a big deal; they'll try it once or twice and find out that unless they're suffering from chronic pain, crippling anxiety or a prescription pill habit they'd like to break, it's not worth their while.

documents.commentText: I urge you NOT to place kratom on a the controlled substances schedule. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I have been taking kratom several days per week for the past 4 years, with many positive results and very few negative ones.  I struggled with depression, anxiety and chronic back pain for much of my adult life, and sometimes drank too much alcohol and occasionally took opiates to combat these symptoms  This drinking wasn't so much of a problem that it interfered with my career or life in general, but I was always looking for something else to provide a relaxing, non-toxic means of relief.  I do not enjoy marijuana, so this wasn't an option, and other herbal supplements were found ineffective.  

Upon discovering kratom, I immediately lost all desire to drink alcohol or take other drugs, and my pain and depression has been greatly reduced.  I find kratom to be an excellent pain reliever, mood booster, and effective anti-anxiety and anti-depressant compound. Taking a few teaspoons mixed in water during the evenings provides at first a mild stimulation, then a relaxing, calm, happy state which persists for hours.  I find I am in a better mood, things which would normally stress me out or weigh down my mind are easily dealt with, and it is very easy for me to be creative.  I have gotten very into playing and recording music, as kratom seems to facilitate a creative, open mindset.  When sick with a cold or flu, or when suffering from any physical ailment, kratom reduces the dysphoria and body pains greatly, without the sedating numbness of opiate drugs.  

The side effects are relatively minimal compared to opiates or especially alcohol.  If taken on an empty stomach, kratom can cause gas or mild nausea, but this is easily remedied by taking it after eating.  The only other side effect I have noticed is a mild lethargy in the mornings after taking too much the night before.  Certainly nothing compared to the vicious hangovers from drinking or the crippling headaches from prescription opiate withdrawals. 

Based on my extensive research, there is only 1 death ever on record that can be solely attributed to kratom.  All the other deaths occurred with a combination with alcohol or other strong depressant drugs, which are surely to blame.  Given that hundreds of thousands of people in the US take kratom on a regular basis, if it was truly dangerous, even a fraction as dangerous as drugs like oxycodone or hydrocodone, surely there would have been thousands of deaths by overdose by now?  There is simply not enough evidence that kratom presents an imminent threat to our public health to justify an outright ban.  

By doing so, the DEA will be needlessly criminalizing a large segment of society and also, perhaps most damagingly, restricting future research on the medical benefits of kratom.  It is incredibly difficult for scientists to do research on schedule 1 drugs, and placing kratom in this category would be very harmful, as there is some evidence to suggest the compounds in kratom could provide a safer alternative to classic opiate treatments, and could lead to an entirely new class of painkiller drugs,which do not suppress respiratory function.

I have a friend who used kratom to successfully quit heroin, and I have read hundreds of other similar stories online.  Given that our nation is in the midst of an opiate epidemic, it seems that, if the DEA truly wants to protect the American people, it would not be banning one of the most promising treatments for this addiction.  I'm not saying kratom is a cure-all, or that it should be taken by everybody.  I don't even mind if the industry is regulated, like tobacco and alcohol, and taxed accordingly.  But banning this plant outright would be truly harmful to our society, and would deprive many people of pain relief and other benefits.

I sincerely hope that Kratom will remain un-scheduled in the future.  Please let the scientific community research this plant for the years to come, and see what it has to offer.

Thank you,

X

documents.commentText:
I am writing personally to address the potential status of Mitragyna Speciosa (Kratom leaf) becoming a Schedule I substance. I will be as forthright and honest as I can; please consider my point of view as I also represent many others alongside me.

I have used Kratom for the past 29 months (2 years, 5 months). I use it on a daily basis. I tell only my friends and close family members, but no one would know otherwise. The only alteration it's made to my life is that I do not suffer so severely from my extreme emotional sensitivity  due to Borderline Personality Disorder. It is an Axis 2 mental health disorder, and about 10% of people with it die at their own hands; its as hopeless as it gets without treatment. Your emotions are extreme and fragile, your relationships are just the same. With it, it's near impossible to live and function normally, and I was almost at the end of my rope two and a half years ago. I have made 2 suicide attempts throughout adulthood (I am 30 years of age now). 

The treatment for this disorder has no prescribed medication, and the counseling and group therapies (though they have been effective) take years to produce results. Without enough stable, disposable income to support such treatments, I was going nowhere.

I was on the verge of a Vicodin addiction after a tooth infection 2 years ago, because it (for the first time since high school) took the emotional pain out of me. I could relax finally. I didn't even know what was in Vicodin, so I did research and discovered that it's a narcotic opioid that can be EXTREMELY addictive and harmful. I thank God every day that I did not fall into an addiction with it, as tempting as it was at that time. What it did though was lead me research for a safer alternative that could help me with my emotional distress and emptiness. That's when by God's grace I discovered Kratom.

I was skeptical, I was nervous, and I didn't know what to expect... but I gave it a try. Here is what I have found to be true with Kratom.

I know what the FDA and DEA report about the effects and dangers of Kratom, and Ive also seen the way it's reported by the media. The truth is, I have never had delusions or hallucinations, never has it caused nervousness, agitation, aggression, sleeplessness, tremors, loss of libido... never have I even had any severe withdrawal symptoms even when I go multiple days without it. Constipation is really the only side-effect I've had, but Ive found when taken in a hot-tea form it resolves this issue. I know that may sound unrealistic to you (especially given how the media portrays Kratom to be)  like surely there's more I'm not telling you, but I really am telling the truth. I am 30 years old, I live independent of my parents, have a stable job in accounting, my own apartment, car, provide for myself and am on a path to achieve the goals I have for my life... and constipation is the only side effect I've ever experienced with Kratom in 29 months.

Not only has it not affected me the way the DEA and FDA say it should, but NEVER (and I mean never) has a direct death been found from Kratom use. All cases of reported deaths (as I'm sure you're aware) found numerous other substances in their system as well. And the CDC has only had one possible call of a Kratom overdose, which was not conclusive either. This is all VERY important to consider. What is the true harm here? Is there any truly, documented, known danger that Kratom causes? It's worth honestly and scientifically seeking an answer to that before reporting it to be on par with Heroin and other Schedule I drugs... is it not? Many foods can cause constipation from time to time, many foods can even produce sickness and harm your body if used irresponsibly... but there is no record that Kratom has ever seriously harmed anyone. It is an uplifting herb indeed, but in a mild, natural manner. Does this alone make it worth banning? Let it be studied and have real documented, scientific conclusions made on it before making a decision like this. Please! 

As a former athlete and basketball player, I have used MANY exercise/workout supplements (such as Creatine among others) that have had far worse and more negative side effects, especially to my digestive system, than I've ever experienced from Kratom. But nothing I've ever tried has been THIS BENEFICIAL to my life overall. It can be such a blessing, and I -- just like you -- would like to see something this valuable used responsibly. I can understand protecting people from danger... but banning this without a true, scientific look at what it does seems irresponsible to me. 

Consider that Hydrocodone (which kills upwards of 16,000 people a year!) is still just a Schedule II drug! I am a respectful person, but please could you help me and write back with the reasoning behind Kratom leaping up as high as a Schedule I? In no way, I truly mean this, does this plant deserve this. Every DEA, FDA, or media report uses such stron

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a useful herbal supplement that improves the quality of life of hundreds of thousands of Americans. In addition, researchers believe kratom could potentially be used to create safe supplements for mild pain.

Scientists have indicated, however, that if kratom becomes a Schedule I substance then it will be almost impossible for researchers to study any potential benefits. People who currently drink kratom tea will no longer be able to enjoy the benefits of the herbal supplement and it will become a felony for Americans to own a mildly uplifting tea. 

Thousands of Americans from across the country have come together in an unprecedented way in order to request that kratom does not become a scheduled substance and instead remains legal; a White House petition requesting that kratom remain legal garnered over 100,000 signatures and kratom rallies were covered by news outlets such as NPR and Forbes.

Reporting by the Washington Spectator outlined why making kratom a scheduled substance would be the wrong policy. In their reporting, the Washington Spectator noted that: "Making kratom a 'controlled substance' could impede future research. Vradi notes that if kratom is restricted 'it will make it much more difficult to obtain large enough amounts of the plant product . . . scientists will have to obtain a Schedule I license and go through multiple administrative steps to obtain kratom and its alkaloids for their research needs. The decision may also hinder future clinical studies that would look at the effects and safety of kratom in humans.' 

The Washington Spectator's full reporting can be found here: https://washingtonspectator.org/tea-action-kratom/

No deaths have ever been directly connected to kratom. Centers for Disease Control centers received substantially more calls about laundry detergent pods than kratom in 2015 and 2016. Energy drinks kill multiple people each year; kratom has killed zero people throughout its decades-long history of use in the United States. 

Perhaps kratom should be regulated in a way that requires clearer labeling and better quality control standards. But making a safe herbal supplement like kratom a scheduled substance will impede research, harm consumers, adversely effect public health in America, and will set a dangerous precedent. Given the unnecessary harm that would be caused to American consumers if kratom were to become a scheduled substance, I urge the Drug Enforcement Administration to reconsider their proposed rule and instead allow kratom to remain freely available to Americans as a legal herbal supplement.

documents.commentText:
I would like to share my story with everyone. Most who know me know I have suffered with severe pain for 3/4 of my life. I recently came across some information on a plant called Kratom. I spent four months researching everything about it. When you live with severe chronic pain the way I do, you are willing to try anything and everything to help you feel as close to "normal" as possible! For many years I have felt like nothing more than a pincushion with a delusional hope of being even half the person I used to be. With appointment after appointment. Scan after scan. Surgery after surgery (including a spinal neurostimulator that is supposed to help reduce my pain and doesn't). Injection after injection. Pill after pill. So many, I have become quite a pharmacist without a degree! Not that I've ever asked to be one or even had a liking for pills of any kind! I've never been the type to enjoy taking anything at all. I remember a time I would struggle with a headache just to avoid taking an asprin. Little did I know... taking pills would be my life. The unpleasant side effects of Pharmaceuticals are something you can only understand if you've been subjected to them as your only option to relief for an extended period of time.. all of which are horrible! Little did I know that my suffering could have ended a long time ago by drinking an all natural tea called Kratom. I am on month two of my Kratom journey and my body hasn't felt this good in a very very long time! When taking my regular meds, if you were to ask me what my pain level is my answer normally is anywhere from a seven to plus ten! However, here I am on month two of Kratom tea and my pain level has been NO more than a four....which to me is almost INVISIBLE! I have taken zero meds and have experienced NO withdrawls from dropping them either!!! UNBELIEVABLE to think that I am finally going to get the life I worked so hard for back! I honestly never thought I would as my condition (DDD) only gets worse and worse. I am still in shock and my emotions have been a complete Rollercoaster. I have been stuck between crying because I can't believe how great I feel...and unspeakable anger because our society allows people like me to suffer while making big Pharma richer and richer with no real pain relief for patients! Anger because I finally found something Natural that ACTUALLY WORKS and the FDA/DEA wants to take it away from us!!! Something so harmless in comparison to all the pharmaceuticals ever prescribed to me. The same pharmacuticals that have destroyed my stomach, intestines, gallbladder and liver to name a few. I have gone to extents that NO person should have to....just to find one single ounce of relief so that I can just be a mom, a woman... who can wash her own dishes, make dinner and care for her children. My journey has been unbelievably dark and full of more suffering than any one person should ever be forced to endure! Pain takes over my entire mind, body and soul regardless of how hard I fight! It changes you and makes you feel lost and worthless because you aren't the same person anymore. Many, many times I have contemplated my existence and lost any and all hope for a functional future. Suicide has danced through my mind way too often over the years. I honestly never thought I could feel "ok" again until Kratom gave me my life back! 
I am begging you to leave Kratom alone! Us chronic pain patients have had things shoved down our throats for years...let us drink our tea in peace. Please do not ban this harmless plant. The facts are there...the evidence that (pure) kratom is safe and works wonders is there. Don't we suffer enough already? Opiates/pills are horrible and they are the problem not kratom!! Please focus your attention on the things that are killing people not the things actually helping to FIX the problem Big Pharma has created. #IAMKRATOM #KeepKratomLegal #KratomSavesLives #PLANTSNOTPILLS #PlantsNotPoison

Due to that I had to depend on prescription pain meds to be able to function day to day. I lived in a pain med induced haze. I would nod off at all times, I couldn't drive my children to their activities because of the meds and I lived in fear of an accidental overdose. I was terrified my kids would find me dead  in the morning before school or when they came home from school. Since the day  I decided to try Kratom my life has changed. I know longer doze off, no longer fear going to sleep, I can drive a car now and not worry about passing out! I participate in my kids lives and I am back to being a normal happy wife and mom.I take Kratom twice a day and now I am a functioning member of society ! Taking Kratom away from me would devastate me and my family. Cost wise we saved money because I no longer have to pay constantly to see a pain dr. at a clinic and as long as I see my reg dr every 3 months(who knows I take kratom) I am good. Banning Kratom would send me back into a horrible life. I know I will always need something so I can function daily with the nerve pain but forcing me to take a dr prescribed pill with so many horrible side effects when there is a natural herb that helps me and so many many others is wrong. We as citizens should have that choice. I read that MS is number 3 or 5 with opioid addiction. I can imagine how it will go up if Kratom is taken away. I have never ever known or heard of anyone dying from Kratom alone or feeling 'high'. A person can mix anything and die but that doesn't make each thing alone something that should be banned. There is not an issue here of young children using it and although some might abuse it I know the stats are far less worse than that of heroin and pain meds.Kratom is used for withdrawals from those 2 things too. Taking Kratom away from the general public because pharmaceutical companies want their share isn't right. Money should not be more important that anyone's life in America and this is what this fight feels like. Banning it will not stop the sell of it or people from using it. It will just make many Mom,dads,people  from all walks of life criminals because we choose to take something that saved us from a life of addiction. Pushing someone like me back into a life of pain pill usage when I see so much on the news how the opioid usage is a huge problem. Doesn't make any sense at all. The time and effort spent on trying to make Kratom illegal should be spent on the real problem with is opioid and heroin addiction. Especially when so many feel that our representatives in Washington are NOT listening to us or even care about us. documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Emily, and I'm a 34 year old digital media executive (Chief Digital Officer) from Seattle, Washington. I was first introduced to kratom two years ago by one of my employees, who had been using the herb to help offset his back pain and sore muscles. I'd recently undergone a spinal surgery myself, and decided to try kratom to see if it would help with my general soreness. I was pleased to discover that not only was it quite helpful with alleviating my pain, but it also provided me with an additional energy boost that was very similar to an excellent cup (or two) of coffee. It's wonderful!

Since I discovered kratom, I've found that it's been extremely beneficial for both my personal and professional life. As a person with chronic back problems who works a job that requires 8+ hours a day of sitting, its pain-reducing qualities are a life saver. I also find that kratom helps keep my energy and focus sharp, which is incredibly useful in my high-stress profession.

As an executive who certainly would NOT consider using illegal drugs, I admit that I was baffled (and a little insulted) when I read that the DEA was considering scheduling the herb as a controlled substance.  I've been using kratom daily for years, and have never experienced any side-effects from the herb -- no dependencies or negative effects. 

I'd be extremely disappointed if I'm no longer able to enjoy kratom, and ask that you reconsider your position on the matter of scheduling it as a controlled substance. From my personal experience and the experience of many other individuals I know, kratom is a highly beneficial plant that positively affects lives. Treating it otherwise would be a huge misstep, and would negatively impact the thousands of Americans currently enjoying its benefits.

Thank you for your consideration,

Emily

documents.commentText: Hello, I would just like to add my comment in support of keeping Kratom off of the scheduled regulation. Since I have been maintaining on Kratom I am no longer dependent on any medications. In fact I believe Kratom is more effective at treating the pain and I am able to use it only as needed. I have also lost weight and been able to maintain better overall health, I do not experience any negative side effects such as constipation like I was with the opiates. I really believe that Kratom has helped my life dramatically and could also help others. Since it does not create respiratory depression I feel it is a safer alternative to opiates plus I don't feel the intoxication or compulsive desire to seek out more Kratom. documents.commentText:
To Whom it may concern,

   My name is Danielle and I am writing to tell you about my positive and life saving experience with Kratom. I had a heart attack at the age of 19 and was implanted with a pacemaker. I was left with terrible anxiety and was given benzodiazepines to alieviate my symptoms. I was on this medication for 8 years, and I had also started drinking alcohol along with it to simply calm myself down. My life was in shambles by the end of it. I had lost my job, and was feeling so anxious every day that I wanted to end my life... then my boyfriend had read about Kratom on a website for natural healing, and he ordered some for me. When I got it, I wasn't sure about it, but tried it anyway.... what did I have to lose. Within the first week, I was able to stop drinking having been taking Kratom. Within a month I was able to stop taking the benzodiazepines. I have been using Kratom for almost 6 years. It saved my life. I am a fully functioning human being, a great and hard working citizen. Please hear our voice, we need this plant, it has helped millions of people. I have never gotten sick from it, I have always used it responsibly.... but even the people who took a lot of it, they never went to the ER, they were fine. I have taken large doses of this plant, and I have never had anything bad happen to me, so I do hope we can keep this for the public... it has healed my anxiety, I haven't drank in over 5 years.... and I am incredibly happy now. Danielle St. Pierre

documents.commentText:
As an oncologist with a strong interest in medicinal plants (many of our current chemotherapeutic agents for cancer have their roots in plant based medicine), I feel that it would be much more useful to public health, to initiate collection of all samples of kratom leaf currently on the market, analysis of botanical identity, and presence or absence of adulterants, and to survey the people who are currently using kratom medicinally, which appears to be primarily as an alternative to opiates for management of chronic pain. Indeed, given the current epidemic of opiate abuse/addiction and fatal overdose, it would seem that Kratom, which has been in use in SE Asia for hundreds of years, both medicinally and recreationally. Putting Kratom into schedule 1, even temporarily, will do nothing except increase adulteration on the black market, and importation will morph to smuggling, with the potential for violence, and increasing the burden on law enforcement and our judicial system. It would be a far greater service to public health to simply quietly study the existing situation, and then make recommendations as to how to make this plant medicine available to individuals for whom it may be appropriate, discover what risks exist for those who use it recreationally, and educating the public about such risks. 
sincerely,
Dwight L. McKee MD

documents.commentText:
I am 61 years old. Although I have not applied for disability, the pain I live with is a factor in my having stopped looking for work. I do not use illegal drugs of any kind.  I began using kratom in June of this year for back and fibromyalgia pain. I stopped using it on September 30 when it became a Schedule I drug. 

Kratom is especially helpful for my fibromyalgia flare-ups. It reduces the achiness and burning feeling in my body by at least 50%, and sometimes more. I use 1-2 teaspoons (I estimate 4-9 grams) of the powdered leaves (usually red bali) as needed with water and 500 mg. acetaminophen.  I am on Cymbalta and Neurontin and an NSAID, yet I still have frequent episodes of intractable pain. 

Kratom provides superb relief from pain. While using it, I also became aware that it was very good at lowering my anxiety, which goes hand in hand with my pain. I have had some terrible side effects from "approved" anxiety medications.  Kratom is very gentle compared to these other meds. 

I believe kratom can be overused. I cannot speak for others, but in my own case the most serious result of overuse is that I will develop a tolerance and I will need to take more of it for the same level of pain relief. Many times, I will skip kratom when I am in a lot of pain because I don't want to take it so often that its effect will be reduced.  In my opinion, one of the most important areas scientists can research is finding a way to keep this tolerance from happening, so that patients can get the same level of relief each time they use it.  If this could be accomplished, over-use of Kratom would unlikely be  a result for those who use it for pain.

Although kratom did lift my mood, I did not consider this being "high." From my viewpoint, kratom's analgesic effect is much more impressive than its ability to create the "mellow" feeling I sometimes feel.  I have never taken more than 20 grams in one day. (I am aware that preparations of the leaves can vary, but I always use the same provider which probably minimizes this).

I hope that a way can be found for kratom to be available for the sake of compassion to all of us who need safe ways to deal with our pain. And the same for those who wish to get off much more dangerous addictions. Currently, I obtain kratom online from a provider that I believe to be very trustworthy and honest about how they obtain and prepare kratom for their customers.

documents.commentText:
Hello, 

I would like to add my name in the support of keeping Kratom legal and unscheduled. I have used Kratom daily for the past two years and it has literally helped me turn my life around. I've been battling major anxiety and panic attacks for more than 15 years, and have been clinically diagnosed with PTSD. And like many who suffer from PTSD, I turned to alcohol to cope/mask the symptoms. It was a losing battle and after 10 years of worsening alcoholism, my physical and mental health were on the fritz. I was also having problems in my personal relationships and at work.  

I found Kratom on an anxiety forum and decided to give it a shot. Surprisingly, I found that not only did it help me manage my anxiety, it curbed my cravings for both alcohol and harder drugs. After a short time, I was stunned to realize I hadn't had a drink in a week. Weeks turned in to months, and months turned into a year. During that time, I've gotten promoted at work and welcomed my first child into the world. I had tried and failed to quit drinking so many times, but the PTSD and anxiety always drove me back. It was miserable. Alcoholism kills so many and I had honestly become resigned to that fate. In addition to regular therapy, Kratom has given me my life back.
 
I know I'm not alone, and many others have had success with Kratom in turning their lives around from dangerous substance abuse problems. It has also provided a real alternative for those who want to avoid powerful prescription narcotics. I fear that any attempt and scheduling would severely limit access to this miraculous plant, and with the opioid epidemic taking more and more lives each day, I believe this would be a tragedy and real step backwards in this country. I've lost more friends than I can count to RX drugs. 

I do believe there should be some kind of industry standards in place, and it should be regulated like other herbal supplements. I'm a happy, law abiding dad and Kratom has helped me get my life back on track. Don't take that away from so many. Thank you for your consideration, and I hope we get this right.  

Sincerely, 

Greg Mabry

I am a 37 year old male but I dont need to tell my story as its already been told.  Instead Id like to discuss a fundamental problem with this commenting period, we simply do not have enough information to make our case or yours. https://medium.com/@anthonyroberts/dea-balks-at-latest-kratom-foia-refuses-to-provide-further-information-d725dc0ce170#.bt7ev7ed6  This is the most basic logic: in order for the public to respond (and build a case against the ban), we must have access to the same data as the DEA. This is why, in court, the plaintiff (or prosecution) is required by law to provide the defense with all of the evidence theyre using to make their case. 
The DEA has yet to prove that there has ever been a problem or epidemic with kratom. www.americankratom.org/survery_healthcare 
Emergency scheduling is not for herbal supplements it  is for dangerous chemicals like K2 and bathsalts that we heard terrifying  stories about week after week and month after month. Why are most people totally unaware about kratom?  Because there were no reports because simply put they are not the same thing, I doubt you never got even 1 plea from anyone saying please dont ban bathsalts as they will negatively impact my health and the health of our country.
And as for the negative inpacts the 15,000 plus people that are asking that you not ban kratom should speak for itself, how many deaths from kratom in this period, 0. How many from opioids ,72..a day. And this is only one aspect of the people it helps. 22  veterans a day commit suicide from ptsd issues , not to mention childhood trauma survivors with ptsd. What about all  of our families that we will become a burden to once more. WE all have one thing in common - we all have suffered so much to end up here to find a piece of mind and life, only to have it taken away would be immoral and unhuman, with the biggest drug epidemic in history, there will be much more to come with no help in sight with a system thats broken and the answer looking you in the face. Try to fix real problems instead of taking up arms in this war on drugs against people that do not want to break the law, and fight the one you are losing instead of attacking something that could be your best ally.There is so much more I could say but Im sure the 15,00 plus people in our community have spoken and should be heard.The consequences  of a ban will be far more harmful to our country .

documents.commentText:
I am a 38 year-old Technical Analyst at a major tech company.

I want to start by saying pleasese do NOT ban kratom or make it a schedule 1 substance.

I have been using kratom for over 2 years now. A friend of mine introduced it to me when I mentioned how I was having issues with anxiety that were making it difficult for me to be able to go to work. Since I have started taking kratom, it has had an incredibly positive impact on my life.

I've found kratom to be very helpful in reducing my symptoms related to anxiety and also depression.

One of the major benefits that I've noticed is that I can take it as needed instead of having to take it every day. I've had times where I've taken it daily for a few months. But there's also been times where I don't feel any need to take except for a few times over the course of several months. At those times when I did stop taking it, I didn't experience any side effects that made stopping difficult. Perhaps a headache, but it's hard to be certain if it was even related since I've always been someone who gets lots of headaches.

As I mentioned previously, kratom helps me at times when my anxiety feels overwhelming. It helps calm and relax me but it doesn't make me tired or disoriented. I need to focus and pay particular attention to details while on the job, and kratom doesn't reduce my ability to focus or concentrate, which is really fantastic.

As far as helping with depression, kratom does an amazing job at elevating my mood. I can literally feel the empty, hopeless feelings caused by depression evaporate when I take kratom. I feel like myself again and I can move forward in my life as a productive member of society.

Anyone who has suffered from anxiety or depression will know how difficult it can be. The help that kratom provides to those who suffer from anxiety and depression, is nothing short of a miracle for us, especially since kratom is a dietary supplement, it's NOT addictive, and it's NOT a drug!

Thank you for taking the time to read my comment.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I would be extremely disappointed if you decided to ignore our rights as US citizens by unfairly placing Kratom in schedule I as it does not belong in that category, or any schedule for that matter. Kratom needs to be treated like alcohol: regulated and taxed, with an age limit to purchase/consume. Kratom is a godsend for me, personally, as I suffer from chronic neck and back pain caused by cervical dystonia. Without any medication, the pain is excruciating and most OTC pain relievers do NOTHING to alleviate this. I have also suffered from anxiety and depression from a young age, and Kratom helps me with these as well. It keeps me relaxed and helps me sleep at night. It is a natural alternative to many pharmaceutical opiates that DO harm people. This substance has helped thousands stay away from those prescription pharmaceuticals that ARE dangerous and, as of this moment, Kratom has never been instigated as the cause of a death via overdose when it was not mixed with various other drugs, proving that it is much safer than alcohol. I know of many ELDERLY patients who are PRESCRIBED Kratom for various reasons, and it vastly improves their quality of life. If you are going to keep dangerous carcinogens and poisons like alcohol and tobacco legal, it would be grossly unjust to place a safe substance like Kratom in the most harshly treated category of drugs. If you keep performing 'emergency' acts like this to 'help' people, you will only continue to lose face as you reveal your ulterior motives and lack of concern for all the people this substance is helping. The 'War On Drugs' needs to end, as it is clearly not helping anyone who does drugs by treating them like criminals. If you really want to end this war, which it seems like you don't, you must decriminalize drugs and regulate them. Doing this would immediately devastate any illegal drug operations as there is simply no reason to go through them when you can legally acquire a drug and know, really KNOW, what you are getting while paying less in the process. The biggest reason that many of these drugs are so harmful is that people are acquiring 'street' versions that are often mixed with substances that are incredibly harmful on their own, not to mention that they are barely informed about the drug itself. If you would only regulate these drugs, instead of letting criminals have their way, the drug empire would collapse and we could release a great many innocent people from prison. With a doctor's supervision and INFORMATION about what they would be taking, the amount of overdoses would be staggeringly lower than it is now. But, it seems the only reason this hasn't already been done is because the government directly benefits from this, the biggest scam in the last thousand years at least. Please, consider the citizens of the planet for once, and realize that this is only hurting everyone. As long as you continue to abuse your power to ban substances uncontested, which is already in violation of our First Amendment rights, people will continue to suffer at your hands.

documents.commentText: I have been addicted to opiates and also alcohol in the past. I found kratom a few years back, and haven't had the inclination to go back to drinking or opiates. I take a very small amount of kratom once or twice a day. 2 ounces of powdered leaf kratom will last me about a month, I'd say that's a relatively small dose compared to what I read people are taking online. As I long time moderate to light user of kratom, I feel I have a good grip on the positives and negatives of taking the plant. The biggest positive I can relay to you is the energy boost and slight mood elevation I get after taking it first thing in the morning, its really the best way to get my day going. The biggest negative I've experienced with it is sporadic constipation, but I cant attribute that to the kratom 100%. I feel that the kratom ban would be a step in the wrong direction that could end up scarring this country in some of the same ways alcohol and marijuana prohibition has done. I feel a better move would be to keep kratom legal and maybe even tax it, and use the tax money to help addicts who need it. There are plenty of other problem substances that could use addressing. To me, banning kratom is like banning nicotine gun, but making sure cigarettes stay legal, it just doesn't make sense.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Laura and I am a 28-year-old wife and mother. I would like to express my opposition to the schedulingn of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine (AKA "Kratom"). I have been diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, a painful and debilitating, inherited condition. There is no cure for my illness and I have struggled to manage the symptoms throughout my life. About a year ago, Kratom was recommended to me as a possible treatment for pain and other ailments. It allowed me to begin living my life again without strong and addictive controlled substances. Kratom is not any more addictive than caffeine, and I can say from personal experience that using Kratom regularly does not lead to tolderance or a need for increased amounts. It also does not produce a "high" like prescription painkillers. Kratom has a mild, relaxing effect that is similar to drinking chamomile tea. Restricting Kratom will undoubtedly block patients with real health concerns from finding alternative treatments to opioids, including myself. Kratom has allowed me to work full-time, care for my child, and function in society. Please do not add the only thing that has truly helped my disorder to the controlled substance list.

Thank you,
Laura

documents.commentText:
Social anxiety has been the biggest struggle in my life. Outgoing people take conversational skills for granted, but for shy people this is a massive, ongoing struggle. 

This seemed normal enough growing up, but it was until adulthood with interviews and holding a job did I realize this was a real problem and was putting a real strain on my career and maintaining relationships with people, even my own family.

From my very first dose of kratom four years ago, the veil of silence was lifted from me, in a swift, gradual swoop. For the first time in my adult life, I felt NORMAL! "So this is how it feels to be social," I may very well have asked myself. Combined with the mood lifting properties of this remarkable herb, I felt an inner peace that had been missing for a long, long time.

And the best part is, kratom is not intoxicating, it does not hinder what daily life requires of me. It's as normal as drinking a cup of coffee in the morning or sipping tea in the evening.

I hate to sound rhetorical by describing kratom in such colorful ways, but it is every bit as good as I say it is. And without it, I don't think I'd be able to maintain my career nor would I have ever been able to fight my anxiety to get on a plane last summer to meet the love of my life in another country.

Kratom is a miracle.

documents.commentText:
I am a 54-year old white male. I am a husband and a father of three. I have been using Kratom as an herbal supplement for about six years. I suffer PTSD from events that happened when I was a Mormon missionary in a third world country from 1981-83. I had severe migraine headaches for about twenty-five years and I would use Imitrex injections and prescription painkillers every day. In 2007, I suffered a heart attack. I was in a downward spiral from heavy medicine use. 
I decided to try Kratom with the hopes of replacing the prescription painkillers that were destroying my work and family life. I was able to stop taking all prescription pain medication immediately. The cycle of rebound migraine headaches caused by vaso-constrictors was broken with daily kratom use and I was able to stop taking the expensive Imitrex injections and pills. 
Now, six years later, I am in perfect health. Yesterday, my blood pressure was 106/70 which is the best its been in years. My doctor is amazed that I have been able to recover so quickly from heart disease and the debilitating effects of PTSD. She has instructed me to continue doing what I am doing even though she knows very little about Kratom.
I have been able to live a healthy and happy life and be the provider my family needs because of my daily kratom supplement use. In 2007 my heart surgeon told me I would be lucky to live ten more years at the rate I was going. It is almost ten years later now and I am enjoying excellent health. I work as a technician for the company Redbox in the day. At night I work for Scholastic book fairs preparing learning materials for childrens school book fairs. I am able to be the husband, father and provider that I was meant to be. 
I live in fear of having to return to the medications that almost destroyed me though. I am very much opposed to a ban on Kratom. Please consider all the benefits Kratom offers people. I wont survive without it. 
Thank you,
Larry Angell
