I have had a very tumultuous adult  life, buried by drugs and desperation. For 4 years, I was an opiate addict who's opiate addiction eventually turned into a heroin and cocaine addiction. I tried going to rehab, used the first day I got out. The only reason I'm alive and not dead or in prison right now is because of kratom. In the past, I would do anything to get my fix. Steal, lie,  and drive hours just to fill that void in my life. Now, I believe I'm a very upstanding citizen. I'm about to be married, eventually have kids, and I actually have enough money to support my future family with a good job. 

I function normally on kratom, it just helps me get through the day and gives me energy and motivation to do what I need to do, and I never feel cravings for opiates anymore. Sure, I think about them from time to time,but giving them serious consideration is just stupid. I don't have these thoughts because I have kratom. It is cheap, legal, and virtually harmless. If it were to be made illegal I don't believe that I would continue using it, but it does worry me that if I started getting opiate cravings again that I would give in and buy some opiates. I believe I will eventually quit kratom, but right now I don't see the need to. I live a completely normal life and it does not interfere with it, if anything it helps it. But when I do quit, I want it to be on my own terms and not because the DEA considers me to be a criminal. Scheduling kratom in any way would prevent people from using it as an alternative to opiates, and cause the opiate epidemic to spike more than it already has. 

Sincerely, 

Joel O'Connor

documents.commentText: My story in short goes like this-  In 1993 I suffered a severe back injury. I spent years with doctors, pain clinics, etc., with no real results except losing all my teeth from the narcotics they were feeding me. On December 20, 2001, I had enough and stopped a 7 year morphine addiction cold turkey. The doctors were fine with the addiction, I was not. I started taking the max dosage of ibuprofen to deal with my pain, but over years of taking it, the otc meds weren't doing anything but messing up my digestive system. I did some research to find something natural to help me, and found kratom. It's been a little over a year since I started drinking the tea, and I have never felt better. To say it's addictive is just a lie. To say it's killed anyone is just a lie. It is a natural herb in the coffee family that's been used for a long time in other parts of the world. I am a successful business owner with a daughter in college. To see what the DEA and the government are doing really opens my eyes to the fact that their actions are driven by money that pharmaceutical companies stand to lose. Nothing more, nothing less. I am for regulation of purity and age restrictions on the sale of herbal supplements, but other than that, the DEA needs to keep their nose out of law abiding tax payers business. Is this still the United States of America? I feel like my constitutional rights are being infringed upon for the sake of a buck.

documents.commentText: Human beings have a tendency to react with great fear when faced with the unknown.  It is probable that this reaction is part of an evolutionary response to protect us from the many dangers that afflicted us when humanity was at the whim of our environment.  I feel this tendency still persist today when unknown substances or subjects enter into the spotlight.  We hear stories from the media, friends, and the government about how harmful or beneficial a substance maybe.  It can truly be tough to discern the truth from the fiction.  I had this fearful evolutionary response when first hearing about Kratom.  What is it? What can it do?  What are its effects?  Is it harmful?  However, I also was positively intrigued by it.  How can this help individuals afflicted by a condition or disease; either painful, emotional, or mental?  Is there a beneficial use that some people might get from it?  My curiosity was raised after listening to Chris Bell speak about his experience with it on the JRE podcast.  He raises a lot of good points about the pros/cons and the misinformation that exists out there.  As a person who believes in the freedom to choose, I believe the DEA should not legal Kratom or any other drug as schedule 1.  It completely limits any possibility of good that could come out of legitimate scientific work.  Look whats being down with MDMA by John Hopkins and Maps.  If the DEA is a responsible organization looking out for the welfare of the American Public it is their place to go after the pushers that would do us harm.  However, it is also their responsibility to allow us to make our own informed decisions.  American Citizens can not do this if Kratom is labeled a schedule 1 drug.  The DEA should do whatever is necessary to ensure scientific research can be conducted tstudy the efficacy of Kratom.  While those studies are being conducted the DEA should also respect a Citizens right to freely choose.  People who have "allegedly" died from Kratom use could have had different chemical makeups from users who have not died.  This is currently a problem for "legal" drugs that one can by over the counter or be prescribed by a doctor.  Medical science can not simply account for the limitless ways medication will affect a person.  Chris Bell's stories, if they are true, show that individuals that need medication can safely and responsibly take krater without negative, harmful, or even deadly consequences.   A

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

I work in education.  I have been using kratom off and on for some time now.  It helps me deal with back pain and anxiety, and gives me a slightly enhanced ability to focus on things like grading papers.  I have never felt "high" from it.  I have used it daily for weeks, then gone without it for months without a single feeling of withdrawal.  I do like the effects, but I do not feel the type of craving I do with, for example, caffeine (and I definitely feel withdrawal from if I go without coffee!).  I exercise regularly and lead a healthy lifestyle; at no point have I ever felt this plant weigh me down or reduce my energy level.  

It is true that I would be disappointed if this plant, which has given me some relief and no perceivable negative side effects, became suddenly unavailable to me.  But I have friends who have gone through struggles for years with dependency on other chemicals such as opiates, who have managed to finally get rid of the habit completely only through kratom, after trying everything else.  And I have recently seen video testimony of military veterans with PTSD who have found solace in this dried plant.  I find this notion even more troubling: as a society we would be condemning these brave people, who put their bodies on the line to defend this country, by denying them the freedom to ingest a natural substance that lets them find peace and relief from the pain of trauma.

Please do not ban this plant.  It will be a sad day for our country.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Sean and I am 20 years old; almost old enough to call myself an adult. I work for a laboratory in the organ procurement organization, and I take what I do seriously. This is because I take my life seriously, in every way possible. Oftentimes I feel too mature for my age by taking full responsibility for who I am as a person and for every action I make. I do the best that I can do every day at work because I like to work hard and earn my right to relax and to enjoy my life. Oftentimes I will strain myself mentally and physically to get the job done, and done right. I take pride in hard work, but not many do. So I tend to find myself working for more people than myself. This leads to excessive mental fatigue/ stress and physical stress and tension in my muscles and joints. I found out about kratom some time ago and found it to be extremely beneficial for both, physical and mental stress, that I tend to put on myself. I like the idea that nature provides a plant that remedies my work-related stress. It has been an absolute pleasure to discover and use this plant for physical and mental stress. I have also used this for pain management in other ways. One other benefit I have discovered, is that it helps me when I am sick. The kind of sick where you have a fever, body aches, nose is a faucet, stomach is unhappy, and your brain feels the pain of everything in the body and usually has unpleasant thoughts. I would take kratom amidst the pain and nausea, an hour or so later, I feel pleasantly uplifted, nose slows down on mucus, and my body aches are tolerable. I felt like I cheated. Being sick is supposed to be terrible, but kratom made it beyond tolerable. I felt so good I could work. I have done this every time I am sick or full of mucus and it always makes me feel like everything will be ok. Even though I feel like I am dying sometimes, or wanting to die. I have also used kratom for other physical pain like bruising, muscle cramps, extreme soreness from working out, any any kind of pain that I put myself through. I have also used it for social anxiety and depression with great benefit as well. Before I end this, I would like to briefly mention that I do not use kratom regularly for "fun". I only use it when I feel burdened with stress in its array of forms and triggers. It has done wonders for me as a "plant medicine". It would be very sad to see such a beneficial plant become illegal. I can handle pain, anxiety, and depression, but if there is a plant that can help, why would someone ban my right to nature? Why would someone deny access to these benefits? What is being accomplished by denying rights to a leaf? Why do I feel like crying over a plant that has helped me more than any other medicine?
